Pandit Laxmi Ganesh Tewari is a renowned Hindustani vocalist from India .
 Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari is an exponent of the Gwalior gharana of vocal music .
After studying with Dr. Lalmani Misra at Banaras Hindu University in Varanasi , he pursued education and teaching opportunities in America .
At Sonoma State University since 1974 , his career has combined performance , scholarship and teaching .
 Born in 1938 in Kanpur , Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari studied at Banaras Hindu University with Dr. Lalmani Misra , Pandit Madhav Vaman Thakar , and professor B. R. Deodhar , earning a doctor of music degree in 1967 .
 Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari moved to the United States to study at Wesleyan University , where Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari earned a Ph.D. in ethnomusicology in 1974 .
 Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari has been on the faculty of Sonoma State University in California since 1974 .
 Today Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari is one of the leading ethnomusicologists with an exemplary body of work on Indian , Buddhist , Arabian and Gamelan music .
 Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari has also made numerous recordings of Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari music ; chief amongst Indian , Buddhist , Arabian and Gamelan is Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari rendering of Sameshwari , a Raga created by Dr. Lalmani Misra to preserve the notes of Samagana of Sama Veda period .
 Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari has conducted field research in India , Turkey , Trinidad & Tobago , Thailand , Fiji , Ghana , and Zimbabwe .
 In addition to Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari books and recordings , Uttar Pradesh , India , Tewari articles have appeared in South Asia Research , South Asia Journal , and Asian Folklore Studies
Malabika Kanan was a Hindustani classical vocalist .
 Malabika Kanan was born in Lucknow to Rabindralal Roy , a musicologist .
 Malabika Kanan was married to another singer , A. Kanan .
 Malabika Kanan received the ITC Sangeet Research Academy Award in 1995 and the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 1999-2000 .
 Malabika Kanan died February 17 , 2009 in Calcutta
Dhamar is one of the talas used in Hindustani classical music .
 Dhamar is associated with the dhrupad style and typically played on the pakhawaj .
 Dhamar tala has 14 beats grouped asymmetrically into a 5-2-3-4 pattern .
A song in dhrupad style set to dhamar tala is also called a dhamar .
The text of a dhamar concerns the antics of Krishna teasing the milkmaids during the Holi Spring Festival of colours .
It is considered a relatively light and romantic musical form .
In counting out the beat , beats 1 , 6 , and 11 are clapped , and beat 8 is indicated by a wave of the hand :
An electronic tanpura is an electronic instrument that replicates the sound of an Indian string instrument known as the tanpura .
In Indian music , drone is a basic function of the music .
The development of a raga , any composition or song within raga presupposes and requires the continuous sounding of the key-note , its octave and another tone , usually the fifth or fourth .
Traditionally drone is provided by one or more tanpura player , especially for vocal performances .
The electronic tanpura was created as a marketable , practical solution for instrumentalists , having their hands otherwise engaged , who can not readily avail themselves of able tanpura players for their long hours of private practice .
Since the late 1970s , little white boxes appeared , first privately , then gradually coming openly to the stage as the technological sophistication of the models advanced .
In Indian solfege , called Sargam , Sa is the tonic , Ma , Pa and Ni are 4th , 5th and 7th tone degrees within the octave .
Generally , the electronic tanpura has one or more dials to control the tone and volume , and may have other switches and buttons that allow a certain pitch and volume to be saved and used again at a later time .
The range is usually one to two octaves .
For many musicians the electronic tanpura is a practical commodity .
It delivers a passable substitute for a real , live tanpura .
Certainly , it is much easier and less expensive than maintaining a live tanpura player .
However , the electronic tanpura is a poor substitute when compared to a good tanpura in expert hands as the tones it creates lack the dynamics of a live musician , producing a mechanical , repetitive sound .
The electronic tanpura was first invented by G Raj Narayan , an engineer-flautist from Bangalore , India , and demonstrated at the annual conference of the Music Academy Chennai in December 1979 .
 The products were manufactured by the company Raj Narayan founded , Radel .
The first versions were created with the technology then available , using discrete components and transistors .
In the late 1990s , these gave way to models using sampled recordings of the traditional tanpura on a chip .
Over the last decade , these have been further refined and the latest models can hardly be distinguished from a traditional acoustic tanpura .
The success of this invention gave rise to many other players who then started manufacturing and aggressively marketing bad copies of these products .
These copies have earned a bad name as the little white boxes and comparisons are made to the traditional acoustic tanpuras
In Hindustani classical music , vivadi refers to pitches that are not part of the arohana or avrohana of a given raga .
In general , vivadi are not to be played during an improvisation on a given raga .
So , for instance , if a raga had the structure S R G m P D N S , S N D P m G R S ; in that case , r , g , M , d and n would all be vivadi .
Although vivadi pitches are generally to be avoided during the playing of a given raga , they are occasionally added by skilled performers in order to introduce some color to an interpretation .
In Carnatic music , vivadi is used in vivadi swaram , vivadi dhosha , vivadi ragam , and by extension vivadi melakarta .
Vivadi term means going against the grain of thought or approach .
A swaram is said to be vivadi in relationship with another swaram , if there is a discordant effect produced by the swaram in relation to the other .
It is different from Apaswaram , which is incorrect swaram or incorrect rendition / pitch / frequency deviating from the swaram itself .
 A ragam is vivadi if A ragam contains vivadi swarams , especially with the vadi swaram of the ragam .
The ragam still is a valid scale and compositions are made using such ragams too .
Examples of popular Vivadi ragas are : Nata , Varali , Vagadheeswari .
 A Melakarta ragam is vivadi if A Melakarta ragam contains vivadi swarams .
40 of the 72 Melakarta ragams have vivadi swaras .
Dhosha means negative effect .
Vivadi ragams are said to have vivadi dhosha , which can be overcome by singing the vivadi swarams in certain phrases that are said to reduce the negative effect .
Articles that discusses vivadi ragas and a review of concerts that mentions some of vivadi ragams
Pandit Tarun Bhattacharya is an Indian classical musician who plays the santoor , a type of hammered dulcimer .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has learnt from Ravi Shankar .
 Tarun Bhattacharya was born on 23 December 1957 in Howrah was from Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya father Rabi Bhattacharya , honed Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya skills under the strict vigil of Pt .
 Dulal Roy and finally the culmination of Dulal Roy learning curve was when the greatest musical icon of India to the world stage Bharat Ratna late Pt .
 Ravi Shankar accepted young Tarun as Ravi Shankar only disciple on Santoor of the Maihar Gharana .
India 's Global Music Ambassador - Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has been a pioneering and revolutionary musician who has changed the face of Indian classical music , he has been truly an unparalleled music ambassador of India .
One of the most celebrated torch bearers of Indian classical music he has virtually traversed the globe many times over performing in some of most awe inspiring venues and cities as Royal Albert Hall , Palace-de-beaux , Theater - De-La-Viile , Apollo Theatre , Jubilee Auditorium , Kremlin .
The mesmerized list of admirers include Prince Charles , George Harrison , Paolo Solaris and many more of respected figures across the Globe .
 The famous Maihar Gharana 's only Santoor Maestro , Pandit Bhattacharya has revolutionized the Santoor , the instrument , as well as it 's style of play .
 He displayed for the first time ever that one could meend or glide notes at the lower octave in a hammered instrument like the Santoor .
The champion maestro changed the art of playing santoor for ever .
Maestro Tarun Bhattacharya is the inventor of mankas or fine tuners that help in the tuning of this 100 stringed instrument fast , with a long lasting effect and a very high degree of accuracy .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya innovative techniques of playing the Santoor also facilitates in the playing of Krintans , Ekharatans , Boltans broadening the utility of the Santoor in various traditional art forms .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya improvisations on the shape and string arrangements have resulted in deeper and more classical sound for the Santoor .
 Maestro Tarun Bhattacharya is recognized the world over for Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya wizardry in Ragdari , as well as , Layakari and plays music that touches the inner soul .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya Santoor thrills all Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya listener transcending countries , cultures , gender , religions and age .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya is one of the few contemporary classical musicians who reach out to Connoisseurs and the general public as Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has been to able to adapt to the changing times despite keeping to the classical genre of music .
Maestro Tarun Bhattacharya has released over 100 CDs and Cassettes .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has been the recipient of numerous felicitations like pre Grammy nomination in 97 , excellence in world music USA , and Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya CD Kirwani has been acclaimed as the top 10 in the world .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has actively endorsed the End Polio Now campaign of Rotary International as its ambassador and Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has been recognized by the Indian National Polio Plus Committee both at India Habitat Centre , New Delhi and Calcutta Press Club for Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya invaluable role in promoting the cause .

 Excellence in World Music from Music of the World - world music USA .

Felicitation at Browning University , Boston , USA .
Maestro Pt .
 Tarun Bhattacharya is a visionary who prefers to call Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya instrument Shata Tantri Veena , the original Vedic name .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya has set on a mission to realize Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya dream to revive the age-old Indian name of this very traditional classcal instrument , , instead of the derived Persian name .
Pt .
Tarun Bhattacharya strongly believes that Indian Classical Music is like a therapeutic drug .
The early introduction of this ` drug ' in schools and colleges shall help in bringing forth and develop the sensibilities of a young adolescent mind , making him/her more humane and also help negate the bad influences .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya does n't believe in making musician out of every individual , but Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya strongly believes that through the power of music individuals can be made compassionate , peace loving and of course musical .
Maestro Pt .
Tarun Bhattacharya is firm believer in the continuance of legacy and rich heritage of Indian classical music and in the Guru-Shishya parampara .
 To further this dream and belief Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya set up a unique institution Santoor Ashram a traditional Gurukul in a village near to Calcutta .
 Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya dreams that one day , quite soon , Indian Classical Music will be introduced at the grass root level , in schools and colleges .
 Maestro Tarun Bhattacharya 's humanitarian nature is manifested through Santoor Maestro Pt Tarun Bhattacharya efforts of imparting music lessons to very talented yet financially underprivileged music students .
The Ashram provides them free stay and hospitality instruments and of course music lessons thereby maintaining the purest form of Guru Shishya parampara .
Santoor Ashram , situated amidst the peaceful tranquility and greenery of rural Bengal , has helped shape the careers of some of the recognized musicians of today .
Despite financial constraints Pt Tarun Bhattacharya continuously strives to develop and shape young , promising classical music careers
 Ashutosh Bhattacharya was a noted Indian classical musician of Hindustani classical music from Varanasi , Uttar Pradesh , who was Tabla player and music educator , besides a practicing Ayurvedic doctor .
 In 1966 , Ashutosh Bhattacharya was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship the highest honour conferred by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama .
 Born in a Bengali family in Varanasi , Uttar Pradesh , Uttar Pradesh , Ashutosh Bhattacharya grew up in the family of Ayurvedic doctors , where both a Bengali family father and grandfather practiced Ayurvedic medicine .
 However , at an young age a Bengali family showed musical inclination and at age 8 started learning pakhawaj from Pandit Ram Nath Mishra .
 After a few years of training , a Bengali family switched to learning tabla from Pandit Kanthe Maharaj , noted tabla player of the Benares gharana , and uncle of Kishan Maharaj .
 a Bengali family started performing at the age of 21 , when in 1937 , a Bengali family accompanied sarod maestro Allauddin Khan at the music concert in Allahabad .
 In the coming years , a Bengali family accompanied leading musicians like , Pt .
Ravi Shankar , Ustad Ali Akbar Khan and Ustad Vilayat Khan .
 Besides Ravi Shankar musical career , Ravi Shankar also practiced Ayurvedic medicine at Ravi Shankar clinic in Varanasi , Uttar Pradesh , and taught numerous students .
 Ravi Shankar died on February 9 , 2004 in Varanasi , Uttar Pradesh , after a brief illness , at the age of 86 .
 Ravi Shankar son , Debabrata Bhattacharya is also a table player
Debasis Chakroborty is an Indian classical slide guitar player who belongs to the Senia-Maihar Gharana .
 Debasis Chakroborty was born in Calcutta , India , and was groomed in the atmosphere of music from Debasis Chakroborty childhood .
 Debasis Chakroborty began learning guitar from Debasis Chakroborty father Sh .
Madhusudan Chakroborty .
 Madhusudan Chakroborty . then came under the tutelage of Pt .
Barun Kumar Pal , a renowned guitarist from Kolkata and Pt .
Jotin Bhattacharya , an eminent Sarod player and senior disciple of Ustad Baba Allauddin Khan Sahib of Maihar Gharana .
 Later on , Debasis Chakroborty became a disciple of the guitar maestro Pundit Brij Bhushan Kabra .
Debasiss style of playing combines both Gayaki and Tantrakari Angs .
 Debasiss is still following the oldest tradition of playing Sarode , Sitar and Veena with Sarode modified Hawaiian guitar , which has Sitar own beautiful technical virtuosity and three octave advantages .
 Debasiss purity of style , uniqueness of imagination and total absorption with melody coupled with Debasiss brilliant technique in which `` Tantrakari '' and `` Layakari '' are prominent and make Layakari recital enchanting .
 Debasiss is an `` A '' grade artiste of Broadcasting Corporation of India in both Hindustani Classical and light music and performed in the prestigious National programme .
 Debasiss is an I.C.C.R. empanelled artiste under the Ministry of external affairs , Govt .
 of India .
 Debasiss visited several Universities and institutions around the world as visiting faculty / Artist in Residence and performed in many prestigious concerts and conferences which were widely appreciated .
 At present , Debasiss lectures in the Department of Music , Institute of Visual Performing Arts & Research , Mangalayatan University , Aligarh
Pandit Basavraj Rajguru was born at Yaliwal , a village in the north Karnataka district of Dharwad , a great centre of Hindustani classical music .
 Pandit Basavraj Rajguru was a leading Hindustani vocal musician in the Kirana Gharana .
 Due perhaps to Pandit Basavraj Rajguru aversion for publicity and Pandit Basavraj Rajguru simple and scholarly lifestyle , Pandit Basavraj Rajguru never achieved the level of fame of Pandit Basavraj Rajguru contemporaries Bhimsen Joshi and Gangubai Hangal of the same gharana .
 Pandit Basavraj Rajguru received many awards , including the Padma Bhushan .
 Born into a family of scholars , astrologers and musicians , the young Basavraj was initiated into classical music at an early age by his father , who was himself a renowned Carnatic musician trained in Tanjavur .
Later he travelled widely in search of musical knowledge to which he dedicated his entire life .
He chose to live a quiet life away from glamour and its attendant trappings .
He excelled both as performer and teacher .
 Besides being a great classicalist , Rajaguru was adept at composing and singing vachanas which made his music more accessible to the general public of Karnataka state .
Basavaraj was fond of music from a very young age .
 Basavaraj would try to persuade drama producers and actors to let Basavaraj sing in their plays , and first became known while singing for Vamanrao Master 's traveling drama company .
 When Basavaraj was 13 years old , Basavaraj lost Basavaraj father .
 Basavaraj uncle became concerned about His uncle future in drama .
 By a fortuitous stroke of fate , the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai discovered the young Basavraj and with little convincing from the MaTh 's swamiji , took the lad into the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai tutelage .
Since then his music embraced a whole new beginning .
 Panchakshari Gawai gave all the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai musical knowledge to the young Basavraj and other students who were not in a position to pay guru dakshina to Basavraj and other students guru .
 the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai mastered several Ragas and styles .
 the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai also became adept at some other arts like wrestling , swimming and cooking .
 the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai teacher would personally make sure that each of His teacher students practiced for at least 12 to 15 hours a day .
 When the young Basavraj graduated the young Basavraj asked the young Basavraj guru what the young Basavraj wanted as gurudakshina , and the young Basavraj guru replied that this would consist of Basavraj passing on what he had learnt from his guru to his own disciples .
 In 1936 at the 600th anniversary of the Vijayanagar Empire in Hampi , the young Basavraj gave the young Basavraj first concert with the young Basavraj guru the blind Ganayogi Panchakshari Gawai .
Fifteen thousand people listened silently to the young musician singing Bageshri and the vachana Nijaguna Shivayogi .
 After the passing away of Panchakshari Gawai in 1944 , the young Basavraj moved to Bombay and had the chance to learn from the legendary Kirana musician and teacher Sawai Gandharva .
 But Sawai Gandharva was suffering from paralysis and had to leave Bombay , so teacher Sawai Gandharva told Sureshbabu Mane , another great Kirana musician and Guru of Dr. Prabha Atre , to take good care of the young Basavraj .
 After learning from teacher Sawai Gandharva , Rajaguru quest took teacher Sawai Gandharva to the North West of Pakistan , where teacher Sawai Gandharva learned from Ustad Waheed khan , Gawai 's guru .
 In Karachi teacher Sawai Gandharva learnt from Ustad Latif Khan for six months .
 teacher Sawai Gandharva was not afraid to accept any challenge .
 Once teacher Sawai Gandharva had to sing after Ustad Nishad Khan and teacher Sawai Gandharva went up to the stage confidently and Ustad Nishad Khan had to accept Ustad Nishad Khan defeat from the young Basavraj .
 On another occasion it is reported that Chhote Ghulam sang Raga Todi so well that nobody dared to defeat Chhote Ghulam , but the young Basavraj did .
 During the partition of India and North West of Pakistan in 1947 , Ustad Latif Khan advised Ustad Latif Khan for six months to take a train carrying thousands of Hindus across the border .
 The train was stopped and attacked on the border but the young Basavraj managed to escape by clinging to the bottom of the carriage all the way from the border to Delhi .
 the young Basavraj fame had spread far and wide and continued to spread ; concert invitations came from every corner of the country .
 the young Basavraj repertoire ranged from the pure classical , Dhrupad to Vachanas , Natyageet , Thumri , and Ghazal spanning eight languages .
 the young Basavraj knew more than forty types of raga and the young Basavraj would sing Vachanas one after another right then and there .
 After the young Basavraj concert in Delhi information minister , B.V. Keskar announced , Arre , hamare Rajguru to hukumi yekka hai !

 At another concert Begum Akhtar , declared , Pandit Basavraj Rajguru yane sur ka badshah .
 or Pandit Basavraj Rajguru signifies the king of music .
 The Government of India bestowed upon Pandit Basavraj Rajguru the Padma Shri in 1975 and the Padma Bhushan in 1991 .
 Pandit Basavraj Rajguru also received Sangeet Natak Akademi awards from central and state governments .
 Pandit Basavraj Rajguru was also awarded with prestigious titles by various organizations and an honorary doctorate by the Karnataka University , Dharwad .
 Besides being an accomplished and talented singer , Rajaguru was patient and caring towards Rajaguru students .
 Rajaguru would never get tired of repeating taans for Rajaguru students ; Rajaguru would never get angry .
 Rajaguru would always tell Rajaguru students that no matter how great they were , if they couldnt pass on what they had acquired to somebody else , the greatness would be worthless .
 Rajaguru was a strict vegetarian and never even tasted tea in Rajaguru life .
 Rajaguru had a very strict regimen of Puja , sadhna , teaching and walking .
 Rajaguru diet was oriented towards preserving Rajaguru voice and Rajaguru never ate or drank anything fried , frozen or fatty .
 Rajaguru dream of coming to U.S. eluded Rajaguru .
 Rajaguru had planned a concert tour in the U.S. in the fall of 1991 , and Rajaguru got a performer 's visa , but on Rajaguru way back to Dharwad Rajaguru had a minor heart attack and was admitted to a hospital in Bangalore .
 Rajaguru disciple , Nachiketa Sharma was beside Nachiketa Sharma when Nachiketa Sharma breathed Nachiketa Sharma last .
 Nachiketa Sharma told Nachiketa to pick the Tambura and sing the SA for Nachiketa Sharma , and declared it was time for Nachiketa Sharma to leave this world .
Basavraj Rajguru died in July 1991 , one of three illustrious Dharwad musicians to do so during this period .
 After Pandit Basavraj Rajguru death , Pandit Basavraj Rajguru wife and Nachiketa Sharma carried Pandit Basavraj Rajguru dead body on 21 July 1991 to Dharwad , where his wife and Nachiketa Sharma taxi was greeted by the whole city .
Pt .
 Mallikarjun Mansur paying Pandit Basavraj Rajguru last respects to Rajaguru declared , Even in his death he looks like a king !

The first Pt .
Basavaraj Rajguru Memorial National Award was conferred on vocalist Pt .
Ullas Kashalkar of Kolkata on 23 August 2011 during the 91st birth anniversary of Pandit Basavaraj Rajguru .
The national award carries a cash prize of Rs .
1 lakh and a citation .
On the occasion two young musicians Jayateerth Mevundi and Sangeet Katti were conferred the Pt .
Basavaraj Rajguru Memorial Yuva Puraskars which carry a cash prize of Rs .
25,000 each and a citation
Rishab Prasanna is an Indian flute or bansuri player .
 Rishab Prasanna was born in New Delhi .
 Rishab Prasanna is the son of the flute and shehnai player , Pt .
Rajendra Prasanna .
 Rishab Prasanna learned Indian classical music from Rishab Prasanna grandfather , Pt .
 Raghunath Prasanna , Raghunath Prasanna father Pt .
 Rajendra Prasanna , and Rajendra Prasanna . uncles Sh .
Ravi Shankar Prasanna , and Sh .
Rakesh Prasanna .
 Apart from Rakesh Prasanna . solo concert , Rakesh Prasanna . is also known for playing with Rakesh Prasanna . brother , Rajesh Prasanna .
 Rakesh Prasanna . travelled to globally to play Rakesh Prasanna . music , and has worked on several projects with different genres , such as jazz , Swedish folk and oriental music in Egypt , including French theatre .
 Ravi Shankar Prasanna frequently travelled to other countries for Ravi Shankar Prasanna projects , solo concerts and workshops .
 Major concerts that Ravi Shankar Prasanna has played at include the WOMAD Festivals in Australia , and New Zealand , and the Festival international de la musique andalou , in Algeria
Amjad Ali Khan is an Indian classical musician who plays the Sarod .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was born into a musical family and has performed internationally since the 1960s .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was awarded Indias second highest civilian honor , the Padma Vibhushan , in 2001 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was born in Gwalior on 9 October 1945 as Masoom Ali Khan , the youngest of seven children , to Gwalior on 9 court musician Hafiz Ali Khan and Rahat Jahan .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan family is part of the Bangash lineage and Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan is in the sixth generation of musicians ; his family claims to have invented the sarod .
 His personal name was changed by a sadhu to Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan received homeschooling and studied music under Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan father .
 In 1957 , a cultural organization in Delhi appointed Hafiz Ali Khan as its guest and the family moved to New Delhi .
 Friends of Hafiz Ali convinced him of the importance of formal schooling for his son ; as a result , Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was taken to meet the Principal of Modern School in New Delhi and admitted there as a day scholar .
He attended Modern School from 1958 to 1963 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan first performed in the United States in 1963 and continued into the 2000s , with Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan sons .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan has experimented with modifications to Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan instrument throughout Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan career .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan played with the Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra and worked as a visiting professor at the University of New Mexico .
 In 2011 , Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan performed on Carrie Newcomer s album Everything is Everywhere with Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan sons .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan has recently been awarded 21st Rajiv Gandhi National Sadbhavna Award .
20 August is celebrated as harmony day , the birth anniversary of Rajiv Gandhi .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan received the Padma Shri in 1975 , the Padma Bhushan in 1991 , and the Padma Vibhushan in 2001 , and was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award for 1989 and the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship for 2011 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was awarded the Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize in 2004 .
The U.S. state Massachusetts proclaimed 20 April as Amjad Ali Khan Day in 1984 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was made an honorary citizen of Houston , Texas , and Nashville , Tennessee , in 1997 , and of Tulsa , Oklahoma , in 2007 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan received the Banga-Vibhushan in 2011 .
 Sarod maestro Amjad Ali Khan , who has shared Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan rich experience in Indian classical music in classes across the West , will now teach for a quarter at Stanford University , this course will have lessons on the Sarod as well .
A Gulzar directed documentary on Amjad Ali Khan won Filmfare award in 1990 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan cared for Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan diabetic father until Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan died in 1972 .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan family arranged a marriage , which failed , and Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan was married a second time , to Bharatanatyam dancer Subhalakshmi , on 25 September 1976 .
Subhalakshmi Barooah Khan is a native of Assam and has stopped performing .
 They have two sons , Amaan , the older one , and Ayaan , who were taught music by They father .
 Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan is a Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan and Gwalior court musician Hafiz Ali Khan wife is a Hindu .
 They family home in Gwalior on 9 was made into a musical center and They live in New Delhi
Tappa is a form of Indian semi-classical vocal music .
Its specialty is its rolling pace based on fast , subtle and knotty construction .
Its tunes are melodious , sweet and depict the emotional outbursts of a lover .
Tappas were sung mostly by songstresses , known as Baigees , in royal courts .
Tappa originated from the folk songs of the camel riders of Punjab , the Tappa style of music was refined and introduced to the imperial court of the Mughal Emperor Muhammad Shah .
And later on by Mian Ghulam Nabi Shori or Shori Mian , a court singer of Asaf-Ud-Dowlah , Nawab of Awadh .
 In Bengal , Ramnidhi Gupta composed Bengali tappas and Bengali tappas are called as Nidhu Babus Tappa .
 Tappa gayaki took new shape and over decades became puratani , a semi-classical form of Bengali songs .
 Nidhu Babus Tappa , as a significant genre in Bengali musical styles , reached levels of excellence in lyrics and rendition , arguably unmatched in other parts of India .
Hugely popular in the latter half of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th , Tappa was the genre of choice of the wealthy elite as well as the classes with more modest means .
An evolved format of the tappa was the baithaki style , which evolved under the direct patronage of the landed elites of the zamindari classes of the late 19th and early 20th centuries , in their baithak-khanas and jalsaghar .
Composers of repute included Bidyasundar , Roopchaand Pakkhi , Dadathakur , Hiralal Sarkhel and many others .
Unfortunately , tappa being mainly a vocal tradition , a lot of priceless material from the body of art has been lost in the passage of time .
A lot of celebrated artists have passed away before recordings of music became common .
What is left today is mainly handed down from the generations by oral traditions as well as some written matter , occasionally turned up in the course of research .
 Ramkumar Chattopadhyay was perhaps the most significant vocal proponent in recent times , of the tappa style in Bengal , renowned for Ramkumar Chattopadhyay semi-humorous and majorly artistic renditions and Ramkumar Chattopadhyay comical incorporation of English into the Bengali lyrics , either Ramkumar Chattopadhyay own translations or Ramkumar Chattopadhyay anecdotal translations based on prior sources , ostensibly for the comprehension of the British sahibs in the British Raj era , but containing many subversive and sarcastic tones in the English transliterations , clearly against the Imperial regime , but subtly put so as not to arouse the suspicion of the strict and sensitive colonial government and invite charges of sedition .

Among the prominent living performers of this style are Pt .
Laxmanrao Pandit of Gwalior , Shanno Khurana , Pt .
 Manvalkar of Gwalior , Girija Devi of Benaras , Dr. Ishwarchandra R. Karkare of Gwalior , Smt .
Malini Rajurkar , Shri .
Sharad Sathe , Manjiri Asnare Kelkar of Jaipur-Atrauli Gharana and Pandit Yashpaul of the Agra Gharana .
 In Bengal , there is a current resurgence of the tappa , with fresh talent beginning to carve out their niches , such as Riddhi , Srikumar Chattopadhyay , Pritam Bhattacharjee , and many others
Sanam Marvi is a Pakistani folk and sufi singer .
 Sanam Marvi sings in Punjabi and Sindhi languages .
Sanam Marvi was born Hyderabad , Sindh , Pakistan in a Muslim Sindhi family .
 Sanam Marvi fathers name is Faqeer Ghulam Rasool , a sufi singer .
 Sanam Marvi had eight siblings .
 Sanam Marvi started training at the age of seven and used to accompany Sanam Marvi father to his performances at various shrines of sufis in Pakistan , including Sindh and Punjab .
 Sanam Marvi later trained under Ustad Fateh Ali Khan of Gwalior gharana .
Sanam Marvi debuted at ` Virsa Heritage ' , a programme on PTV .
 Sanam Marvi became popular after Sanam Marvi performance at Coke Studio , a Pakistani television series featuring live music performances .
 Sanam Marvi has since appeared in two seasons of the Coke studio .
 Sanam Marvi perform sufi concerts around the world .
 Sanam Marvi is among the finest performers in the Sufi , ghazal and folk genres Sanam Marvi sings compositions of Allama Iqbal , Baba Bulleh Shah , Baba Sheikh Farid , Alam Lohar , Sachal Sarmast , the Sufi mystic from Sindh , Shah Abdul Latif Bhittai .
 Sanam Marvi made Sanam Marvi debut in with a solo performance at 2010s Jahan-e-Khusrau , the Sufi music festival .
 In February 2011 , Sanam Marvi performed with Indian playback singer Rekha Bhardwaj at Times of Indias Aman ki Asha at Chowmahalla Palace , Hyderabad .
 Sanam marvi has made Sanam Marvi Bollywood singing debut with Ali Zafar starer London , Paris , New York , singing along with Hadiqa Kiyani and Ali Zafar .
 Sanam Marvi is married to Hamid Ali and together Hadiqa Kiyani and Ali Zafar have three children
Rasoolan Bai was a leading Indian Hindustani classical music vocal musician .
 Belonging to the Benaras gharana , Rasoolan Bai specialized in the romantic Purab Ang of the Thumri musical genre and tappa .
 Rasoolan Bai was born in 1902 at Kachhwa Baazar , Mirzapur , Uttar Pradesh , in a poor family , though Rasoolan Bai inherited the musical legacy of Rasoolan Bai mother Adalat , and displayed Rasoolan Bai grasp over classical Ragas as an early age .
 Recognising this at the age of five , Rasoolan Bai was sent to learn music from Ustad Shammu Khan , and later from sarangiyas Ashiq Khan and Ustad Najju Khan .
Rasoolanbai became an expert in Tappa singing as well as Purab Ang , Thumri , besides dadra , poorbi geet , hori , kajri and chaiti .
 Thumri first performance was held in Dhananjaygarh court , after Her first performance success Thumri started getting invitations from local Rajas of the time , thus Thumri went on to dominated the Hindustani classical music genre for next five decades , based in Varanasi and became the doyenne of Benaras gharana .
 In 1948 , Thumri stopped performing mujra and moved out of Thumri kotha , started living in a bylane of Varanasi and married a local Banarasi sari dealer .
A contemporary of Siddheswari Devi also from the same gharana , besides , concerts and mehfils , she often sang on Lucknow and Allahabad stations of All India Radio and Doordarshan till 1972 , and her last public singing was held in Kashmir .
She was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in Hindustani music Vocal in 1957 by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy of Music , Dance and Theatre .
Despite an illustrious musical career , she died in penury , running a small tea shop next to the radio station where she had often broadcast from .
She has also taught noted classical singer Nainna Devi .
Her house of burnt during 1969 communal riots in the city .
She died on December 15 , 1974 , at the age of 72 .
 Rasoolan Bai and the tawaif or courtesan tradition of women musicians was featured in the film The Other Song by Saba Dewan , also featuring Rasoolan Bai more famous song , Lagat karejwa ma chot , phool gendwa na maar , a 1935 Gramophone recording
Asgari Bai was a renowned Indian Dhrupad singer .
 She was a recipient of Padma Shri , Tansen Samman , Academy Nari Shakti Samman and Shikhar Samman .
She has also been felicitated with Nari Shakti Samman .
Crowned with many awards , the artiste enthralled music lovers not only in Madhya Pradesh but also across the country with her unique style and talent for decades .
Asgari Bai was born in Bijawar , Chhatarpur .
She had come with her mother Nazeera Begum to Tikamgarh .
 Her mother was a court singer for the erstwhile royal family of Bijawar , while her grandmother Balayat Bibi adorned the court of Ajaygarh princely state .
Asgari Bai made her Guru to Zahoor Khan resident of Gohad , Bhind .
She had been in Tikamgarh Raj Darbar up to 35 years .
Asgari Bai acquired extraordinary expertise in Dhrupad to reign as the main court singer for the Orchha dynasty .
She was also invited by other royal families to treat music lovers to her spellbinding .
 Asgari Asgari Bai was married at the age of 35 years with Chiman Lal Gupta of Agra .
She has 5 sons and 3 daughters .
She was awarded the Padmashri on March 24 , 1990 .
She was awarded Sangeet Natak Akademi award in February 1987 , and honoured by the Madhya Pradesh government with the Tansen Samman in December 1985 and the Sikhar Samman in February 1986
Mohammad Sabir Baburaj , also known as M. S. Baburaj , was a Malayalam music composer .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj is often credited for the renaissance of Malayalam film music .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj has rendered music to many evergreen Malayalam film songs .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj was born on 29 March 1921 in Kozhikode , then known as Calicut .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj early childhood was spent in destitution and poverty .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj father , Jan Muhammed Khan , who was a Hindustani musician from Bengal who frequently held concerts in Kerala , deserted Jan Muhammed Khan Malayali mother when Jan Muhammed Khan was very young , and returned to Jan Muhammed Khan native Kolkata .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj thus became a fatherless , often singing songs in trains to make a living .
 But as luck would have it , a policeman , Kunjahammed , an enthusiast of music , from his native town of Kozhikode , noticing the boys vocal talents , decided to virtually adopt him .
 One of his greatest achievements was the introduction of Hindustani strains into Malayalam popular music .
 He successfully composed melodies based on Hindustani Ragas and blended Malayalam lyrics into them .
 Most of the lyrics were written by eminent Malayalam poets like P. Bhaskaran and Vayalar .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj learned basic lessons of Hindustani music from Mohammad Sabir Baburaj father from a very young age , but Mohammad Sabir Baburaj could not learn Hindustani music for long due to Mohammad Sabir Baburaj fathers demise .
In search of pure music , young Baburaj visited West Bengal , Mumbai and Sri Lanka .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj learned Harmonium in these period .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj came back to Kerala to a miserable life .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj sang on the streets of Kozhikode to earn Mohammad Sabir Baburaj livelihood.Police constable Kunju Muhammed , who was a fan of Baburajs father adopted Baburajs father and brought up .
 Later Mohammad Sabir Baburaj started composing music for the Malayalam dramas in the Malabar region and thus slowly entered the field of music direction .
 In 1957 , Mohammad Sabir Baburaj composed music for the Malayalam film `` Minnaminungu '' , by Ramu Kariat , thus entered the Malayalam film industry .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj was also an accomplished singer and harmonium player .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj died an early death , on 7 October 1978 at the age of 57 .
 Mohammad Sabir Baburaj was survived by Mohammad Sabir Baburaj wife and children .
 The Baburaj - P. Bhaskaran - K. J. Yesudas combination produced many of the most memorable tunes of the 60s and 70s .
 Most of Mohammad Sabir Baburaj classic duets were sung by K. J. Yesudas & S. Janaki , each recording solo Baburaj compositions as well .
The Baburaj - S. Janaki partnership is sometimes compared to that of Madan Mohan and Lata Mangeshkar combination of Hindi Music .
 Many of Baburajs songs remain wildly popular in Kerala to date , with songs like Oru Pushpam Maatram frequently rendered on stage at various events .
 The Manorama Music company , chanced upon an old audio cassette of Mohammad Sabir Baburaj rendering some of Mohammad Sabir Baburaj own compositions .
 The Manorama Music company was recorded during one of those heady musical evenings that Mohammad Sabir Baburaj and Mohammad Sabir Baburaj friends occasionally indulged in , towards the end 1960s , when most Mohammad Sabir Baburaj greatest hits were composed .
The cassette was re-mixed and became an instant hit .
The tracks gave Kerala a rejuvenated taste of Baburajs music .
 Though a successful composer , Mohammad Sabir Baburaj was never a careerist .
 Today , various clubs and musical organisations conduct stage programs in honor of Mohammad Sabir Baburaj , and hand over the proceeds to Mohammad Sabir Baburaj family.As with the case with many erstwhile musical geniuses , Mohammad Sabir Baburaj concentrated solely on Mohammad Sabir Baburaj music .
 During Mohammad Sabir Baburaj time , money was not easy to come for artists , and Mohammad Sabir Baburaj was never managed to earn much , dying a poor mans death .
 ` Thrikkakkare theerthakkare ' in the 1978 film ` Yagaswam ' directed by Hariharan was Hariharan last recorded song .
 The following is an incomplete list of movies that Mohammad Sabir Baburaj had composed Baburajs songs for .
 All the films are in Malayalam
Bickram Ghosh is an Indian tabla player who performs Hindustani classical music and fusion music .
 Bickram Ghosh music is strongly influenced by thumri and khayal genres of the Patiala gharana .
 Bickram is known to experiment and reinterpret music and culture ; Bickram dabbles in a vast repertoire of musical genres , from classical , rock , new-age , fusion to film music .
 Bickram was born in Kolkata , West Bengal to the tabla maestro Pandit Shankar Ghosh and classical vocalist , Sanjukta Ghosh .
 Bickram studied at La Martiniere Calcutta and graduated in English from St. Xaviers College , Kolkata and Masters in English Literature from Jadavpur University .
 Bickram started learning tabla from Bickram father Pandit Shankar Ghosh , who had played with Ustad Ali Akbar Khan .
Bickram Ghosh has performed with well-known performers including Ustad Ali Akbar Khan and Pandit Ravi Shankar .
 Bickram Ghosh also performed in jugalbandis with Bickram Ghosh father in some concerts .
 Bickram worked with George Harrison just before the ex-Beatle 's death .
 Bickram performs in various avatars .
 Bickram long-standing band , Rhythmscape , which performs neo-fusion music , celebrated their 10th anniversary in 2011 .
 To celebrate the occasion Rhythmscape collaborated with Greg Ellis to perform in Kolkata and Mumbai , an event organized by Folktronic .
The band also released their second album , Transformation , which went on to win the Best Fusion Album at the Indian Recording Arts Awards 2012 .
 Bickram performs within Troikala with Assamese folk/indie singer Papon and Scottish singer-songwriter Rachel Sermanni .
 Troikala was curated and organized by British Council in association with Folktronic .
 Troikala performed as part of fusion Sufi act , Sufusion with vocalists Ambarish Das and Parvati Kumar , keyboardist Indrajit Dey , and drummer Arun Kumar .
 Bickram collaborated with Sonu Nigam to compose the music for the film Jal .
 Bickram has also scored music for many movies including the Mira Nair production , Little Zizou .
 Bickram launched Bickram music company , Melting Pot Productions , in October 2010 .
 On 1 October 2012 , Bickram won the 2012 GIMA in the Best Pop/Rock Single category for Bickram composition , Vande Mataram , featuring a host of artists across India , including Sonu Nigam , Shankar Mahadevan and Sunidhi Chauhan .
 In June 2012 , Bickram performed a concert One World Fusion Extravaganza at Shilpakala Vedika auditorium in Hyderabad to mark World Music Day .
 Bickram appeared in an episode of MTV Roots .
Bickram Ghosh taught a percussion course entitled Repercussion for Ace Open University via online streaming
Manju Mehta was born in well-known Bhatt family of Jaipur .
 Manju Mehta had Manju Mehta initial training in sitar from Manju Mehta elder brother Pandit Shashimohan Bhatt .
 Manju Mehta younger brother is the world renown Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt .
 Manju Mehta learned classical music under Damodarlal Kabra and Pandit Ravi Shankar .
Manju Mehta is a top Grade artist on All India Radio .
She is the co-founder of Saptak school of music @ Saptak trust Saptak Festival of Music held every year in Ahmedabad
Debashish Bhattacharya is an Indian classical musician who plays the lap slide guitar .
 Debashish Bhattacharya was born into a musical family in Kolkata , it became apparent that Debashish Bhattacharya was skilled at a young age .
 Debashish Bhattacharya parents , both traditional Indian vocalists , gave Debashish Bhattacharya a basic understanding of music and Debashish Bhattacharya first began strumming a guitar at age three , when Debashish Bhattacharya father gave him a full-size Hawaiian lap steel guitar .
 Debashish Bhattacharya made Debashish Bhattacharya debut at the age of four on All India Radio , in Calcutta .
 At the age of nine , Debashish Bhattacharya left Debashish Bhattacharya parents for ten years to study under the pioneer of Indian slide-guitar Brij Bhushan Kabra .
 At age twenty , Debashish Bhattacharya was awarded the President of India Award for winning the National Music competition of All India Radio .
 Debashish Bhattacharya originality as a musician has earned Debashish Bhattacharya global admiration , and Debashish Bhattacharya has performed on networks all over the world .
 Debashish Bhattacharya has attracted attention to the slide guitar and Indian classical music within India and globally .
 Today Debashish Bhattacharya has more than 2000 students in India and other countries , and thousands of musicians , music directors , teachers , and followers who have been led to the new language of old traditional Indian music of Debashish Bhattacharya .
 Debashish Bhattacharya invented Debashish Bhattacharya own slide-guitars , unique to Debashish Bhattacharya compositions , which Debashish Bhattacharya calls the Trinity of Guitars .
These hollow neck instruments are the 24-string chaturangui , the 14 string gandharvi and the anandi , a 4-string lap steel ukulele .
 He opened a new Universal School of Music in Kolkata , India , where he teaches students from all over the world the principle universal form of Indian music and special course of Guitar .
The school is a non-profit organisation , works for restoring music , musician and traditional art .
 His most popular albums are : Mahima with Bob Brozman , and Calcutta Slide-Guitar , Vol .
3 .
Both of these albums are on Riverboat records and ranked in the top 10 of the Billboard World Music Charts .
 Both of these albums was nominated for a 2009 Grammy Award in the category of Best Traditional World Music Album for Both of these albums album Calcutta Chronicles
Vilayat Hussain Khan was one of the prominent figures of Agra Gharana , who was known both as singer and teacher .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan father , Natthan Khan , was himself a well known singer , and a noted guru .
 Vilayat Hussain Khans elder brothers were also noted singers and taught Vilayat Hussain Khans elder brothers after their fathers early death .
 Abdullah Khan was Natthan Khans son who was several years senior to Abdullah Khan brother Vilayat Hussain Khans elder brothers .
Vilayat Hussain Khan , the singer , is not to be confused with the famous and controversial sitar player Vilayat Khan .
 Vilayat Khan the singer had several disciples in Maharashtra , and the region owes its eminence in Hindustani music to the work of generous teachers like Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan , Balakrishnabuwa Ichalkaranjikar , Alladiya Khan , and Abdul Karim Khan .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan most famous guru-shishya relationship was with Jagannathbuwa Purohit and each of several disciples in Maharashtra composed several bandishes dedicated to the other .
 Vilayat Abdullah Khan singing from Abdullah Khan later years is available through commercial releases and private collectors .
Vilayat Hussain Khan composed bandishes in many ragas including some very rare ones under the nome de plume Pran Piya .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan received Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan early training in Hindustani classical music from Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan father Natthan Khan who was one of the pioneers of the Agra Gharana .
 After Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan fathers death , Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan was trained by Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan uncles Kallan Khan and Mohammad Baksh .
The total number of gurus of Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan sahib are estimated at around 42 which include aftab-e-mousiqi Ustad Faiyaz Khan .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan sahib most famous guru-shishya relationship was with Jagannathbuwa Purohit and each of them composed several bandishes dedicated to each other .
 Some of Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan sahib well known students include Mogubai Kurdikar , Pandit Yashpaul , Jagannathbuwa Purohit , Menaka Shirodkar , Ratnakant Ramnathkar , Ram Marathe , Gajananrao Joshi and Girija Kelekar .
 Some of his well known students son Yunus Hussain Khan is a prominent name in Agra Gharana as well
In London is a studio album by Hindustani classical musician Ravi Shankar .
 London was published on LP record in 1964 , originally with the title Indias Master Musician / Recorded in London .
In the late 1990s , Squires Productions was commissioned to digitally remaster the album for Compact Disc ; Wayne Hileman was the mastering engineer .
 Angel Records published the remastered album on 26 January 1999 under the shortened title In London
ITC Sangeet Research Academy is a Hindustani classical music academy run by the corporate house , ITC Ltd. .
 ITC Sangeet Research Academy is located in Kolkata , India .
Noted musicians associated with the academy include Ulhas Kashalkar .
Satyajit Ray , legendary filmmaker , was one of the trustees .
ITC Sangeet Research Academy was established in 1978 with the objective of preserving and promoting Hindustani Classical Music .
Vijay Kichlu , of the celebrated vocal duo Kichlu Brothers , was the Founding Director .
 The academy has housed several great musicians and gurus of Kolkata , India ever since ITC Sangeet Research Academy inception .
Hirabai Barodekar , Nissar Hussai Khan , Nivrutti bua Sarnaik , Latafat Hussain Khan , Ajoy Chakraborty , Arun Bhaduri , and Ulhas Kashalkar are some of the prominent musicians who have served or continue to serve as gurus .
The academy has also produced a string of performers such as Ajoy Chakraborty , Rashid Khan , Arun Bhaduri , Shubhra Guha , Kaushiki Chakraborty , Shashank Maktedar , Omkar Dadarkar , Samarth Nagarkar , Arshad Ali Khan , Shantanu Bhattacharya , Anirudh Bhattacharya , Abir Hussain , Supratik Sen Gupta and many more .
The academy carries out research in Hindustani classical music in order to restore some of the undocumented works by the maestros .
 The academy organises a classical music festival called as ITC SRA Sangeet Sammelan every year in all major cities in Kolkata , India .
These Sammelans showcase the best of their talent and also present the greatest musicians of the country .
 They also organise the ITC Ltd. SRA Mini Sangeet Sammelan in smaller cities
In Concert 1972 is a double live album by sitar virtuoso Ravi Shankar and sarodya Ali Akbar Khan , released in 1973 on Apple Records .
 Concert 1972 was recorded at the Philharmonic Hall , New York City , in October 1972 , and is a noted example of the two Hindustani classical musicians celebrated jugalbandi style of playing .
With accompaniment from tabla player Alla Rakha , the performance reflects the two artists sorrow at the recent death of their revered guru , and Khans father , Allauddin Khan .
 The latter was responsible for many innovations in Indian music during the twentieth century , including the call-and-response dialogue that musicians such as Ravi Shankar , multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan and Alla Rakha popularised among Western audiences in the 1960s .
 The album features three ragas , including Raga Sindhi Bhairavi , which Ali Akbar Khan had previously interpreted on Ali Akbar Khan landmark recording .
 In Concert 1972 1972 has received critical acclaim ; Ken Hunt of Gramophone magazine describes Gramophone magazine as a sometimes smouldering , sometimes fiery , masterpiece and the living , fire-breathing embodiment of one of the greatest partnerships ever forged in Hindustani music .
 Ali Akbar Khan and Ravi Shankar trained in the Maihar gharana under multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan and Devis father , the teacher and multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan .
Known as Baba , the latter is recognised as one of the great Indian classical music innovators of the twentieth century , having composed up to 600 pieces of music and been responsible for modernising two of its most important string instruments - the sitar and the sarod .
 Author Peter Lavazzoli credits Babas various contributions as having shaped ... much of what the West knows as Indian classical music via Ravi Shankar and Khans subsequent work .
 Of the two musicians , multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan , as a master sarodya , was the first to achieve international recognition , with a visit to New York that culminated in multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan 1955 album .
 The latter was the first album of Indian classical music , While highly regarded as solo artists , Ravi Shankar and Khans duets , known as jugalbandi , were similarly acclaimed from the 1950s onwards .
Music critic Ken Hunt writes of the tigerish potential for male and female dialogue in their jugalbandi combination .
 Compared to the more traditional musical path adopted by multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan , Born in East Bengal , multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan joined Shankar on stage at Madison Square Garden , New York , in August 1971 for the Concert for Bangladesh , organised by Harrison .
 Just over a year afterwards , on 8 October 1972 , Ravi Shankar and multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan were recorded at another New York venue , the Philharmonic Hall , accompanied again by Alla Rakha .
 Ravi Shankar often commented on the warm reception afforded Ravi Shankar by audiences in America , where New York had been the first Western city to embrace Indian music .
 As at the Bangladesh shows , there was a poignancy to this 1972 performance , following the death of Allauddin Khan in September that year .
 As audiences in America music guru , Baba had remained a revered figure in audiences in America lives , and a man considered a saint in his home town of Maihar .
 In My Music , My Life , Shankars 1968 autobiography , he writes admiringly of Baba followa way of life that was a beautiful fusion of the best of both Hinduism and Islam , and being similarly broadminded in his musical vision by -LSB- leading us away from the confines of narrow specialization that prevailed in our music .
 The ensuing duet at the Philharmonic Hall was a passionate musical exchange between Ravi Shankar and multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan , a performance that far surpasses a tribute frozen in time , according to Music critic Ken Hunt .
 In a role that Ravi Shankar had introduced as an ambassador for Indian classical music , Ravi Shankar first addressed the New York audience , to explain what the loss of Allauddin Khan meant to Indian music .
 Providing the drone-like accompaniment behind Ravi Shankar and multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan during the concert were two tambura players , named as Ashoka and Susan on the album credits .
 Lavezzoli writes of Shankars longstanding association with Lavezzoli tabla player that Alla Rakha was the ideal partner , given the drummers broad training .
 Continuing Babas efforts to elevate tabla from Shankars longstanding association previous , secondary status , Ravi Shankar allowed the drums more space in Ravi Shankar performances , ensuring that the tabla became recognised as a solo instrument .
 Hem Bihag , an evening raga , was followed by a night raga , Manj Khamaj , a piece that had appeared on Shankars At the Woodstock Festival live album .
The final selection was a morning raga , Sindhi Bhairavi .
 multi-instrumentalist Allauddin Khan had recorded this piece as side one of Music of India , and Ravi Shankar similarly included it on The Sounds of India , a 1957 album that Lavezzoli describes as Lavezzoli own counterpart to Khans debut release .
The Philharmonic Hall recording became In Concert 1972 , made up of the three ragas spread over four LP sides and totalling over 140 minutes of music .
 An Apple Records release via Shankars friendship with Harrison , the double album was produced in London by Harrison midway through sessions for his Living in the Material World album .
Harrisons co-producers were Rakhas son Zakir Hussain , and sound engineer Phil McDonald .
Apple Records issued In Concert 1972 in January 1973 in the United States , and three months later in Britain .
Billboard magazine carried an Apple trade ad with a tagline beginning : Within the small community of Brilliantly Gifted Musicians there exists an even smaller world of Masters .
 Two of these masters recently joined together in concert ... The double album appeared at the same time as a flurry of other Apple releases , some of Gifted Musicians two-record sets also , in the case of Yoko Ono s Approximately Infinite Universe and the Beatles compilations 1962-1966 and 1967-1970 .
Despite such an output of product , the label was being wound down from this point on .
 In Concert 1972 was the final Shankar-related release on Apple Records , following Shankar-related Joi Bangla EP and Raga film soundtrack and the Concert for Bangladesh triple album , all issued in 1971 .
 By the time In Concert 1972 was available in the UK , in April 1973 , Ravi Shankar , Harrison , Alla Rakha and Khans sarod-playing son Aashish were working in Los Angeles on the Shankar Family & Friends album .
The latter , which would be a Dark Horse Records release , was remastered and reissued in 2010 as part of the Ravi Shankar-George Harrison , Collaborations box set , at the same time as Shankars East Meets West Music reissued the equally rare Raga documentary and soundtrack album .
 In Concert 1972 1972 was not included in these reissue projects , but Concert 1972 was released on CD as part of Apples 1996-97 repackaging campaign .
The 2004 two-CD version reunited the two halves of Raga Manj Khamaj .
 Rough Guides world music guidebook lists In Concert 1972 among The 2004 two-CD version very selective highlights of all Shankars releases , and writes of the live album : Pyrotechnics and profundity recorded in New York , matching sitar and sarod in Hindustani musics greatest jugalbandi .
In a piece written not long after the death of Ali Akbar Khan in June 2009 , MusicTraveler website described the album as absolutely mesmerising .
 Some commentators have written that Khans sarod playing surpassed that of Ali Akbar Khan in June 2009 father , Noting the reverence afforded Baba for his contributions to the genre , Rough Guide remarks on such comparisons : While it is considered unpardonable even to whisper it , many consider the more elevating player .
Reviewing the Apple CD in June 1997 , Ken Hunt enthused in Gramophone magazine : This is the living , fire-breathing embodiment of one of the greatest partnerships ever forged in Hindustani classical music .
 Some commentators sarod-sitar brotherhood had begun under Some commentators guru during the 1940s .
 By the 1950s Some commentators combination of the robust , steel-clad sarod and the delicate sitar was highly acclaimed and in 1972 Some commentators was undoubtably the hottest ticket in Hindustani heaven ... Two musicians pouring their hearts out for their guru : that is the most succinct description of this sometimes smouldering , sometimes fiery , masterpiece .
Few Hindustani reissues - or new releases - will match its white-hot heat of creativity this year
A Meeting by the River is an album by Ry Cooder and Vishwa Mohan Bhatt , released in April 1993 through the record label Water Lily Acoustics .
Recorded in September 1992 , the improvised collaborative album features Cooder on slide guitar and Bhatt on the Mohan veena , a stringed instrument created by Bhatt .
 A Meeting by the River was produced by Kavichandran Alexander and Jayant Shah , engineered by Kavichandran Alexander and mastered by Kevin Michael Gray and Paul Stubblebine .
The album peaked at number four on Billboard Top World Music Albums chart and earned Cooder and Bhatt Grammy Awards for Best World Music Album at the 36th Grammy Awards .
The album is included in Tom Moons 2008 book 1,000 Recordings to Hear Before You Die .
A Meeting by the River was recorded in September 1992 and features Cooder solely on slide guitar and Bhatt on the Mohan veena , a stringed instrument created by Bhatt .
Allmusic s Daniel Gioffre described the instrument as a hybrid between a guitar and a vichitra veena , performed with a metal slide moving across steel rods along the neck .
Cooder had heard a recording of Hindustani classical music performed by Bhatt and was impressed by his playing and the haunting clarity of the Mohan veena .
Cooder and Bhatt met for the first time less than one hour before recording began and improvised much of the set .
 The album was produced by Kavichandran Alexander and Jayant Shah , engineered by Kavichandran Alexander and mastered by Kevin Michael Gray and Paul Stubblebine .
Cooder and Bhatt are accompanied by Cooders fourteen-year-old son Joachim on dumbek , a Middle Eastern drum , and Sukhvinder Singh Namdhari on tabla .
 The collaboration between Cooder and Bhatt marked Alexanders first attempt to record musicians of different cultures together , one of his goals when Alexanders founded the record label .
Author George Plasketes described Bhatts playing as highly nuanced while Cooder performs in a more loose-jointed , slip n slide style .
 According to Daniel Gioffre , Cooder and Bhatt use improvisation and voice-like phrasing , showing melodic performances in an alternating fashion and in unison .
The album contains four tracks , three of which were credited to Cooder and Bhatt , ranging in length from approximately seven and a half to twelve minutes .
Longing has a structure similar to a raga .
Author Tom Moon noted that Cooder takes the lead on the hymn Isa Lei as Bhatt contributes elaborate squiggling asides and swooping nosedives .
In 2011 , Bhatt performed A Meeting by the River at a music festival in honor of guru Kelucharan Mohapatra .
Bhatt said of the song : Music has no religion and no geographical or linguistic barrier .
It speaks a universal language .
My composition - A Meeting by the River - aims at explaining this .
Bhatt has stated that he considers working with Cooder his most special collaboration .
 Daniel Gioffre wrote a positive review for the album and called Cooder and Bhatt genuine masters of Cooder and Bhatt respective instruments .
 Daniel Gioffre described the musical interplay between the musicians as nothing short of astounding and the album as a rare instance in which a combination of genres works .
 Furthermore , Daniel Gioffre wrote : this album is masterfully recorded ; each instrument is clear , distinct , and three-dimensional sounding .
A Meeting by the River is a must-own , a thing of pure , unadulterated beauty , and the strongest record in Cooders extensive catalog .
Peter Margasak of the Chicago Tribune awarded the album four out of four stars , describing Cooders performance as arresting and Bhatts haunting .
 Peter Margasak of the Chicago Tribune wrote that the fusion revealed a rare , often transcendental beauty as the two artists gently and intuitively found common ground .
 Rolling Stone called the album fruitful and awarded an album by Ry Cooder three out of five stars .
A Meeting by the River reached a peak position of number four on Billboard Top World Music Albums chart .
In 1994 , the album earned Cooder and Bhatt Grammy Awards for Best World Music Album .
Bhatt became one of a few Indian musicians to have received a Grammy Award ; until A. R. Rahman won at the 52nd Grammy Awards in 2010 , previous Indian award winners had been recognized jointly with Western artists .
 The February 25 , 1995 issue of Billboard Top World Music Albums , which featured the annual Indies Spotlight and covered independent music between the January 29 , 1994 and January 21 , 1995 issues of the magazine , included A Meeting by the River at number ten on The February 25 list of the Top Indie World Music Albums .
The album is included in Tom Moons 2008 book 1,000 Recordings to Hear Before You Die : A Listeners Life List .
All tracks by Ry Cooder and Vishwa Mohan Bhatt unless noted otherwise
Kajari , derived from the Hindi word Kajra , or Kohl , is a genre of semi-classical singing , popular in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar .
 It is often used to describe the longing of a maiden for the Hindi word Kajra lover as the black monsoon cloud come hanging in the summer skies , and the style is notably sung during the rainy season .
 It comes in the series of season songs , like Chaiti , Hori and Sawani , and is traditionally sung in the villages and towns of Uttar Pradesh : around Banaras , Mirzapur , Mathura , Allahabad and the Bhojpur regions of Bihar .
Some noted exponents of Kajari are Pandit Channulal Mishra , Shobha Gurtu , Siddheshwari Devi , Girija Devi , and Rajan and Sajan Mishra
 the Keherwa or Kaharva is one of the famous talas of Hindustani music .
 Kaharva is also one of the common taals in North India , used in various popular compositions of Indian music .
 the Keherwa has many variations including dhumaali , bhajani , and qawwali .
 the Keherwa is a 8-beat pattern used in ragas .
It has eight beats in two equal divisions .
The period between every two beats is equal .
 The first beat out of 8 beats is called sam and the fifth beat out of 8 beats is called Khali .
Sam is the Ist Division .
Khali is the IInd Division .
To exhibit the Keherwa , the audience claps on the first beat and then shows that fifth beat is waived .
Cyclical series of equally periodical beats consisted of recurring claps and waves : .
The popular Hindi film song , Rang Barse Bhige Chunar Wali from Silsila , is also set in Keherwa by films music composers duo , Shiv-Hari , who are noted classical musicians
Hillel Slovak was an Israeli-American musician best known as the original guitarist and founding member of the Los Angeles rock band Red Hot Chili Peppers .
 Prior to his brother James Slovak death of a heroin overdose in 1988 , Slovak recorded two albums with the band , Freaky Styley and The Uplift Mofo Party Plan .
 his brother James Slovak guitar work was primarily rooted in funk and hard rock , although his brother James Slovak often experimented with other genres including reggae and speed metal .
 his brother James Slovak is considered to have been a major influence on the Red Hot Chili Peppers early sound .
 Born in Haifa , Israel , Slovak immigrated with his brother James Slovak family to the United States when he was five years old .
Slovak met future band mates Anthony Kiedis , Flea , and Jack Irons while attending school in Los Angeles .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis joined the group afterwards Anthym along with former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons while attending Fairfax High School ; Flea would later join the group , which later changed Flea name to What Is This ?

 Slovak , Flea , audience member Anthony Kiedis , and former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons started Red Hot Chili Peppers in 1983 , which became popular in the Los Angeles area , playing various shows around the city .
 However , Slovak quit the band to focus on What is This ?
 , which had gotten a record deal , leaving the Red Hot Chili Peppers to record This debut album without audience member Anthony Kiedis .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis rejoined the Chili Peppers in 1985 , and recorded the albums Freaky Styley and The Uplift Mofo Party Plan with the band .
 During audience member Anthony Kiedis career , Slovak developed a serious heroin addiction .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis attempted to quit the drug many times , but ultimately succumbed to audience member Anthony Kiedis addiction , dying of an overdose on June 25 , 1988 at age 26 .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis was replaced by guitarist John Frusciante , who was greatly influenced by Slovaks playing style .
Several Red Hot Chili Peppers songs have been written as tributes to Slovak , including Knock Me Down and My Lovely Man .
 In 1999 , My Lovely Man brother James Slovak published a book entitled Behind the Sun : The Diary and Art of Hillel Slovak , which features Slovaks diaries and paintings .
 Slovak was inducted into the the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Red Hot Chili Peppers on April 14 , 2012 , with a member of the Red Hot Chili Peppers brother accepting on a member of the Red Hot Chili Peppers behalf .
 Hillel Slovak was born in Haifa , Israel , to Jewish parents who were survivors of the Holocaust .
 his brother James Slovak mother was of Polish descent and his brother James Slovak father of Croatian descent .
The family emigrated to the U.S. when Slovak was five years old .
They settled in the Queens borough of New York City , then in 1967 relocated to Southern California .
As a child , Slovak developed an interest in art , and would often spend time painting with his mother , Esther .
He attended Laurel Elementary School in West Hollywood and Bancroft Jr. .
 High School in West Hollywood , where he met future bandmates Jack Irons and Michael Flea Balzary .
Slovak received his first guitar at age 13 as a bar mitzvah present , and would often play the instrument into the late hours of the night .
During this time , he was highly influenced by hard rock music such as Jimi Hendrix , Led Zeppelin , and Kiss .
 As a freshman at Fairfax High School , Slovak formed a band with former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons on drums and two other high school friends , Alain Johannes and Todd Strassman .
They called their band Chain Reaction , then changed the name to What is This ?
after their first gig .
 After one of the groups shows , Slovak met audience member Anthony Kiedis , and invited audience member Anthony Kiedis to audience member Anthony Kiedis house for a snack .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis later described the experience in audience member Anthony Kiedis autobiography Scar Tissue : Within a few minutes of hanging out with Hillel who first got me into hard rockin , I sensed that audience member Anthony Kiedis was absolutely different from most of the people Id spent time with ... audience member Anthony Kiedis understood a lot about music , audience member Anthony Kiedis was a great visual artist , and audience member Anthony Kiedis had a sense of self and a calm about him that were just riveting .
 Slovak , audience member Anthony Kiedis and Flea became best friends and often used LSD , heroin , cocaine and methamphetamine recreationally .
 Anthyms original bassist was deemed unsatisfactory , so Slovak began teaching Flea to play bass .
Following several months of commitment to the instrument , Flea developed proficiency and a strong musical chemistry with Slovak .
 When Todd Strassman saw Flea playing Anthym songs on Todd Strassman equipment Todd Strassman quit the band , with Flea quickly replacing Todd Strassman .
Shortly afterwards Anthym entered a local Battle of the Bands contest and won second place .
 afterwards Anthym started to play at local nightclubs , despite the fact that the members were all underage .
After graduating from high school , the band changed their name to What Is This ?

 Flea left afterwards Anthym around this time to accept an offer of playing bass in the prominent L.A. punk band Fear .
 What Is This ?
 continued on and performed many shows along the Southern California coast .
 Slovak , audience member Anthony Kiedis , and Flea began to create Slovak , Flea , Kiedis , and Irons own music after finding inspiration in a punk-funk fusion band called Defunkt .
The three formed a band with former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons called Tony Flow and the Miraculously Majestic Masters of Mayhem .
 The band had only one song , entitled Out in L.A. , and was formed for the purpose of playing the song once .
 The song was based on a guitar riff that Slovak wrote while jamming with former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons , and was not meant to become a real song until audience member Anthony Kiedis decided to rap over the music .
Following the groups first show at The Rhythm Lounge , the owner of the bar asked them to return , but with two songs instead of one .
After several more shows , and the addition of several songs to their repertoire , the bands name was changed to Red Hot Chili Peppers .
 After the band started to gain popularity amongst the L.A. club scene , audience member Anthony Kiedis began writing more The lyrics .
The lyrics would eventually become songs such as Green Heaven and True Men Dont Kill Coyotes , and the bands concert repertoire quickly grew to nine songs as a result of months of playing local nightclubs and bars .
 Over the course of the next six months , the Red Hot Chili Peppers played many shows in L.A. clubs and became something of an underground hit .
 Slovak , audience member Anthony Kiedis , and Flea moved into a small house in a high-crime area in West Hollywood where Slovak , Flea , Kiedis , and Irons collaborated musically and continued Slovak , Flea , Kiedis , and Irons drug addictions .
The threesome traveled to New York City to perform more shows and to spread Chili Pepperdom .
 Shortly after the trip , Slovak moved out of the groups shared house to live with Chili Pepperdom girlfriend .
The Red Hot Chili Peppers entered Bijou Studios to record a demo tape and subsequently secured a record deal with EMI .
Flea left Fear to pursue the Red Hot Chili Peppers .
At the same time , What is This ?
had also gotten a record deal .
 Since Slovak considered the Chili Peppers to merely be a side project and not a serious commitment , he left This to concentrate on What is This ?
 Flea ultimately respected the decision , but felt the band would suffer musically without This .
 He and audience member Anthony Kiedis hired drummer Cliff Martinez and guitarist Jack Sherman to fill former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons and Slovaks places , respectively .
 During the recording of the second What is This ?
album , Slovak became frustrated with the band and contacted Flea about rejoining the Red Hot Chili Peppers .
 This came at an opportune time , as the group was dissatisfied with Slovaks replacement , Jack Sherman .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis felt that Shermans guitar work didnt have the same spirit that Slovak contributed to the bands sound .
 When Flea asked Kiedis how audience member Anthony Kiedis felt about Slovak rejoining the band , audience member Anthony Kiedis responded by saying Id give I firstborn son to get him back in the band .
 After the culmination of the promotional tour for This first album , guitarist Jack Sherman was fired and Slovak rejoined the band .
 Slovak returned to the Chili Peppers for This second album , Freaky Styley , which was released on August 16 , 1985 .
What is This ?
 had finally disbanded , and former Anthym-drummer Jack Irons returned to the Chili Peppers in mid 1986 after Cliff Martinez was fired .
 Flea , Slovak and audience member Anthony Kiedis especially were involved in heavy drug use and This relationships became strained .
 Flea recalled that it began to seem ugly to I and not fun ; our communication was not healthy .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis became dependent on heroin , leaving the rest of the group to work on much of the albums material by themselves .
 The band lived in Detroit for a portion of the recording of the album , where audience member Anthony Kiedis and Slovak indulged in heavy cocaine use .
 When Slovak was under the influence , audience member Anthony Kiedis would often wear brightly colored clothing and dance in a shuffling fashion , which became the inspiration for the song Skinny Sweaty Man from the bands next album .
 After audience member Anthony Kiedis completed a stint in rehab , audience member Anthony Kiedis rejoined the Red Hot Chili Peppers in Los Angeles to record their third album The Uplift Mofo Party Plan .
 Slovak felt a deep connection to the album ; audience member Anthony Kiedis reflected in audience member Anthony Kiedis diary It was so fun .
 Im so extremely proud of everybodys work - Im so extremely proud of everybodys is at times genius .
 Slovak was the subject of the songs Skinny Sweaty Man , I and I Friends , & No Chump Love Sucker .
 the song Skinny Sweaty Man was nicknamed Slim Bob Billy , Slim , or Huckleberry , and throughout the albums audience member Anthony Kiedis calls audience member Anthony Kiedis by these nicknames before audience member Anthony Kiedis starts a guitar solo .
On The Uplift Mofo Party Plan , Slovak experimented with different musical styles , playing the sitar on the song Behind the Sun .
 Slovak and audience member Anthony Kiedis became addicted to heroin early in Slim Bob Billy , Slim , or Huckleberry careers , and Slovak often attempted to conceal his brother James Slovak addiction from his brother James Slovak friends and family .
 The band generally was more worried about Kiediss addiction , which was much more open and noticeable to the other members , while Slovak was much more subtle and much more cunning in Kiediss disguise .
During the tour in support of Freaky Styley , Slovaks health began to deteriorate .
 Slovak and Flea would wrestle regularly on tour , but Slovak became too weak to participate .
 audience member Anthony Kiedis commented on the situation : I could tell that Hillel who first got me into hard rockin had no inner core of strength ; audience member Anthony Kiedis had been robbed by audience member Anthony Kiedis addiction of the life force that allows you to at least defend yourself .
It was a sad moment .
 A roadie of the band who was concerned for Slovaks health contacted his brother , his brother James Slovak , who had been unaware that Slovak had ever used heroin .
 Deciding to give sobriety a chance , both audience member Anthony Kiedis and Slovak stopped using drugs prior to both Kiedis and Slovak European tour in support of The Uplift Mofo Party Plan , and decided to help each other steer clear of heroin .
 An entry from Slovaks diary on January 21 , 1988 discusses audience member Anthony Kiedis attempts to begin a new drug-free phase of life .
 During the tour both experienced intense heroin withdrawal , with Slovak much more unstable than audience member Anthony Kiedis .
 Slovak much more unstable withdrawal symptoms took a toll on Slovak much more unstable ability to play Slovak much more unstable instrument ; at one point Slovak had a mental breakdown and was unable to play a show , leaving the rest of the band to play an entire set with no guitar .
