 Sumati Mutatkar died on February 28 , 2007 , at a private hospital in Kolkata , after a brief bronchial illness at the age of 91 ; Sumati Mutatkar was survived by Sumati Mutatkar daughter
Alka Yagnik is amongst the best-known playback singers of Hindi cinema with a career spanning three decades .
 Alka Yagnik is a record seven-time winner from a record of 35 nominations of the Filmfare Award for Best Female Playback Singer , a two-time recipient of the National Film Award as well as several other music awards listed below .
 Alka Yagnik was the only leading playback singer during 90s to mid 2000s .
 Further , as many as 20 of Alka Yagnik tracks feature in BBCs Top 40 Bollywood Soundtracks of all time review .
Alka Yagnik was born in Kolkata on 20 March 1966 .
 Alka Yagnik mother Shubha Yagnik was a singer of Indian classical music .
 Her mother Shubha Yagnik received Her mother Shubha Yagnik school education from Modern High School for Girls .
 In 1972 at the age of 6 , Her mother Shubha Yagnik started singing for Akashvani , Calcutta .
 At age 10 , Her mother Shubha Yagnik mother brought her to Mumbai as a child singer .
She was advised to wait until her voice matured , but her mother remained determined .
 On a subsequent visit , Hamari Bahu Alka got a letter of introduction to Raj Kapoor from his Kolkata on 20 distributor .
 Raj Kapoor from his Kolkata distributor heard the girl and sent her with a letter to noted music director Laxmikant .
 Impressed , Laxmikant gave Laxmikant two alternatives - an immediate start as a dubbing artist or a later break as a singer ; they settled for the latter .
Alka Yagnik is classically trained .
 Alka Yagnik began singing bhajans for Akashvani , Calcutta .
at the age of six .
 Alka Yagnik first song was for the film Payal Ki Jhankaar in , followed by Laawaris with the song Mere Angane Mein , followed by the film Hamari Bahu Alka .
 Alka Yagnik got Alka Yagnik big break with the song Ek Do Teen from the film Tezaab .
 The song won Alka Yagnik a Filmfare Best Female Playback Award .
 Alka Yagnik has sung in many languages other than Urdu-Hindi , including Gujarati , Avadhi , Oriya , Assamese , Manipuri , Nepali , Rajasthani , Bengali , Bhojpuri , Punjabi , Marathi , Telugu , Tamil , English and Malayalam .
 Alka Yagnik has worked with Indian composers such as Kalyanji-Anandji , Rahul Dev Burman , Laxmikant , Rajesh Roshan , Nadeem-Shravan , Jatin Lalit , Anu Malik , A. R. Rahman , Anand-Milind , Himesh Reshammiya , Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy , Ismail Darbar , Aadesh Shrivastava , Viju Shah , M. M. Keeravani , Sajid-Wajid , Bappi Lahiri , Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan , Sandesh Shandilya and many others .
 In a career spanning three decades Alka Yagnik has sung many duet songs , most of these have been with Udit Narayan and Kumar Sanu .
 Alka Yagnik has also sung many duets with Abhijeet Bhattacharya , Sonu Nigam , Vinod Rathod & Shaan .
 Alka Yagnik has also sung in many albums such as Tum Yaad Aaye , as well as Tum Aaye and Shairana in which Alka Yagnik worked in close collaboration with award-winning lyricist Javed Akhtar and singer Hariharan .
 Alka Yagnik has also rendered the Hanuman Chalisa and various devotional songs .
 Hamari Bahu Alka shares the title with Asha Bhosle for the greatest number of Filmfare Awards won by a single female playback singer .
 Hamari Bahu Alka has also been the judge of various Sa Re Ga Ma Pa Challenge shows , and Star Voice of India , both singing competition shows , in which children or adults of various age groups compete with one another to win the award for best vocals .
 In addition to this , Hamari Bahu Alka song Chamma Chamma from China Town Gate was featured in the song Hindi Sad Diamonds from the soundtrack of the film Moulin Rouge !

She has also been performing in live concerts around the world .
In 2012 she along with Sonu Nigam sang a song Shiksha Ka Suraj as part of National Literacy Mission of India for which she was felicitated by Union Minister For Human Resource Development Kapil Sibal .
Further in 2012 , on occasion of 100 years of Hindi Cinema , her song Taal Se Taal Mila from the movie Taal was voted as the best song of the century in a poll conducted by DesiMartini , Hindustan Times and Fever 104 .
Also her song Choli Ke Peeche from the movie Khalnayak was voted as the hottest song of the century in a poll conducted by Sanona .
She has also been involved in various projects pertaining to empowerment of the girl child .
 Composers Laxmikant-Pyarelal have created several musical songs with her in movies such as the film Tezaab , Hum , the movie Khalnayak , Khuda Gawah , Agneepath and many others .
 Alka Yagniks collaboration with Nadeem-Shravan in movies such as Saajan , Phool Aur Kaante , Deewana , Hum Hain Rahi Pyar Ke , Dilwale , Raja Hindustani , Barsaat , Jeet , Raja Hindustani , Pardes , Sirf Tum , Dhadkan , Kasoor , Raaz , Andaaz , Dil Hai Tumhaara , etc. has created several songs over the years .
 Hamari Bahu Alka has been Dil Hai Tumhaara lead female singer throughout Dil Hai Tumhaara career .
Alka Yagnik has often collaborated with Jatin Lalit in movies such as Khiladi , Ghulam , , Sarfarosh , Yes Boss , Kuch Kuch Hota Hai , Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham ... , Phir Bhi Dil Hai Hindustani , Chalte Chalte , Hum Tum .
Alkas collaborations with Anu Malik over the years in films include Baazigar , Phir Teri Kahani Yaad Aayee , Imtihaan , Refugee , Vijaypath , Main Khiladi Tu Anari , Akele Hum Akele Tum , Duplicate , Soldier , Aarzoo , Har Dil Jo Pyar Karega , Asoka , Umrao Jaan , Fiza , Josh , Ishq Vishk , LOC Kargil .
 Hamari Bahu Alka collaborations with A. R. Rahman in movies such as the movie Taal , Lagaan , Zubeidaa , The Legend of Bhagat Singh , Swades , Yuvvraaj , Ada ... A Way of Life , Slumdog Millionaire .
Alkas work with Rajesh Roshan in films such as Karan Arjun , Sabse Bada Khiladi , Koyla , Kaho Naa ... Pyaar Hai , Koi ... Mil Gaya , Aap Mujhe Achche Lagne Lage , Krrish .
 Hamari Bahu Alka has worked in several films with Anand-Milind notably Qayamat Se Qayamat Tak , Anjaam , Suhaag , Coolie No. 1 , Loafer , Umrao Jaan , Hero No. 1 , Mrityudand & Jaanwar .
 Hamari Bahu Alka gave Himesh Reshammiya Himesh Reshammiya first break in the movie Pyaar Kiya To Darna Kya .
Thereafter the duo has worked together creating popular scores in several movies such as Hello Brother , Kahin Pyaar Na Ho Jaaye , Humraaz , Chura Liyaa Hai Tumne , Tere Naam , Bardaasht , Aitraaz , Maine Pyaar Kyun Kiya , Kyon Ki , Banaras , 36 China Town , Milenge Milenge , etc. .
Alkas collaboration with Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy in films such as Dil Chahta Hai , Mission Kashmir , Armaan , Kal Ho Naa Ho , Lakshya & Kabhi Alvida Naa Kehna .
Alka Yagnik has won several prestigious music awards for best female playback such as Filmfare Awards , National Awards , Bollywood Movie Awards , IIFA Awards , Star Screen Awards , Zee Cine Awards , etc. .
 Alka Yagnik also holds the record for most awards won as well as maximum nominations for Filmfare Award for Best Female Playback Singer .
 Further in 2012 , on occasion of 100 years of Hindi Cinema , Alka Yagnik song Taal Se Taal Mila from the movie Taal was voted as the best song of the century in a poll conducted by DesiMartini , Hindustan Times and Fever 104 .
 Also Alka Yagnik song Choli Ke Peeche from the movie Khalnayak was voted as the hottest song of the century in a poll conducted by Sanona
Padmabhushan Pandit Buddhadev Das Gupta is an Indian classical musician who plays the sarod .
Pandit Buddhadev Das Gupta resides in Kolkata , India .
 Padmabhushan Pandit Buddhadev Das Gupta is one of the artists featured in Nimbus Records s The Raga Guide .
 Buddhadev Das Gupta was born in 1 February 1933 in Padmabhushan Pandit Buddhadev Das Gupta maternal home at Bhagalpur , India to parents Prafulla Mohan Dasgupta and Bhabani Dasgupta .
 Padmabhushan Pandit Buddhadev Das Gupta father was District Magistrate by profession and an avid lover of music although District Magistrate by profession never learnt music .
 Since childhood little Buddhadev grew up with a musical atmosphere at little Buddhadev home .
 At a very early age little Buddhadev started taking Sarod lessons from the eminent Sarod maestro Sangitachrya sri Radhika Mohan Maitra .
 little Buddhadev first program in the All India Radio was as a guest artist .
 little Buddhadev has done more than 17 national programs in All India Radio , which is a very rare incident among known Indian Classiscal Musicians .
 Besides little Buddhadev world-wide fame as a Sarod maestro , Pandit Buddhadev Dasgupta has had an equally brilliant track record in Academics .
 little Buddhadev stood 2nd in the Matriculation Examination , held in 1948 .
 little Buddhadev studied Mechanical Engineering at the prestigious Bengal Engineering College , Shibpur , which was then affiliated to the University of Calcutta and stood 2nd .
 little Buddhadev received the honorary D.Litt degree from the Bengal Engineering and Science University , Shibpur at the honorary D.Litt degree annual convocation on 16 February 2010 .
 In 2011 , Sarod maestro Buddhadeb Dasgupta , was offered the Padma Shree by the government of India , but a Sarod maestro turned it down saying it was far too late in the day .
 In Jan 2012 , a Sarod maestro has been conferred with Padma Bhushan by Govt .
of India .
 a Sarod maestro famous autobiography Bamaner Chandrasparshavilash , was periodically published in a Bengali Magazine Disha and has been published in the form of book in 2004 and in 2010 .
The book became instant hit and is a best-seller among Bengali autobiographies
In Hindustani music , a pakad is a generally-accepted musical phrase thought to encapsulate the essence of a particular raga .
The pakad contains the melodic theme of the raga , on listening to the pakad a person who knows the raga is usually able to identify it .
In many cases , the ragas contain the same swaras , then the pakad also contains information about gayaki or chalan .
Usually , the pakad is formed from short convolutions of the arohana and avarohana , while in some cases it is quite different from them .
 The pakad for a particular raga need not be unique , The pakad for a particular raga sole purpose is to clarify what raga The pakad for a particular raga is .
For example , here is a pakad for raga Yaman , a prominent raga from Hindustani Music :
 While the sitar had earlier been used in jazz and Indian film music , a classical Indian stringed instrument was from the 1960s onwards that various pop artists in the Western world began to experiment with incorporating the sitar , a classical Indian stringed instrument , within various pop artists in the Western world compositions .
 The first known use of the sitar in a rock music recording session was made by the Yardbirds when various pop artists in the Western world hired a sitar player to play the main riff for various pop artists in the Western world single Heart Full of Soul .
However , the version with the sitar riff was not released at the time and George Harrison is now recognised as having introduced the instrument to pop music .
During a break in the filming of The Beatles second movie , Help !
 , George Harrison picked up a sitar left on the set as a prop and attempted to play it .
 George Harrison initial interest eventually led to George Harrison taking lessons from Pandit Ravi Shankar and Shambhu Das .
 George Harrison subsequently played the instrument on the Beatles song Norwegian Wood on the LP Rubber Soul in 1965 , which became the first released Western pop song to feature the sitar .
George Harrison went on to play the tamboura , a long-necked plucked lute , on both Revolver and Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band , as well as laying down sitar tracks for both albums on the songs Love You To , Tomorrow Never Knows , and Within You Without You .
A later Beatles song , Across the Universe , also featured the sitar .
 Additionally , George Harrison made great use of the sitar on George Harrison first solo album , 1968s Wonderwall Music .
 In early 1966 , Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones played the sitar on Paint It , Black , having taught Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones to play after visiting Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones friend George Harrison .
 Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones also played sitar on some tracks of Between the Buttons and 1968s Wonderwall Music Satanic Majesties Request .
 In early October 1967 , Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones again played sitar on My Little One in a recording session with Jimi Hendrix as well as the tambura on Street Fighting Man .
A fad for sitars in pop songs soon developed , facilitated by the Danelectro Companys 1967 introduction of the first electric sitar , known as the Coral Electric Sitar .
This instrument was an electric guitar with a distinctive sitar-like sound , rather than an acoustic sitar of the type traditionally made in India .
Despite producing similar sounds , the two instruments are completely different .
As the electric sitar was much easier to play than the traditional version it quickly became the preferred choice of most rock musicians .
The Coral instrument was an inexpensive item for its time and production only continued for a few years , making them relatively rare and expensive instruments today .
 The late 1960s saw the release of songs featuring the sitar that included The Monkees This Just Doesnt Seem To Be My Day , Ricky Nelson s Marshmallow Skies , Scott McKenzie s San Francisco , The Cyrkle s Turn-Down Day , The Cowsills The Rain , the Park , and Other Things , John Fred and John Fred Playboy Bands Judy in Disguise , The Turtles Sound Asleep , The Chocolate Watch Band s In the Past , The Box Tops Cry Like a Baby , The Lemon Pipers Green Tambourine , Traffic s Paper Sun and Hole In My Shoe Tomorrow Real Life Permanent Dream , July The Way and The Kinks Fancy .
Elvis Presley had several recordings that prominently featured the electric sitar .
 These included a 1967 cover of Tommy Tucker s R&B ; classic Hi-Heel Hi-Heel Sneakers , Mort Shuman s Youll Think Of My , , Percy Mayfield s Stranger In My Own Home Town and a cover of the Anne Murray country classic , Snowbird .
 In the instances of Hi-Heel Sneakers and Snowbird , Nashville , Tennessee session musician Harold Bradley played the electric sitar .
 For Youll Think Of My and Stranger In My Own Home Town In My Own Home Town , highly regarded Memphis , Tennessee and Nashville , Tennessee session musician Reggie Young played the electric sitar .
 The Mamas & The Papas used the sitar on various tracks such as People Like Us , Snowqueen Of Texas , Lady Genevieve , My Wan na Be a Star and Grasshopper , and Sergio Mendes & Brazil 66 used it on `` Chove Chuva '' .
Eric Burdon and the Animals played the instrument in the songs Winds of Change , No Self Pity , Orange and Red Beams , All Is One , We Love You Lil , and Monterey .
The Strawberry Alarm Clock use the sitar in songs such as An Angry Young Man , Black Butter-Present and Sit with the Guru .
Although often overlooked , some of the most extensive users of the instrument in contemporary music were Mike Heron and Robin Williamson of The Incredible String Band , combining folk , psychedelia with eastern influences in the songs The Song Has no ending parts 1-9 , The Mad Hatters Song and The Iron Stone .
Steve Miller Band used sitar in their popular song Wild Mountain Honey .
Art-Rock bands such as The Moody Blues used the sitar on a few albums and particularly on In Search of the Lost Chord while the The Pretty Things album S.F. Sorrow also featured the instrument on a few tracks , as did Procol Harum s epic song In Held Twas In I on the segment Glimpses of Nirvana .
Jethro Tull used the sitar on Fat Man and Skating Away on the Thin Ice of the New Day .
 The Strawbs used The Strawbs on many recordings while Genesis used the electric sitar on Fat Man and Skating song My Know What My Like from Fat Man and Skating fifth album Selling England by the Pound .
 Steve Howe of Yes used an electric sitar on the bands album Close to the Edge , and the band Family used the instrument in the song Face In The Cloud , recorded on Fat Man and Skating 1969 album Family Entertainment .
Donovan s hit song Hurdy Gurdy Man used a tamboura , which can also be heard on songs such as Sunny South Kensington , Breezes of Patchouli , Celeste , Guinevere , Three King Fishers , Ferris Wheel , and Fat Angel .
 Richie Havens made extensive use of the sitar in the title song of Richie Havens second album , Something Else Again .
Blue Cheer used both sitar and tabla in their song , Babji .
Although the sitar craze had died down by 1970 , its distinctive sound had become an indelible part of pop music .
 Tom Petty and Mike Campbell used a guitar fitted with a harpsichord-device to simulate a sitar for Tom Petty and Mike Campbell hit Dont Come Around Here No More while John Renbourn used the instrument prominently during John Renbourn time with the folk band Pentangle , on songs such as Once My Had a Sweetheart , House Carpenter , Cruel Sister , Rain And Snow and The Snows .
Roy Wood from The Move played sitar on Night of Fear using the same riffs as Tchaikovsky s 1812 Overture , as well as the electric sitar on Open up said the world at the door .
 Moreover , the Dutch band Shocking Blue used the sitar in many of The songs , most prominently in Love Buzz , Acka Raga , Water Boy , Hot Sand , and Im A Woman .
 In 1987 George Harrison returned to the sitar in George Harrison nostalgic Beatles tribute , When We Was Fab for the album Cloud Nine
Ashwin Kumar Batish Hindi : ashvin kumaar baatish is a sitar and tabla player best known for rekindling interest in the sitar among young Indians .
 A child prodigy , young Ashwin would often sing with young Ashwin sister Meena Batish at performances organized by young Ashwin father , the composer , author , Bollywood playback singer and music director , Pandit Shiv Dayal Batish .
 young Ashwin mother , Shrimati Shanta Devi Batish , was an All India Radio artist and is credited for starting young Ashwin on the dholak drum around the age of seven and on the sitar around the age of 12 .
 When Ashwins father took Ashwins to see Ashwins friend Ashok , the son of the great music director and harmonium wizard Pandit Bhagatram , Ashwin fell in love with the sitar .
 Ashok was only 2 years older than young Ashwin and seeing Ashok friend perform made young Ashwin think that young Ashwin could too .
 In 1964 , Ashwins father left India to visit one of his daughters in England .
 young Ashwin turned to young Ashwin mother and shared with Shrimati Shanta Devi Batish young Ashwin secret wish to play the sitar .
 Shrimati Shanta Devi Batish bought young Ashwin a student model sitar and started teaching young Ashwin Shrimati Shanta Devi Batish , as Shrimati Shanta Devi Batish had played the sitar when young .
 young Ashwin mother had also presented young Ashwin with some sitar albums by Ravi Shankar .
 young Ashwin would listen and copy all the songs to the best of young Ashwin abilities .
 At the same time , young Ashwin was also a great fan of the Beatles , Cliff Richards , Pat Boone and other pop singers of the 50s era .
 young Ashwin wasted no time in whipping out the songs young Ashwin heard from these Western artists .
 It was when young Ashwin joined young Ashwin father in England at around age 14 that young Ashwin started receiving training from young Ashwin on the intricacies of North Indian classical music .
 young Ashwin also started learning compositions in various ragas .
 young Ashwin father would often sing and have young Ashwin copy the musical phrases .
 He also taught young Ashwin many songs based in various ragas he had studied with his Guruji Shri Chandan Ram Charan .
 By age 16 , young Ashwin had started to accompany young Ashwin father on various programs .
 young Ashwin also started getting calls to play for college nights for which a local tabla player would accompany him .
 One such memorable event was when young Ashwin performed for an OXFAM benefit in England .
 Soloing in front of a live audience , without young Ashwin father by young Ashwin side , made young Ashwin realize how much more young Ashwin needed to learn , and young Ashwin became an earnest disciple of his father .
 young Ashwin was put on a rigorous practice schedule .
 The cold English weather meant that there was only one warm room in the house where all young Ashwin family would gather .
 To Ashwins advantage and delight , Ashwins father would always give Ashwins playing the preference to the dismay of Ashwins brothers and sisters .
 While Ashwins siblings strained to enjoy the British movies and serials on the TV , young Ashwin started to show improvement in Ashwins playing .
 On one such day , young Ashwin was practicing .
 When young Ashwin stopped playing , there was silence in the room .
 All young Ashwin family members were looking at young Ashwin and young Ashwin saw young Ashwin siblings nodding and showing appreciation at what young Ashwin had just played .
 young Ashwin learnt from this experience and started to tune into this new sense of expressive musical attraction .
 young Ashwin fine-tuned this ability in young Ashwin live performances .
 At 20 , young Ashwin found young Ashwin working full-time for a group of Chartered Accountants as an apprentice popularly known as an articled clerk .
 When young Ashwin turned up at the job in long hair and jeans , young Ashwin was promptly pulled aside by young Ashwin employers and given a lecture on attire .
 While Ashwin ignored these admonishments from young Ashwin bosses and fellow clerks , despite threats of being given menial tasks if young Ashwin did not comply , young Ashwin was finding that being part of the workforce was in complete contrast to young Ashwin lifestyle as a performer .
 young Ashwin is presently teaching Indian music at young Ashwin music school in Santa Cruz , California .
 young Ashwin was one of the pioneers on the World Wide Web credited with some of the very first Indian music-related websites which young Ashwin ran on the Gopher platform via the early University of California , Santa Cruz system .
 young Ashwin also publishes an online magazine that is mostly educational in nature called RagaNet .
 It provides regular lessons on sitar , tabla , Dilruba , History of India music , etc. .
 Articles on musical instruments of India are also a regular feature .
 Although young Ashwin training has been in North Indian classical music , Ashwin Batish has been equally at home with Western music often performing with jazz and rock musicians .
 young Ashwin 80s fling with fusion music young Ashwin self-titled Sitar Power was instrumental in garnering young Ashwin serious airplay including a recording contract with Shanachie Records of New Jersey .
 young Ashwin did not last long at Shanachie Records of New Jersey due to disappointing sales reports and lack of support .
 young Ashwin soon formed young Ashwin own record label , Batish Records to publish all young Ashwin familys works .
 young Ashwin continues to be active in the field of Indian music and is currently teaching at the Batish Institute of Indian Music and Fine Arts in Santa Cruz , California , USA .
 young Ashwin fathers death in the year 2006 dealt a severe blow to Ashwins energies and after a long period of inactivity young Ashwin has found a new direction .
 In remembrance and as a dedication to young Ashwin fathers memory and contribution to the music world , young Ashwin has embarked upon a very special venture into broadcasting .
This has given a voice to over 50 years of archived audio and video content .
 Radio Ragmala Radio and Television streams young Ashwin related audio and video content 24/7 providing a glimpse into the rich musical heritage of the young Ashwin family .
 It is also intended to be highly educational in nature thus fulfilling the intent of Ashwins father to help spread this wealth of musical knowledge to the rest of the world .
 young Ashwin has been actively spreading young Ashwin brand of classical and fusion music by creating portals on social networks such as Myspace and Facebook .
Ustad Kirit Khan was a talented Sitar player of the Indian subcontinent .
 Ustad Kirit Khan was born on October 29 , 1955 in Comilla , Bangladesh and later settled in Kolkata , India .
 Ustad Kirit Khan comes of an internationally renowned illustrious family of musicians of Bangladesh , which produced a galaxy of famous classical musicians like , Ustad Dr. Alauddin Khan , the world reputed Maestro of Seni-Maihar and Alauddin Gharana of Hindustani Classical Music , Ustad Ayet Ali Khan , Ustad Dr. Ali Akbar Khan , Pandit Ravi Shankar , Ustad Bahadur Khan , Ustad Khadem Hossain Khan , Ustad Abed Hossain Khan , Ustad Mir Kashem Khan , Ustad Phuljhuri Khan , Ustad Khurshid Khan , Ustad Shahadat Hossain Khan , Annapurna Devi , Reenat Fauzia and many others .
 Ustad Kirit Khan is the second son of Ustad Bahadur Khan , a reputed Sarod artiste and the younger brother of talented Sarod player Bidyut Khan , who was still actively propagating the musical culture of the family until his recent illness .
Kirit Khan died prematurely in 2006 due to kidney failure .
 At the age of seven , Ustad Kirit Khan started learning music .
 First Ustad Kirit Khan took Ustad Kirit Khan lessons on Tabla and later on Sitar .
 Ustad Kirit Khan learnt Sitar from Ustad Kirit Khan father Ustad Bahadur Khan till Ustad Kirit Khan death in 1989 .
 Ustad Kirit Khan acquired sheer virtuosity in Ustad Kirit Khan fingers under the strict mentorship of Ustad Kirit Khan father .
 In 1976 Ustad Kirit Khan appeared in front of audience with a duet concert with Ustad Kirit Khan father and that was the start of Ustad Kirit Khan glorious career .
From then on he played Sitar at home and abroad consistently .
Among his memorable concerts is a duet performance with his father in the Sursringer Music Conference in Mumbai in 1986 .
In 1987 he was showered with appreciation for his solo Sitar recitals in Mumbai organized by Ustad Abdul Halim Zafar Khan Academy .
In the same year he participated in a duet concert with his father in Tansen Music Conference .
 In 1991 he was highly appreciated at the Surdas Music Conference in Kolkata .
 In 1999 he was highly acclaimed by audience at the Dover lane Music Conference in Kolkata .
He had toured different countries in the world performing with his Sitar since 1978 .
 The First countries he toured are Russia , and Cuba .
Then in 1988 he rendered his recitals in Germany , and England .
In 1999 he performed in Denmark , Switzerland , N. Ireland , and Scotland .
In 2003 he performed in South America , and Sweden .
He received several awards and appreciation for his contribution in music .
In 1984 he obtained the title Suramani from the ` Haridas Music Conference ' , and later Surjhankar in Mumbai .
 In 1985 he was given a reception in Brahmanbaria , Bangladesh , as the soil 's bright son , with a golden key as a token of their sincere appreciation .
Besides playing sitar he also engaged himself as a music director in different films .
He worked with his father as an assistant music director in Hindi Films ` Garam Hawa ' , ` Amabashya Ki Chand ' .
He also worked as assistant Music director in Bangla films ` Natun Pata ' , ` Jukti Takko Goppo ' , ` Je Jekhane Dariye ' .
He was the solo music director of the film Nilkanya .
 He started a documentary film called ` Gharana and Parampara ' which has been sponsored by Government of Kolkata , India .
The theme of the film was to make the younger generation aware of Parampara and concept of Gharana .
 Though a busy artiste he also engaged himself as a music teacher In Ustad Bahadur Khan Music Academy in Kolkata and thus played a role to spread Indian classical instrumental music .
He was a visiting teacher on sitar in Indian Music Academy in Frankfurt , Germany
Vincent McDermott is a classically trained American composer and ethnomusicologist .
 Vincent McDermott works show particular influence from the musics of Southeast Asia and Southeast Asia , particularly the gamelan music of Central Java .
 Vincent McDermott is among the second generation of American composers to create and promote new compositions for gamelan .
 Vincent McDermott received a B.F.A. in music composition from the University of Pennsylvania , an M.A. in music history from the University of California , Berkeley , and a Ph.D. in music history , theory , and composition from the University of Pennsylvania .
 Vincent McDermott composition instructors included Constant Vauclain , George Rochberg , Darius Milhaud , and Karlheinz Stockhausen .
 In 1980 , Vincent McDermott became friends with Lou Harrison , the godfather of American gamelan .
 It was Harrison who encouraged Vincent McDermott to start composing for gamelan .
 Vincent McDermott first encountered gamelan c. 1965 in Amsterdam .
 Vincent McDermott later studied Central Java gamelan in Indonesia at the Akademi Seni Karawitan Indonesia in Central Java .
 Vincent McDermott has studied or worked in Surakarta with Sumarsam and Rahayu Supanggah , and later , in the United States , with Pak Cokro and Midiyanto .
 In the 1970s Vincent McDermott made an intensive study of Hindustani classical music , studying with sitarist Ira Das Gupta , and with renowned tabla player Zakir Hussain .
Many of McDermotts works are written for standard Western ensembles .
 In 1969 Many of McDermotts works began to incorporate sounds and ideas from North Indian music .
 In 1980 Lou Harrison encouraged Vincent McDermott to begin composing for gamelan .
 Vincent McDermott has since composed a number of works for gamelan , and has presented gamelan workshops in several Asian nations , focusing primarily on encouraging new compositions for gamelan .
 Vincent McDermott has received several Fulbright grants and National Endowment for the Arts commissions .
 Vincent McDermott was a recipient of a Masters Award from the Oregon Arts Commission .
 McDermotts compositions have been performed in North America , Europe , and Southeast Asia .
 From the earliest period Vincent McDermott was drawn to cross-cultural works , multimedia , and theatrical music .
These interests continue to this day .
 Two of his operas , The King of Bali and Mata Hari , juxtapose gamelan and Western ensembles .
Both were written and performed in the U.S. with English texts in the 1990s , and in the new century have been translated into Indonesian and performed in Yogyakarta , Indonesia .
 Both musical styles have swayed in different directions .
 Both generation witnessed the onset of a wealth of new styles , and in Both early days Both tried Both hand at many of Bali and Mata Hari .
 By and by Both eschewed the poles of abstract atonality and indeterminacy that were much in favor in the 1960s and 1970s .
 Instead Both turned increasingly to modality , melody , and counterpoint , which styles have continued since .
 Both compositional goals are expressivity , depth , and spirituality , yet often with a light heart .
 In Southeast Asia , Both advises young composers to borrow what they can from western traditions , saying Southeast Asia will help them speak to international audiences .
 But Both insists the soul of their music as well as many of Southeast Asia techniques must come from their own soil .
 Vincent McDermott has taught at the Hampton Institute in Virginia and at the Wisconsin Conservatory of Music in Milwaukee , Wisconsin , where Vincent McDermott served for a time as dean and director .
 In 1977 Vincent McDermott began teaching at Lewis & Clark College in Oregon ; Vincent McDermott retired in December 1997 and is now a professor emeritus .
 While there Vincent McDermott began the colleges world music program and in 1980 founded its first gamelan , Venerable Showers of Beauty , which was purchased in Central Java with the help of Rahayu Supanggah and Nyonya Nora along with an American patron , Loraine Fenwick .
 Vincent McDermott directed the gamelan and later invited Central Java musicians to teach .
 Vincent McDermott also instituted classes in Indian and African music performance with Nisha Joshi and Obo Addy .
 Vincent McDermott has since helped to establish gamelan programs at the College of William and Mary and the University of Puget Sound .
 Among Vincent McDermott composition students at Lewis and Clark College were Greg Bowers , Erika Foin , Hoe Yeong KIm , Duncan Nielson , Myrna Schloss , and Sophia Serghi .
 Vincent McDermott has also written articles on various subjects for various music journals .
 Vincent McDermott presently divides Vincent McDermott time between Yogyakarta , Central Java and the United States .
 In Yogyakarta , Vincent McDermott directs an ensemble called Musica Teatrica Nova
Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang was an Afghan musician and best known exponent of hindustani classical music from Kabul Afghanistan .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang was the second oldest son of the renowned musician , Ustad Ghulam Hussain .
 Mohammad Hussain was born and raised in Kharabat , a city famous and conceivably notorious for Kharabat musicians .
 Ustad Ghulam Hussain was born in Kharabat , an area in the old city of Kabul as Mohammad Hussain , the second son of the Peshawar musician , Ustad Ghulam Hussain , from whom Ustad Ghulam Hussain learned the basics of music .
 Ustad Ghulam Hussain then studied Indian Classical Music in the Patiala School of Music in India .
 After 16 years of learning from Ustad Ashiq Ali Khan , Ustad Ashiq Ali Khan returned to Radio Kabul at the age of 25 .
 Soon afterward Ustad Ashiq Ali Khan was awarded the title of Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang by the government of Kabul Afghanistan .
Ustad Sarahang performed various genres of classical and semi-classical music , including khayal , thumri , tarana , and ghazal .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang earned the following titles and degrees from various music schools of India : .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang recorded roughly 500 raga performances and ghazals in India and at Radio Kabul .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang has sung mostly the Ghazals of Amir Khusraw and Abul Maani Bedil , the famous poets of Indian School of Poetry in Persian , as Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang was a famous Bedil Shenas .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang wrote two books about classical music , Qanun-e Tarab and Mussiqi-e Rag-ha .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang has also created or composed several ragas including Hazra and Minamalee .
At the age of 25 , Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang participated in a festival of music held at Kabuls famed Pamir Cinema .
Amongst the participants were Ustad Qasim and Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan .
 At this festival , Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang amazed the crowd with Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang talent and passion and was awarded the Gold Medal over the more famous Masters of music .
 Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang performance at this festival earned Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang the title of Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang and a few years later , the government of Kabul Afghanistan awarded Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang the title of In Kabul Afghanistan .
 Qanon e Tarab : Explaining the rules of eastern music .
Ustad Sarahang also wrote many articles in Pashtun Ghag newspaper .
 In India , Ustad Sarahang was an idol to be worshipped .
 During Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang last trip to Allahabad School of Music , in order to show respect for the great Ustad Sarahang , Indian female ` Ustads ' and students of the school lined up and bowed their heads furnishing the path to the stage with their hair so that Ustad Sarahang could walk over them .
 Ustad Sarahang once said that if Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang were to die in India , Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang was to be buried next to the tomb of Baydel Abdul-Qadir Bedil .
 Upon Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang last trip to India in 1982 , Ustad Sarahang fell gravely ill and was hospitalized and ordered not to sing and to keep Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang talking to a minimum .
 But Ustad Sarahang disregarded the orders of Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang doctors and continued Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang performance which earned Ustad Mohammad Hussain Sarahang yet another medal and with the Gold Medal the pride to the people of Kabul Afghanistan
Radhika Mohan Maitra was an Indian sarod player .
 Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra was considered an influential figure in 20th century sarod playing and received the title Sangeetacharya .
 Radhika Mohan Maitra was born 1917 in Calcutta to a prominent family of the erstwhile feudal aristocracy of East Bengal , and grew up in Rajshahi , where Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra family had vast estates .
 Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra grandfather Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra was a pakhawaj player and had in his employ , the renowned sarod player Mohammad Amir Khan , with whom Radhika Mohan studied for five to six years .
 According to Maitras private accounts given to his student Kalyan Mukherjea , this training initially adhered to a basic corpus of about 20 ragas for the first four years , but as the Ustad began to realize that his student Kalyan Mukherjea time was running out , his student Kalyan Mukherjea taught Radhika Mohan as many as three to four ragas in a day , in sessions lasting all day .
Radhubabu later studied dhrupad with the famous beenkar Dabir Khan and sitar with Enayat Khan .
 Maitras debut concert was in Calcutta , in the home of another aristocratic family , the Gangulys , who were also patrons of music .
Two of the Ganguly brothers , Shyam and Hirendra Kumar became renowned sarod and tabla players , respectively .
 This was followed by an appearance at the Allahabad Music Conference in 1937 , where Ganguly won the first prize in the instrumental music contest and was invited to perform alongside stalwarts such as Hafiz Ali Khan and Allauddin Khan .
 This was at this same conference that Ganguly gave a duet concert with Allauddin Khan at the latters invitation .
 Ganguly rose to great heights as a performer and from about 1940 until the mid-60s , no major musical event in India was complete without Ganguly participation .
 Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra was a prolific composer and perhaps the only keen student of sarod technique in Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra era .
 Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra not only archived hundreds of traditional compositions in voluminous ledgers that Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra maintained , but also devised a very efficient method of imparting sarod technique , repertoire and what Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra considered good musical taste , to Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra students .
 Radhubabu was considered a formidable authority on the theoretical aspects of raga music , which Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra took great pains to translate accurately into Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra own music and that of Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra students .
 After 1970 , Maitras technical form , which Maitras technical form was so renowned for , began to decline steeply , as Maitras technical form was struck by one personal tragedy after another .
 In 1976 , Maitras technical form announced Maitras technical form retirement from the concert stage and returned to perform only twice after , once in 1980 and then in 1981 .
 In October 1981 , Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra died of brain hemorrhage as a result of an accident in Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra south Calcutta home .
As a teacher , Radhika Mohan Maitra had very few equals .
Some of his students include sitarist Nikhil Banerjee , sarod players Buddhadev Dasgupta , Nemai Chand Dhar , Anil Roychowdhury , Samarendranath Sikdar , Kalyan Mukherjea , Narendranath Dhar , Joydeep Ghosh , sitarists Himadri Bhushan Bagchi , Sanjoy Bandopadhyay and Sugato Nag .
Of his students , Kalyan Mukherjea and Samarendra Sikdar are the closest to his personal sound and style .
Radhubabu was temperamentally and culturally unlike the professional musicians of his time .
 He belonged to the erstwhile patron class and had organized and financed many large-scale music conferences , and even when , after the partition of India in 1947 , he had to leave his ancestral lands in Rajshahi and come to Calcutta , was not able abandon his aristocratic temperament in favour of the professional mindset .
As a result , he was never a commercially successful musician .
 Radhika Mohan Maitra was also exceptionally well-educated for an Indian musician of Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra era .
 Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra had a masters degree in Philosophy , and trained as a lawyer .
 In fact , Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra took to law as Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra profession , and was a failure in this endeavour , before allowing music to become Raybahadur Lalita Mohan Maitra livelihood
Tansen Samaroh or Tansen Sangeet Samaroh is celebrated every year in the month of December in Behat village of Gwalior district , Madhya Pradesh .
It is a 4 day musical extravaganza .
Artist and music lovers from all over the world gather here to pay tribute to the Great Indian Musical Maestro Tansen .
The event is organized near the tomb of Tansen by the Academy of the department of culture , Government of Madhya Pradesh .
Artists from all over India are invited to deliver vocal and instrumental performances .
The prestigious National Tansen Samman is a musical award conferred to the exponents of Indian music .
National Tansen Samman has been conferred to noted vocalist duo of Rajan and Sajan Mishra .
Tansen Samaroh was organized jointly by Alauddin Khan Kala Evam Sangeet Academy and The Academy of the department of culture in Madhya Pradesh from 14-17 December 2012
The rudra veena is a large plucked string instrument used in Hindustani classical music , one of the major types of veena played in Indian classical music .
It has a long tubular body made of wood or bamboo with a length between 54 and 62 inches .
Two large-sized , round resonators , made of dried and hollowed gourds , are attached under the tube .
Twenty-four brass-fitted raised wooden frets are fixed on the tube with the help of wax .
There are 4 main strings and 3 chikari strings .
As Rudra is a name for the Hindu god Shiva , rudra vina literally means the veena dear to Shiva .
It is an ancient instrument rarely played today .
The rudra veena declined in popularity in part due to the introduction in the early 19th century of the surbahar , which allowed sitarists to more easily present the alap sections of slow dhrupad - style ragas .
In 20th century , Zia Mohiuddin Dagar modified and redesigned the rudra veena to use bigger gourds , a thicker tube , thicker steel playing strings and closed javari that .
This produced a soft and deep sound when plucked without the use of any plectrum .
The instrument was further modified as the shruti veena by Lalmani Misra to establish Bharats Shadja Gram and obtain the 22 shrutis
Rahul Sharma is an Indian classical musician of Hindustani classical music .
 Rahul Sharma plays santoor and is also a vocalist .
Rahul Sharma was born in Mumbai to the Dogra Brahman family of santoor player Shivkumar Sharma and Manorama , from a family steeped in the tradition of Kashmir .
 Rahul Sharma grandfather , Uma Dutt Sharma , was a master of the santoor .
 Shivkumar Sharma , Shivkumar Sharma , his father father , mastered the instrument by experimenting with various striking positions and tones .
 As Shivkumars status rose in the musical circles of Jammu & Kashmir , word of Shivkumar Sharma , his father performances grew over borders and continents .
Rahul Sharma continued the tradition of the instrument .
 Rahul Sharma was always in love with music , singing and playing the harmonium at an early age .
 Learning the santoor at age 13 , Rahul Sharma wasnt completely sure of pursuing music until Rahul Sharma turned 17 .
 After studying economics at Mumbais Mithibai College , Rahul Sharma began performing with Rahul Sharma father .
 Rahul Sharma started accompanying Rahul Sharma in concerts in 1996 , at the age of 24 .
 The mountainous region of Jammu & Kashmir was where Rahuls musical lineage evolved and in September 2000 , Real World Records released Music Of The Himalayas , a live performance in Turin featuring Rahul Sharma , percussionist Pandit Bhawani Shankar , and tabla player Ustad Shafat Ahmed Khan .
 Rahul Sharma has performed in North America and throughout Europe , and at various folk and world music festivals , including WOMAD .
 Rahul Sharma quickly became a sought after concert artist , and has released several CDs , some solo and some with his father .
 Rahul Sharma has collaborated with international musicians like pianist Richard Clayderman and keyboardist Kersi Lord .
 The Confluence has mostly Indian titles , six of which were composed by Rahul Sharma Rahul Sharma .
 Rahul Sharma provided the music for the Hindi feature film Mujhse Dosti Karoge , for which Rahul Sharma received the award in the Best Debut-Music Director category at the 2002 Zee Bollywood Music Awards .
 Rahul Sharma last album Time Traveler which has been described as New-Age was released on March 10 , 2006 .
He collaborates with Ustad Zakir Hussain , Pt Bhavani Shankar Kathak , Shafat Ahmed Khan tabla .
In cooperation with the Aga Khan Trust for Culture , Smithsonian Folkways Recordings will release three volumes of its initially seven volumes ' Central Asian Music series on March 30 , 2010 .
 Vol .9 : In the Footsteps of Emperor Babur : Musical Encounters from the Lands of the Mughals explores the common ground of musical styles , sensibilities , and instruments from Central Asia , Afghanistan , and Northern India .
Six brilliant instrumentalists , amongst whom Rahul Sharma and Homayun Sakhi , the leading Afghan rubab player , illuminate the musical legacy of the Mughal Empire , founded five centuries ago by Emperor Babur .
 Rahul Sharma married Rahul Sharma sweetheart Barkha Patel who is from Mumbai , on 19 January 2008 , more information on Barkha Sharma : http://www.barkhansonzal.com/html/barkha-sharma.html
Vijay Kichlu is an Indian Classical singer .
 Vijay Kichlu studied Dhrupad with the Dagar Brothers and Khayal with Latafat Hussain Khan , whose style had a strong connection with Dhrupad .
 Vijay Kichlu and Vijay Kichlu brother , Ravi Kichlu , formed a famous classical vocalist duo .
 Vijay Kichlu was the founder and head of the ITC Music Academy for 25 years until Vijay Kichlu decided to retire due to change in management at the the ITC Music Academy headquarters
Sudhirkumar Saxena was a tabla artist and professor .
 Sudhirkumar Saxena learnt the tabla performing art for years from Ustad Habeebuddin Khan , the doyen of the Ajrada gharana .
Pandit Saxena was the first drummer in India to have worked as professor of tabla at a centre of higher learning .
 Pandit Saxena retired from Maharaja Sayajirao University , Baroda , in 1983 as head of Maharaja Sayajirao University music department , after serving the institution for thirty-three years .
 In Pandit Saxena younger days , Pandit Saxena participated in most of the major music conferences of the country as a tabla accompanist to many front-ranking musicians and dancers .
 Spending Pandit Saxena formative years in Meerut , Pandit Saxena also graduated in Political Science .
 He in Pandit Saxena era , played with most of the stalwarts of Indian Classical Music at that time .
 The speed of Pandit Saxena hands on the Baaya i.e. the bigger of the two drums in tabla - which is the bass drum ; was incredible .
 When Pandit Saxena went to Russia , people were so amazed by the sound Russia produced that they suspected a pigeon being hidden inside somewhere to produce that sound !

He was an extremely humble person and one of the best Gurus one could ever meet .
He never declined to teach anyone who came to him for help .
Right from teaching seasoned musicians , he taught even naive beginners - sometimes free of cost .
His book The Art of Tabla Rhythm - Essentials , Tradition & Creativity is one of the best books written on Tabla .
 As he used to say , one can never learn Tabla from a book and one always requires a Guru to learn , but this book serves the purpose of reaching out to the world with the lovely traditions of the Indian Classical Music .
He was the first guru of tabla player Divyang Vakil
 the Arohana , the Arohana or the Arohana , in the context of Indian classical music , is the ascending scale of notes in a raga .
The pitch increases as we go up from Shadja to the Taar Shadja , possibly in a crooked manner .
In Hindustani classical music , the ascending scales notes are S R G M P D and N. Lower forms of notes are written in lower case , like r g m d n , while the first scale given above is that of higher form of the notes .
The English notes C D E F G A and B correspond to S R G M P D and N , when C is taken as the tonal note .
In Carnatic music , the ascending scales notes for the variant notes R G M D and N have a subscript number indicating the specific variant .
 In Sankarabharanam ragam the Arohana is S R2 G3 M1 P D2 N3 S. See swaras in Carnatic music for explanation of notation .
In Abhogi ragam , which is a janya ragam of 22nd melakarta Kharaharapriya , the Arohana is S R2 G1 M1 D2 S .
In this ragam certain notes are excluded so the raga is totally changed
Syahi is the tuning paste applied to the head of many South Asian percussion instruments like the dholki , tabla , madal , mridangam , khol and pakhavaj .
 Syahi is usually black in colour , circular in shape and is made of a mixture of flour , water and iron filings .
Originally , syahi was a temporary application of flour and water .
Over time it has evolved into a permanent addition .
Syahi functions by loading only a portion of the stretched skin with weight .
In the higher-pitched drum this has the effect of altering the resonance frequency of some lower order vibrations more than others .
The action on the left hand drum is a little different .
 On other side , The action on the left hand drum position is offset and serves simply to lower the resonance frequency .
The application of the syahi is very involved .
 The application of the syahi starts with a base layer of mucilage , followed by the application of numerous thin layers of syahi masala , which are then rubbed with a stone .
Not all of the layers are the same size .
But the final product is expected to exhibit a specific shape .
The stone abrasion is crucial to creating the syahi .
The material from which the syahi is made is inherently inflexible ; if it were simply applied in a single layer and allowed to harden , it would not allow the drum to vibrate freely .
The process of rubbing or polishing with the stone creates a tight latticework of cracks which extend down to the very base of the syahi , allowing vibrations to travel across the whole object , despite the toughness of the syahis raw material .
The process from the application of the first layer of glue and the finesse in adding the subsequent layers of syahi is the main determinant in the resulting tonal purity of the instrument and also of the longevity of the layers .
Once the preliminary leatherskin Puri is fastened onto the face of the tabla , the craftsman applies the glue in a circle on the surface leaving a half-inch margin from the Chati .
When the glue is about to set , the syahi is applied in a 2-3 mm thick layer over the glue with small spikes in the syahi layer .
Once the syahi is semi-hardened and not yet dry , the rubbing with the stone begins .
The rubbing continues till it removes the spikes and a coarse surface results .
On this , layers are then added in reducing concentric circles , each half to one mm thick .
The essence lies in beginning the rubbing before the syahi completely hardens and continuing it till the surface is nearly dry when the new layer is added .
The rubbing and its proper technique ensures that the layers are each uniformly thick , tapering slightly at the edges to smoothly merge in the layer below .
The process of rubbing generates heat in the paste applied and achieves the function of drying the paste and also the frictional vibration of the surface with the stone results in a fine latticework of cracks leaving grains of syahi attached only to the base of the layer below .
 This structure gives the instrument This structure exceptional sonority and tonal quality among all percussion instruments and also the rich harmonics which range from This structure tuned pitch of a few hundred Hertz to a few KiloHertz .
 If the syahi is allowed to harden without rubbing Syahi continuously , pockets of solidity would be left in the layers and distort the tone and also result in breakage of the grains from the layers within a short span , resulting in a jarring rattling sound during playing .
The layers , as the leatherskin on which they are applied , are vulnerable to humidity in the weather and also the moisture in the players hand .
Interaction with moisture results in melting of the black crystals .
This is the reason why players frequently use powder to keep the hands dry while playing
Mian Ghulam Nabi Shori popularly known as Shori Mian was an Indian composer of Hindustani classical music .
He was a court singer of Asaf-Ud-Dowlah , Nawab of Awadh .
He composed tappa , one of the most difficult classical forms , in Punjab .
The brisk and ornate tappa form , romantic in nature , tappas text is always in Punjabi .
 It was supposed to be a song of the cameleers of Punjab and Rajasthan .
 Born in Punjab to Ghulam Rasool Khan .
 The common myth tells that Ghulam Rasool Khan was initially trained in Khayal singing and had a great command on singing Taan .
 Ghulam Rasool Khan was not satisfied with Khayal for expressing Ghulam Rasool Khan skill in singing singing Taan , Ghulam Rasool Khan restlessly traveled in Punjab , where Ghulam Rasool Khan listened to the folk songs of camel-riders , which Ghulam Rasool Khan thought to be suitable for Ghulam Rasool Khan own style of singing .
 Ghulam Rasool Khan composed Tappa using various ornamentations with singing Taan , Jamjama , Khatka , etc. .
 In the Tappas of Shori Miyan , in Antara we find the Tappas of Shori Miyan , in Antara name as Shori
Pannalal Ghosh , also known as Amal Jyoti Ghosh , was a Bengali Indian flute player and composer .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh was a disciple of Allauddin Khan , and is credited with giving the flute its status in Hindustani classical music .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh was born on 24 July 1911 in Barisal , East Bengal in British India .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh was named Amal Jyoti Ghosh with Pannalal having been Amal Jyoti Ghosh nickname .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh father , Akshay Kumar Ghosh , was a sitarist .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh received Amal Jyoti Ghosh initial training in music from Amal Jyoti Ghosh father , learning to play the sitar .
 Two apocryphal incidents in Amal Jyoti Ghosh childhood are believed to have influenced Amal Jyoti Ghosh in taking up the flute .
As a child he had picked up a small flute that cowherds usually played , and on the basis of the education he was receiving on the sitar from his father , he would try to play musical patterns on the flute .
The family 's ancestral house was on the banks of the Kirtankhola river .
 At the age of nine , while swimming in the river one day , Amal Jyoti Ghosh found a long bamboo stick that was half-flute and half walking stick .
 The flute part of the stick was longer than a traditional flute and Amal Jyoti Ghosh started practising on it .
 Then at the age of eleven , Amal Jyoti Ghosh is said to have met a holy man who held a conch and a flute and asked if Amal Jyoti Ghosh could play the flute .
 When Amal Jyoti Ghosh obliged , the man blessed Amal Jyoti Ghosh and said that music would be Amal Jyoti Ghosh salvation .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh was married to Parul Ghosh in 1924 when Parul Ghosh in 1924 was only nine and Amal Jyoti Ghosh was thirteen years old .
 Parul Ghosh in 1924 was the younger sister of Ghosh 's friend Anil Biswas who went on to become a celebrated music composer .
 Parul Ghosh in 1924 was a talented singer Parul Ghosh in 1924 and later became a well-known playback singer .
 In 1928 , Amal Jyoti Ghosh became a part of the Indian Independence Movement .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh joined a gymnasium and learnt martial arts , boxing and stick fighting .
 As Amal Jyoti Ghosh became more involved in the independence movement , the government started keeping a close watch .
 Consequently Amal Jyoti Ghosh shifted to Calcutta at the age of seventeen in search of a livelihood .
 At the age of eighteen , Amal Jyoti Ghosh started focusing Amal Jyoti Ghosh attention on the flute .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh realised that a bigger flutes pitch and sonority would be more appropriate for both classical and light music .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh experimented with various materials including metal and different types of wood , and decided on using bamboo .
 Amal Jyoti Ghosh finally settled on a flute which was thirty two inches long .
Pannalal Ghosh jointly scoring the background for `` Aandhiyan '' in 1952 along with Ustad Ali Akbar Khan and Pandit Ravi Shankar .
He was the first to introduce the seven hole flute .
Authentic list of Pt .
 Pannalal Ghosh 's noteworthy students at Calcutta contained Haripada Choudhary , Aminur Rehman , Fakirchanda Samanta , Sudhanshu Choudhury , Mukul Roy and Gaur Goswami .
The students at Bombay included Tribhuvan Gondkar , Rasbihari Desai , Devendra Murdeshwar , V.G. Karnad , Chandrakant Joshi , Mohan Nadkarni , Prabhakar Nachane , Niranjan Haldipur , Krishnarao D. Desai , Ramaprasad Mukherjee , Mahesh Mastfakir , Sharad Maholay , Bhailal Barot , Suraj Narain Purohit and Hari Chabria
In the context of Indian classical music , Swara is a Sanskrit word that means a note in the octave .
 The seven basic swaras of the scale are named shadja , rishabh , gandhar , madhyam , pancham , dhaivat and nishad , and are shortened to Sa , Ri or Re , Ga , shuddha Ma , Pa , Dha , and Ni and written S , R , G , M , P , D , N. Collectively these notes are known as the sargam .
Sargam is the Indian equivalent to solfege , a technique for the teaching of sight-singing .
The tone Sa is not associated with any particular pitch .
As in Western moveable-Do solfege , Sa refers to the tonic of a piece or scale rather than to any particular pitch .
In the general sense svara means tone , and applies to chanting and singing .
The basic swaras of Vedic chanting are udatta , anudatta and svarita .
The musical octave is said to have evolved from the elaborate and elongated chants of Sama Veda , based on these basic swaras .
Siksha is the subject that deals with phonetics and pronunciation .
 Naradiya Siksha elaborately discusses the nature of The basic swaras of Vedic chanting , both Vedic chants and the octave .
A dot above a letter indicates that the note is sung one octave higher , and a dot below indicates one octave lower .
Or , if a note with the same name - Sa , for example - is an octave higher than the note represented by S , an apostrophe is placed to the right : S .
If it is an octave lower , the apostrophe is placed to the left : S. Apostrophes can be added as necessary to indicate the octave : for example , `` g would be the note komal Ga in the octave two octaves below that which begins on the note S .
 The basic mode of reference is that The basic mode of reference is equivalent to the Western Ionian mode or major scale .
All relationships between pitches follow from this .
In any seven-tone mode , R , G , D , and N can be natural or flat but never sharp , and the M can be natural or sharp but never flat , making twelve notes as in the Western chromatic scale .
If a swara is not natural , a line below a letter indicates that it is flat and an acute accent above indicates that it is sharp .
 Sa and Pa are immovable , forming a just perfect fifth .
In some notation systems , the distinction is made with capital and lowercase letters .
When abbreviating these tones , the form of the note which is relatively lower in pitch always uses a lowercase letter , while the form which is higher in pitch uses an uppercase letter .
 So komal Re/Ri uses the letter r and shuddha Re/Ri , the letter R , but shuddha Ma uses m because So komal Re/Ri has a raised form - tivra shuddha Ma - which uses the letter M. Sa and Pa are always abbreviated as S and P , respectively , since S , R , G , M , P , D can not be altered .
The swaras in Carnatic music are slightly different in the twelve-note system .
 There are three types each of Chatushruti Rishabha , Shuddha Gandhara , Dhaivata and Nishada .
There are two types of Madhyama , while Panchama and Shadja are invariant .
As you can see above , Chatushruti Rishabha and Shuddha Gandhara share the same pitch .
Hence if C is chosen as Shadja , D would be both Chatushruti Rishabha and Shuddha Gandhara .
 Hence Shadja will not occur in same raga together .
Similarly for two swaras each at notes 4 , 10 and 11 .
Each shuddha swara is traditionally held to have originated in the sound of a different animal , and some have additional meanings of their own .
Also , each swara is associated with one of the seven chakras of the body .
Just as the swaras ascend through the saptak , so they are mapped onto the chakras in the body in ascending order .
Komal notes are associated with the left side of each chakra ; the left channel , Ida Nadi , is the side of emotion and intuition .
Shuddha and tivra notes are associated with the right side ; the right channel , Pingala Nadi , is the side of logic .
 Ragas , therefore , have more or less of an effect on a given chakra depending on the notes Shuddha and tivra contain .
In certain forms of Indian classical music and qawwali , when a rapid 16th note sequence of the same note is sung , different syllables may be used in a certain sequence to make the whole easier to pronounce .
For example , instead of sa-sa-sa-sa-sa-sa-sa-sa said very quickly , it might be sa-da-da-li-sa-da-da-li which lends itself more to a quick and light tongue movement .
In the context of Indian classical music some specific forms of swara-s fulfill the technique of playing a note .
Such ornamentations in Indian classical music is important for the proper rendition and essential to create the beauty of a raga .
Some notes are linked with their preceding or succeeding notes ; these linked notes are called grace notes or kan-swars .
Kan-swars deal with so called touch notes .
Kan-swars can be executed vocally and on instruments in three ways : .
Andolit swars are raga-specific notes that are oscillated within the Andolan alankar .
The specification of the Andolan alankar is the oscillation from a fixed note touching the periphery of an adjacent note .
By this oscillation the shrutis are touched which exist in between
Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa commonly referred as Mirashi Buwa was an Indian classical singer in khyal - genre of Hindustani classical music .
 Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa was a noted disciple of Balakrishnabuwa Ichalkaranjikar of Gwalior gharana , along with Vishnu Digambar Paluskar .
 Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa was known for Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa fast taans .
 Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa was also an actor and had performed in many of the Sangeet Nataks , Marathi theatre musicals .
 Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa was born in 1883 in Ichalkaranji in present Kolhapur district , Maharashtra .
 Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa worked with theatre company Natyakala Pravartak Mandali in Pune , from 1911 to 1932 , and also taught music to numerous disciples .
 In 1961 , Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award , given by the Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy of Music , Dance & Drama .
 Yashwant Sadashiva Buwa notable disciples include Vinayakbuva Utturkar and Yashawantbuva Joshi of Mumbai
Shaik Dawood Khan also known as Ustad Shaik Dawood & Sheik Dawood , was a performer on the Indian tabla .
 Ustad Shaik Dawood Khan was formerly a staff artist in All India Radio .
Ustad Shaik Dawood Khan was born in Sholapur .
 Ustad Shaik Dawood Khan father Hashim Sahib was a draughtsman in the PWD , Bijapur .
 Shaik Dawood received Shaik Dawood training under several notable masters .
 These include Mohammad Kasim of Sholapur , Ustad Alladiya Khan of Hyderabad , Ustad Mohammad Khan of Hyderabad , Ustad Chote Khan of Hyderabad , and Ustad Mahboob Khan of Miraj .
 In Mohammad Kasim of Sholapur lifetime Mohammad Kasim of Sholapur accompanied most of the great musicians of the era .
 These include Aftab-e-Mausiki Ustad Fayyaz Khan , Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan , Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan , Ustad Barakat Ali Khan , Roshanara Begum , Abdul Wahid Khan , Pandit Bhimsen Joshi , Pandit Sawai Gandharva , Pandit Basawaraj Raj Guru , Nazakat Salamat , Mushtaq Hussain Khan , Pandit D. V. Paluskar , Pandit Vinayak Rao Patwardhan , Ustad Allaudin Khan , Ustad Ali Akbar Khan Girija Devi , Pandit Ravi Shankar , Ustad Vilayat Khan .
 In Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan life Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan received numerous awards .
 These include the prestigious Sangeet Natak Akademi Award - 1991 .
Unfortunately he was too ill to attend the award ceremony and died shortly after the awards ceremony
Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is a Sitarist and a teacher .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is the winner of the Padmabhsushan and Padmashree awards .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is the writer of three books , composer of eight new raga 's and numerous musical compositions .
 From 1963 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri has appeared in numerous radio broadcasts , and Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is a disciple of Mushtaq Ali Khan .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is considered a leading Sitarist of Post War era .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is regarded as one of the leading proponents of Senia Style .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri is the former Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri and Head , Faculty of Music , University of Delhi .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri music is noted for Music sweet sinking ringing tone .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri currently stays with Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri son , daughter-in law and niece at Chittaranjan Park , New Delhi .
Pt .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri was born in 1935 in Mymensing .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri started playing the Sitar from four years of age .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri first broadcast was at the age of eighteen at the All India Radio in 1953 .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri received Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri education in the University of Calcutta .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri joined Delhi University as a reader from 1971 to 1982 and was the Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri and Head of Music Department from 1985 to 1988 .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri has served as a visiting professor at the MIU , Iowa from 1991 to 1994 .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri received Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri training in the Sitar under late Panchu Gopal Ratna and Ushtad Mustaq Ali Khan .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri started paying the Sitar from four years of age .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri first broadcast was at the age of twelve at the All India Radio in 1953 .
 Pandit Devabrata Chaudhuri created 8 new Ragas viz .
Bisweswari , Palas-Sarang , Anuranjani , Ashiqui Lalit , Swanandeswari , Kalyani Bilawal , Shivamanjari and Prabhati Manjari .
 Ashiqui Lalit has authored three book on Indian Music namely ` the Sitar and Its Techniques ' , ` Music of India ' and ` On Indian Music ' .
 Ashiqui Lalit has recorded 24 CD 's for 24 hours of the day in USA .
 Ashiqui Lalit is considered a leading proponent of playing the repeated articulation of the pedal tone with the tonic pitch of the second string string , by pulling the string across the fret that is allowed to die out before the basic alternation stroking is continued .
 Ashiqui Lalit is also unique I using the 17 fret sitar while most musicians use the 19 fret sitar .
 In April 2010 Ashiqui Lalit started the UMAK Center for culture in memory of Ashiqui Lalit '' guru '' Ustad Mushtaq Ali Khan
Saraswati Rane was an Indian classical singer in the Hindustani Classical genre .
 Saraswati Rane was a daughter of Ustad Abdul Karim Khan , the founder of Kirana Gharana .
 Saraswati Rane family had a long and great music tradition .
 Her family got Her family initial training of vocal music of the Kirana Gharana style from Her family elder brother Sureshbabu Mane and elder sister Hirabai Barodekar , who themselves were the doyen of Indian classical music of their times .
 Later Her family also sang along with elder sister , Hirabai Bododekar , especially in jugalbandi style .
 Born on October 4 , 1913 to Ustad Abdul Karim Khan , the founder of Kirana Gharana , and Tarabai Mane , as Sakina , Tarabai Mane grew up in a musical household .
 After separating from Tarabai Mane husband , Tarabai , Tarabai mother , renamed all Tarabai five children ; hence Sakina became Kumari Saraswati Mane .
 Tarabai Mane was initiated into music by Tarabai Mane brother Sureshbabu Mane , later after 1930 , Tarabai Mane also started learning from Tarabai Mane sister Hirabai Barodekar .
 To enhance Tarabai Mane musical knowledge Tarabai Mane also got taleem from ustads of different gharanas like the nephew of Alladiya Khan , Ustad Natthan Khan of Jaipur gharana , Prof. B. R. Deodhar and Pandit Master Krishnarao of Gwalior gharana .
 Kumari Saraswati started Kumari Saraswati musical career at a very early age of seven years with stage acting in musical dramas like Sangeet Saubhadra , Sangeet Sanshaykallol , Sangeet Ekach Pyala etc. .
 Right from a young age , i.e. , since 1929 , Kumari Saraswati started acting in major roles with great noted artists like Balgandharva and other in shows all over India .
 In 1933 , Kumari Saraswati started performing on Akashwani .
 Kumari Saraswati continued performing on All India Radio as a top grade artist until 1990 , when Kumari Saraswati declared Kumari Saraswati retirement from public performances .
 Kumari Saraswati is amongst the few classical vocalists to have participated in many Radio Sangeet Sabhas from Kanyakumari to Peshawar from the early 1940s to mid 1980s .
 Kumari Saraswati was amongst the first female artists to give playback for Hindi and Marathi films .
 Kumari Saraswati first playback was in Marathi film Payachi Dasi , directed by Acharya Atre .
 Kumari Saraswati remained in the field till 1954 .
 Kumari Saraswati song from the Hindi film Ramrajya .

 ` Bina Madhur Madhur Kachu Bol ' reached the peak of popularity all over India , and she was awarded by HMV for the highest sale of gramophone records in those times .
 She also gave playback for Hindi film , Sargam , and Bhumika , directed by noted director Shyam Benegal .
She had an opportunity to sing under the music direction of great music directors like C. Ramchandra , Shankarrao Vyas , K. C. Day , and Sudhir Phadke .
 Kumari Saraswati was invited to participate on the eve of first independence Day at Delhi .
 Kumari Saraswati was also invited to participate in a grand celebration at Shivneri on the first Maharashtra Din by the then chief minister Late Yashwantrao Chavan .
 In the same period Kumari Saraswati became a very popular singer of Marathi light classical songs , popularly known as Bhav-geet , and Kumari Saraswati records got overwhelming response from all over Maharashtra .
 Kumari Saraswati was among the few top artists of India who was invited in prestigious music conferences held in places like Mumbai , Kolkata , Delhi , Chennai , Baroda , Bhopal , Gwalior etc. .
 Kumari Saraswati often performed at the Pune Sawai Gandharva Music Festival .
 Kumari Saraswati and Kumari Saraswati elder sister , Hirabai Barodekar were the first to start the concept of jugalbandi vocal recital by ladies .
 Saraswatibai and her elder sister jugalbandi recital was appreciated all over the world and got an overwhelming response from 1965 to 1980 .
 Saraswatibai and her elder sister jugalbandi records and now cassettes are still in demand .
 Though Kumari Saraswati was busy in Kumari Saraswati own professional career , whenever Kumari Saraswati found free time , Kumari Saraswati carried on the work of teaching classical music to talented students some of whom are well-known artists in this field .
 Kumari Saraswati grand daughter Meena Faterpekar is one of the very few female classical vocalists from Kirana Gharana pursuing the same tradition .
 Her grand daughter Meena Faterpekar was married to Sunderrao Rane .
 Her grand daughter Meena Faterpekar died on 10 October 2006 .
Sarswatibai was awarded : 1 .
Balgandharva Purskar 2 .
Balgandharva Gold Medal 3 .
ITC Sangeet Research Academy Award 4 .
Yeshwantrao Chavan Puraskar 5 .
Guru Mahatmya Puraskar 6 .
Ustad Faiyaz Ahmed Khan Memorial Trust
Tana Mana is an album by Indian musician Ravi Shankar , originally credited to the Ravi Shankar Project and released in 1987 .
 The album is an experimental work by sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar , mixing traditional instrumentation with 1980s electronic music and sampling technology .
 sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar recorded much of Tana Mana in 1983 with sound effects innovator Frank Serafine , but much of Tana Mana in 1983 remained unreleased until Peter Baumann , head of new age record label Private Music , became attached to the project .
The album title translates to mean body and mind .
 In addition to sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar familiar instrument , the sitar , sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar plays synthesizer extensively on the recording .
The album also includes contributions from Lakshmi Shankar , Aashish Khan and Kumar Bose , and Western musicians such as George Harrison , Al Kooper and Ray Cooper .
 In sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar 1997 autobiography , Raga Mala , Ravi Shankar writes that Raga Mala started work on Tana Mana in 1983 at the home studio of Frank Serafine , a sound effects designer for Hollywood films such as Tron .
 The album began as an experiment by sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar with the innovative sampling technology that Serafine had assembled at his studio - Serafine FX in Venice , western Los Angeles .
 sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar recalls recording two or three pieces on synthesizer before having to depart for India .
 On sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar return to Los Angeles , sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar overdubbed contributions from regular accompanists such as sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar son Shubho and sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar , and from sarodya Aashish Khan and tabla player Swapan Chaudhuri .
Up to five new pieces were also recorded at this time , according to Shankars recollection .
 The experimental nature of the project impressed sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar circle of friends in California , sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar writes in Raga Mala , but confused record companies , who were unable to attribute the music to a recognised genre .
 The recordings were left sitting there waiting for someone to show more interest , sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar recalls , until the involvement of German composer Peter Baumann , who had formed a label specialising in experimental music , Private Music , in 1984 .
According to the credits listed in Shankars 1995 box set In Celebration , further recording for what became Tana Mana took place during 1986 .
One of the additional tracks was Friar Park , featuring Shankars friend and sometime collaborator George Harrison .
 Named after collaborator George Harrison estate in Oxfordshire , west of London , the song was based on Raga Charukeshi and features Shankar playing both standard and bass sitars .
 sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar and collaborator George Harrison taped the track at FPSHOT , collaborator George Harrison home studio , accompanied by Ray Cooper on marimba and Markandeya Mishra , a local tabla player .
 Another 1986 recording was West Eats Meat , Meat title suggested by Serafine as a pun on Shankars earlier cross-cultural projects , such as West Meets East , his trilogy of albums with classical violinist Yehudi Menuhin .
 sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar describes the session for West Eats Meat as the first time sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar ever played sitar with a jazz bassist - in this instance , Patrick OHearn .
 Produced by German composer Peter Baumann at The Enterprise in Burbank , California , the session included contributions from Lakshmi , sarodya Aashish Khan and former sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar student Harihar Rao , and tabla player Kumar Bose .
 Like tabla player Swapan Chaudhuri , tabla player Kumar Bose had become one of Shankars preferred accompanists on tabla , following the end of of the sitarists 33-year partnership with Alla Rakha in 1985 .
 Other Western musicians who contributed to the album include Al Kooper , on electric guitar , and Ric Parnell , playing electronic drums .
 In both his autobiography and the comments included with In Celebration , sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar refers to Tana Mana as having been an enjoyable album to make .
 The title track was one of my favourite numbers , he writes - a musical tribute to his mother , who died in 1936 while sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar was in Paris with sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar brother Uday s dance company .
 In his 1995 comments on Tana Mana , sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar writes : I lost I sweet mother at an early age , but I clearly remember her singing to I .
 I dedicate this song to her beautiful spirit .
The title translates to mean body and mind .
 Another track , Memory of sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar , is dedicated to Uday Shankar , who died in Calcutta in 1977 .
Private Music released Tana Mana in 1987 , with the album credited to the Ravi Shankar Project .
 sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar attributed its eventual release , four years after conception , to the advent of new-age music , a genre that German composer Peter Baumann record label did much to promote .
Inside the Kremlin and Passages , the latter a collaboration with American composer Philip Glass .
 Tana Mana , Friar Park and West Eats Meat later appeared on In Celebration , which collaborator George Harrison compiled to celebrate sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar 75th birthday .
Allmusic critic Adam Greenberg writes of Tana Mana : The reverberant quality of the sitar combines rather well with the chosen electronic accompaniments to form a set of coherent songs , unlike many other such attempted combinations of traditional instruments and technology .
 The sitar playing is , as usual , superb ... With an extra sarod thrown in , a small front line of synthesizers , and sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar friend George Harrison assisting on the autoharp , the pile of musicality that forms allows an unexpectedly coherent , clear , and relatively focused piece of music to emerge .
 In a 2010 article on sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar , music website Shakenstir described Tana Mana as having brought Mr. Shankar 's music into the New age with Mr. Shankar 's music unique method of combining traditional instruments with electronics .
 The article quoted a 2007 interview in which sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar defended sister-in-law Lakshmi Shankar association with Western artists such as classical violinist Yehudi Menuhin , collaborator George Harrison , American composer Philip Glass and John Coltrane against criticism from Indian classical music purists : Yes , I performed with Yehudi Menuhin , composed 2 concertos experimented with jazz , far eastern music , Phillip Glass , ballet , orchestration film music , music theatre and so much more - from 1945 ...
