It is a symmetric ragam that does not contain madhyamam or nishadam .
 It is an audava-audava ragam in Carnatic music classification .
 Its structure using swaras in Carnatic music notation is as follows .
 In this form , The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani is considered a janya ragam of Kharaharapriya , the 22nd Melakarta ragam , though it can be derived from 3 other melakarta ragams , Gourimanohari , Hemavati or Dharmavati , by dropping both madhyamam and nishadam .
 The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani ragam brings out karuna rasa and lends The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani for elaboration and exploration .
 The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani has many compositions in classical music and in film songs .
The popular Hindi film song Jaane kahan gaye woh din is based on this scale .
 The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani was a favourite of the legendary composers Shankar-Jaikishan , in addition to the aforementioned song from Mera Naam Joker they also used The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani for O basanti pavan paagal in Jis Desh Men Ganga Behti Hai and O mere sanam in Sangam Mere naina Saon Vhado .
Kannum Kannum from the movie Thiruda Thiruda is regarded as the most different song done in this raga .
 In Carnatic music , two ragamalikas start with a refrain in The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani .
M S Subbulakshmi made Kurai onrum illai very popular which begins with this scale .
 Kurai onrun illai literally means there is no defect or there is nothing left wanting , alluding to we are satisfied and thankful in prayer to Kannan .
Another composition Muiyakka muiyakka , by Purandaradasa , also begins with this scale .
Another famous composition in this raaga is Jagat janani rendered in Tamil language .
This section covers the theoretical and scientific aspect of this ragam .
Shivaranjanis notes when shifted using Graha bhedam , yields 2 other pentatonic ragams , namely , Sunadavinodini and Revati .
Graha bhedam is the step taken in keeping the relative note frequencies same , while shifting the shadjam to the next note in the ragam .
See Graha bhedam on Shivaranjani for more details and an illustration .
 The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani is a janya ragam associated with the 64th parent scale Vachaspati .
 The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani has vakra prayoga and The Carnatic scale Shivaranjani scale is as follows
Sangit Makarand is an ancient work on classical music written by Narada .
This work is a rare collection of definitions , descriptions and comments on all the essentials music by other ancient reputed authors from Bharata Muni to Sharangdeva .
Its main feature is the treatiment of Ragas ; categorizing them as male , female and neuter .
The treatise circa 1100 CE is the earliest text where rules similar to the current Hindustani classical music can be found .
 Narada actually names and classifies the system in its earlier form before the advent of changes as a result of Persian influences .
It also hints on the uniqueness of the raga-nomenclaturing .
On close study of it , one learns of three distinct stages on the nomenclaturing of the Indian ragas
Pandit Narasimhalu Vadavati is a clarinet musician .
 Pandit Narasimhalu Vadavati was born in 1942 in Pandit Narasimhalu Vadavati , a small village in Raichur taluk of Karnataka , India .
 Sri Matamari Veeranna was Sri Matamari Veeranna first Guru .
 Sri Matamari Veeranna learned Hindustani classical music under the guidance of Gwalior and Jaipur Gharana exponent late Pandit Siddarama Jambaladinni .
 Sri Matamari Veeranna was nominated as president of the World Music Festival 2011 organized at Los Angeles by World Clarinet Association .
 Pandit Narasimhulu Wadavati has earned an outstanding reputation for Pandit Narasimhulu Wadavati pioneering contribution to music having adapted a Western Classical instrument , Clarinet to Hindustani style of music .
 The its International Who 's Who in Music Biographical Centre , Cambridge , U.K. has now listed Biographical in its International Who 's Who in Music .
 Biographical fame shot to new heights when Biographical directed music for the award winning French Documentary `` Hathi '' .
Pandit Wadavati was born in 1942 in a small village , Wadavati in Raichur Taluk .
 Pandit Narasimhulu Wadavati grandfather was a Shehnai artiste , a Shehnai artiste father a Tabla player and a Shehnai artiste mother too was a devotional singer.Thus a Shehnai artiste was born into a musically talented family were strong foundations were laid .
 a Shehnai artiste love for music grew from a Shehnai artiste early boyhood years .
 a Shehnai artiste accepted Sri Matamari Veeranna as a Shehnai artiste Guru and also continued to practice under the guidance of Sri Venkatappa from whom Sri Venkatappa learnt to sing .
 a Shehnai artiste learned Hindustani classical music from the late Pandit Siddarama Jambladinni a famous vocalist belonging to the Gwalior and Jaipur Gharanas .
 After intensive practice for more than 10 years a Shehnai artiste became familiar with the intricacies and was able to give solo recitals .
 With a streak of experimentation in a Shehnai artiste after years of arduous practice a Shehnai artiste mastered playing the Clarinet adapting to Hindustani Music .
 a Shehnai artiste has perfected the art of producing a series of sounds in such a way that the listener can get a near-vocal impact .
 a Shehnai artiste can produce the elongated drawl of the `` vilambit '' portion of the gharanas in a sonorous manner .
 a Shehnai artiste subtle nuance has earned a Shehnai artiste applause among the music fraternity .
 Even today a Shehnai artiste continues to thrill the audience and transport them to raptures with a Shehnai artiste delightful rendition of `` alap '' , `` bada khayal '' and many more .
 Along with a Shehnai artiste troupe a Shehnai artiste has not only performed in Karnataka , India but also in U.K. , USA and France and won paeans of admiration from the audience .
 For a decade now , a Shehnai artiste passion to spread music has inspired a Shehnai artiste to set up Music Academy `` Swara Sangama Sangeetha Vidyalaya '' at Wadavati in Raichur Taluk and `` Pandit Narasimalu Wadavati Music Academy '' at Bangalore .
Chairman - Karnataka Sangeetha Nrutya Academy - Govt .
 of Karnataka .
 Karnataka Kala Tilak title by Karnataka Music and Dance Academy .
Gold Medal and Asthan Vidwan title by Shri Sharada Peetha of Shringeri Mutt by Sri Jagadguru Srimad Bharati Theertha Swamiji .
Bharatha Ratna Visweswaraiah Award by Engineering Pratistana , Bangalore in the year 1996-97 .
 Participation in Kannada Koota Conference in USA in 1997 .
 Karnataka Rajyothsava Award by Karnataka Government for 1997-98 .
Participation in Clarionet concert in CalArts , USA in 1998 .
 Honored and considered as an Outstanding Artist of the 20th Century by International Biographical Center , Cambridge .
Honored at the 68th Akhila Bharathiya Kannada Sahithya Sammelna , Bagalkot , Karnataka .
Honored with the title Hindustani Clarionet Sangeetha Ratna by Government Music College , Coimbatore , Government of Tamil Nadu .

 of Karnataka , India .

 of Karnataka
Shanno Khurana is a noted Indian classical vocalist and composer , from the Rampur-Sahaswan gharana of Hindustani classical music .
 A disciple of the doyen of the gharana , Ustad Mushtaq Hussain Khan , Rampur-Sahaswan is known for performing rare bandish and raag , though Rampur-Sahaswan singing style includes genres like khayal , tarana , thumri , dadra , tappa , to chaiti and bhajan .
 Born and brought up in Jodhpur , Rampur-Sahaswan started singing on All India Radio in 1945 in Lahore , later shifted to Delhi , where Rampur-Sahaswan continued Rampur-Sahaswan singing on All India Radio , Delhi and in concerts and music festivals .
 Rampur-Sahaswan also pursued music education , finally earning her M. Phil M. Phil .
and PhD in music from the Kairagarh University , and has undertakes extensive research on folk music of Rajasthan .
 Rampur-Sahaswan was awarded the Padma Shri in 1991 , followed by the Padma Bhushan in 2006 , the third highest civilian honour given by Government of India .
 In 2002 , Rampur-Sahaswan was conferred the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship , the highest honour in the performing arts conferred by the Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama .
 Shanno Khurana was born and brought in a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan .
 a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan was a family on non-musicians , of doctors , engineers , and people working in foreign services .
 But a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan interest in music grew in a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan early age , when a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan saw a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan brother learning from musicologist and vocalist Pandit Raghunath Rao Musalgaonkar , a disciple and nephew of Raja Bhaiya Poonchwale of Gwalior gharana .
 However , a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan conservative family didnt allow girls to learn music , but when a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan father saw listening intently to classical music on radio , he allowed a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan to start a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan musical training at age 12 under Pandit Raghunath Rao Musalgaonkar .
 Shanno Khurana was married at age 18 , to a dentist with the Indian Air Force and shifted to Lahore , though a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan continued singing at All India Radio , Lahore , starting in 1945 .
 After partition of India , a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan family had to shift to Delhi , where a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan husband left Air Force and started his private practice .
 However , at the insistence of a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan husband , a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan started a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan riyaz once again , despite having two young children and an ailing mother-in-law .
 a Punjabi family in Jodhpur , Rajasthan practiced with tabla maestro Pandit Chatur Lal , which continued for the following 16 years , and soon singing on radio as well .
 Meanwhile , Nirmala Joshi , who was secretary of the Sangeet Natak Akademi at the time , invited Nirmala Joshi to teach classical music at Nirmala Joshi music school , Sangeet Bharati at Mandi House in Delhi .
 Subsequently , Nirmala Joshi was introduced to Nirmala Joshi next teacher via Nirmala Joshi husband , when musicologist and chief producer at AIR , Delhi , Thakur Jaidev Singh happened to be AIR , Delhi , Thakur Jaidev Singh patient .
 AIR , Delhi , Thakur Jaidev Singh helped Nirmala Joshi get confidence as Nirmala Joshi started touring to Turkey , Iran , Greece and other areas as a part of cultural delegations sponsored by Government of India .
 Besides performing at notable music festival across India through the 1960s and 70s , including Tansen Sammelan , Gwalior , Harvallabh Festival , Jalandhar , and Haridas Music Harvallabh Festival , Mumbai .
 Tansen Sammelan taught Nirmala Joshi the purab-ang Thumri , and later insisted Nirmala Joshi on joining the Indira Kala Sangeet University at Khairagarh , Madhya Pradesh , where eminent musicologist and teacher S. N. Ratanjankar who has remained principal of Bhatkhande Music Institute , was the Vice Chancellor at the time .
 AIR , Delhi , Thakur Jaidev Singh was Nirmala Joshi guide through Nirmala Joshi M. Phil and PhD in music , wherein Nirmala Joshi undertook an extensive study-tour of Rajasthan , for Nirmala Joshi research on the folk music traditions of Rajasthan , tappa and folk songs .
 For the next three years , travelled back and forth from Delhi , but managed to complete Nirmala Joshi education .
 Nirmala Joshi went on to training under V. R. Athawale of Gwalior Gharana and S. N. Ratanjankar of Agra gharana , both of whom taught Nirmala Joshi rare ragas , further expanding Nirmala Joshi repertoire .
 Finally , at the request of AIR , Delhi , Thakur Jaidev Singh , Nirmala Joshi trained under the doyen of Rampur-Sasawan gharana , singer Ustad Mushtaq Hussain Khan , who was then teaching at the Bharatiya Kala Kendra in Delhi .
 However , Mushtaq Hussain first tested Nirmala Joshi skills for over five months , finally one day when Nirmala Joshi successfully sang Raag Nayaki-Kanada , Raag Nayaki-Kanada took Nirmala Joshi on formally as a student , via the ganda-bandh ceremony .
 After his untimely death in 1964 , Nirmala Joshi continued Nirmala Joshi training under his son , the Ustad Ishtiaq Hussain Khan .
 This extensive and varied training helped Nirmala Joshi expand Nirmala Joshi musical repertoire to include rare raagas and bandish , besides khayal , tarana , thumri , dadra , chaiti and bhajan , besides tappas and jangra , a folk form of Rajasthan .
 Over the years , Nirmala Joshi has been involving in not just research and documentation of aprachalit ragas , but also promoting This extensive and varied training through music festivals and lecdem series .
 Nirmala Joshi organization , Geetika , organizes music festivals for women , and tala vadya kutcheri , an all-woman music festival , Bhairav se Sohni , held in 1983 and all-woman festival on aprachalit raags held in 1996 .
 Over the years Nirmala Joshi composed directed and sung five full-length musicals , experimenting both with classical music as well as folk music styles .
 Nirmala Joshi operas include Heer Ranjha with Sheila Bhatia , in which Nirmala Joshi also played the lead role , Sohni Mahiwal in Punjabi , where in Ustad Mushtaq Hussain , son of Nirmala Joshi guru sang with Nirmala Joshi , Jahanaraa in Urdu , Chitralekha , based on the story by Bhagwati Charan Verma and directed by B.V. Karanth has music composed on 80 classical ragas , and Sundari , based on the novel by the same name written by Bhai Vir Singh in 1979 .
 In 2006 , Nirmala Joshi music album of genre of tappas , titled Sufi Raah was released by Parzor Foundation .
 Shanno Khurana was awarded the Padma Shri in 1991 , followed by the Padma Bhushan in 2006 , the fourth and the third highest civilian honour respectively given by Government of India .
 In 2002 , Nirmala Joshi was conferred the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship , the highest honour in the performing arts conferred by the Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama .
and was later made a board member of the Sangeet Natak Akademi
Roshan Ara Begum was a Hindustani classical vocalist .
 In Pakistan Hindustani is revered as Mallika-e-Mauseeqi .
 As the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan , Roshan Ara linked through the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan cousin Ustad Abdul Karim Khan to Kirana Gharana .
 Born in Calcutta in or around 1917 , Roshan Ara Begum visited Lahore , the cultural centre of Pakistan during the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan teens to participate in musical soirees held at the residences of affluent citizens of Chun Peer in Mohalla Peer Gillaanian at Mochi Gate .
 During the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan occasional visits to the city the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan also broadcast songs from the then All India Radio station , and the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan name was announced as Bombaywali Roshan Ara Begum .
 the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan had acquired this popular nomenclature because the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan shifted to Mumbai , then known as Bombay , in the late 1930s to live near Ustad Abdul Karim Khan , from whom the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan took lessons in Hindustani classical music for fifteen years .
 the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan performance in Chun Peers abode in early 1941 pleasantly surprised local heavyweights and connoisseurs with the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan expertise in rendering classical compositions .
 In Mumbai , the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan lived in a sprawling bungalow with the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan husband Chaudhry Mohammed Hussain , a police officer .
 Possessing a rich , mature and mellifluous voice that could easily lend Mumbai to a wide range of intricate classical music pieces , Roshan Ara employed the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan natural talent in the promotion of the art , which requires a high degree of cultivation and training .
 the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan singing features a full-throated voice , short and delicate passages of sur , lyricism , romantic appeal and swift taans .
 All these flourishes were combined in the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan unique style that reached Her singing peak from 1945 to 1982 .
 the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan vigorous style of singing was interspersed with bold strokes and layakari .
 Migrating to Pakistan in 1948 after the partition of India , Roshan Ara Begum settled in Lalamusa , a small town from which the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan husband hailed .
 Although far away from Lahore , the cultural centre of Pakistan , the cultural centre of Pakistan , the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan would travel back and forth to participate in music and radio programmes .
 Visual and audio recording-devices have preserved the richness of Roshan Aras music -- which often overflowed with tonal modulations -- Roshan Aras music sweetness and delicacy of gamaks and the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan slow progression of raags .
Roshan Ara Begum also sang some film songs , mostly under music composers like Anil Biswas , Feroze Nizami and Tassaduq Hussain .
 the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan sang for well-known films such as Pahali Nazar , , Qismat , Roopmati Baazbahadur and Neela Parbat .
 the daughter of Ustad Abdul Haqq Khan died in Pakistan in 1982 at the approximate age of sixty-five
 Shubha Mudgal is a well-known Indian singer of Hindustani classical music , Khayal , Thumri , Dadra , Thumri , Dadra , and popular Indian Pop music .
 Shubha Mudgal has been awarded the 1996 National Film Award for Best Non-Feature Film Music Direction for Amrit Beej , the 1998 Gold Plaque Award for Special Achievement in Music , at the 34th Chicago International Film Festival , for Shubha Mudgal music in the film Dance of the Wind , and the Padma Shri in 2000 .
 Shubha Mudgal is also close to movements like ANHAD and SAHMAT .
 Born in an academic family to Skand and Jaya Gupta in Allahabad , Uttar Pradesh , Uttar Pradesh .
Both her parents were Professors of English Literature at Allahabad University , with deep interest in Classical Hindustani Music and Kathak .
Her paternal grandfather , Prof. P. C. Gupta was also a Professor at Allahabad University .
She attended St. Marys Convent Inter College .
As a young girl she started learning Kathak in Allahabad following the foot steps of her sister .
She once replied to a dance examiners routine query of Aap kis gharaane ki naachti hain ?
with the retort , Hum apne gharaane ki naachte hain .
She later switched to Hindustani Classical Music as her vocation of choice while maintaining the same individualistic attitude .
 Her first traditional teacher was Pandit Ramashreya Jha in Allahabad , Uttar Pradesh .
 Shubha Mudgal moved to New Delhi , and enrolled at the Delhi University .
 Shubha Mudgal continued Shubha Mudgal musical education under Pandit Vinaya Chandra Mudgalya at the urging of Shubha Mudgal first guru .
 After graduating from the University , Shubha Mudgal training continued under Pandit Vasant Thakar in New Delhi , and more informally with other established singers as Pandit Jitendra Abhisheki , Naina Devi and Pt .
Kumar Gandharva .
 Shubha Mudgal started performing as a Hindustani classical singer in the 1980s , and gained a certain reputation as a talented singer .
 In the 1990s , Shubha Mudgal started experimenting with other forms of music , including pop and fusion varieties .
 Shubha Mudgal says , I believe in music .
 Khayal , Thumri , Dadra and Thumri are I favourites , but that does not mean that I should not experiment with other forms .
 Why should I curtail I musical urges ?
 asks the singer and adds , I want to allow the artist in I to come through .
 If you are a musician , how can you say , this one is from devotional poetry , so I am not going to sing it .
 In addition to Shubha Mudgal recordings and concerts , Shubha Mudgal briefly ran a website called raagsangeet.com aimed at lovers of Classical Indian Music .
 Shubha Mudgal sang the title track of Star Plus s No. 1 serial Diya Aur Baati Hum along with Kailash Kher .
It is a very soulful , classical - based Rajasthani folk song .
 After graduating from the Delhi University , Shubha Mudgal married Pt .
 Shubha Mudgal son Mukul Mudgal who was a promising lawyer .
Shubha Mudgal however got divorced from him , and married Aneesh Pradhan .
 Shubha Mudgal only son from Shubha Mudgal previous marriage , Dhaval , is a member of a Delhi-based band and a promising poker player
Riyaz is an Urdu language term used for music practice , for honing of Hindustani classical music vocal as well as instrument skills .
Sadhakam or Sadhana in Carnatic music .
 Sadhakam is followed rigorously by the students as well as exponents of vocal as well as dancing forms .
 The Riyaaz or Sadhakam , which often starts early in the morning at four , is taken seriously by the students for Riyaaz or Sadhakam requires intensity , discipline and commitment for years and forms an important component in the Guru - Shishya parampara .
 In Carnatic music , the impression is that the assiduous sadhakam of the Trinity of Carnatic Music was the bedrock of the excellence of the old-world vidwans
 Bhopali , also known as Bhoop , Bhoop or Bhupali , is a Hindustani classical raga .
It is a pentatonic scale .
Most of the songs in this raga are based on Bhakti rasa .
The same raga in Carnatic music is known as Mohanam .
Writing about the musical theory of Indian classical music is fraught with complications .
There is no universally accepted set of rules or formal method of writing notations .
However , the Bhatkhande and Paluskar paddhatis are the two ways of writing down musical notations .
Indian music has always been more of an aural tradition , and written word has never been an essential part of imparting talim .
Note : Normally written swaras indicate the middle octave .
A swara immediately followed by 1 indicates the mandra saptak and indicates the taar saptak .
Behavior refers to practical aspects of the music .
 It is complicated to talk about this for Hindustani music since many of the concepts are fluid , changing , or archaic .
 The following information can not be accurate , but The following information can attempt to reflect how the music existed .
Bor , Joep .
Rao , Suvarnalata ; der Meer , Wim van ; Harvey , Jane The Raga Guide : A Survey of 74 Hindustani Ragas .
Zenith Media , London : 1999
Anindo Chatterjee is an Indian tabla player from Farukhabad gharana .
 Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee was born in a musical family .
 Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee uncle Pt .
Debiprasad Chatterjee is an eminent sitar player of this country .
 Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee younger sister Smt .
 Keka Mukherjee is a leading sitar player of AIR and also well known for His younger sister Smt . solo performance .
 Keka Mukherjee is a disciple of Pt .
Jnan Prakash Ghosh .
 Gifted with an ability to summon crystal-clear melodies from Jnan Prakash Ghosh . drums , Anindo Chatterjee evolved into one of the worlds greatest tabla players .
 The director of the Farrukhabad Gharana of Tabla , founded by Haji Vilayat Khan Saheb , Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee continues to give new voice to his instrument .
 In addition to solo performances and recordings , Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee worked with sitar players Nikhil Banerjee , Imrat Khan , Budhaditya Mukherjee , and Rais Khan , Ustad Amjad Ali Khan , Ustad Sahid Parvej Pt.Manilal Nag , sarod players Buddhadev Das Gupta and Ali Akbar Khan , Ustad Amjad Ali Khan , Tejendra Narayan Majumder , flutist Hariprasad Chaurasia ; santoor player Pandit Shivkumar Sharma ; and vocalists Pandit Mallikarjun Mansur and Gangubai Hangal .
 Inspired by Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee uncle , Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee , Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee began playing tabla at the age of five .
Studying briefly with Ustad Afaq Hussain Khan of the Lucknow Gharana , he advanced to Pandit Jnan Prakash Ghosh , with whom he studied for three decades .
 The recipient of the prestigious Presidents Award in 1970 , Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee became the first table player to perform in the House of Commons 20 years later .
He performed at Rashtrapati Bhavan when U.S. President Barack Obama visited India in November 2010 .
 Pandit Biswanath Chatterjee received the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award for 2002
Pritam Bhattacharjee is an Indian classical vocalist .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee sings in Hindustani style of music .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee was born to Monjushree Bhattacharjee , a musician .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee was trained under Amarendra Chakraborty until the age of 14 .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee also trained under Pandit Jasraj .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee started Pritam Bhattacharjee career after training under Pandit Jasraj .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee has performed solos in many concerts and festivals in India and abroad .
 Pritam Bhattacharjee is a teacher at the Pandit Jasraj School of Music Foundation , Atlanta Chapter
Bhaskar Nath is an Indian classical instrumentalist .
 Bhaskar Nath plays the Shehnai beloning to Meerut Shehnai Gharana .
 Bhaskar Nath is a child prodigy .
Bhaskar Nath was born in New Delhi in a family of musicians originally hailing from Meerut to classical singer Pandit Vishwanath and K Rajlaxmi .
 Bhaskar Nath uncle is Pandit Jagannath , a renowned Shehnai player .
 He started learning Shehanai and Harmonium since young age under guidance of Shehanai grandfather Om Prakash .
He is schooling at Delhi Public School .
He is training under legendary vocalist Pandit Jasraj .
 Bhaskar Nath gave Bhaskar Nath first solo performance at the age of 10 .
 Bhaskar Nath renders in Ragas in Gayaki ang , Banarasi dhun , Thumri , Chaiti , Thumri / Chaiti / Kajri and a special in Tappa .
 Bhaskar Nath performed at the major festivals like the prestigious Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Festival in 2010 , Pandit Motiram Pandit Maniram Sangeet Samaroh in 2011 .
Bhaskar Nath belongs to a family of renowned musicians of Meerut Shehnai Gharana .
 Bhaskar Nath started Bhaskar Nath early training in Shehnai , Flute , and Harmonium at a very young age under the guidance of Bhaskar Nath grand father , the Late .
Pt .
 Om Prakash , guidance of his grandfather Om Prakash paternal uncle , the Late .
Pt .
 Jagannath who was an internationally acclaimed Shehnai Vadak and guidance of his grandfather Om Prakash father the renowned vocalist of Kirana Gharana , Pt .
 Pandit Vishwanath .
 Pandit Vishwanath is currently learning the fine nuances of music under Guru Shishya Parampra from `` Padam Vibhushan '' Sangeet Marthond , Pt .
Jasraj ji .
Bhaskar Nath has performed in many prestigious concerts .
 Bhaskar Nath performances have received rave reviews from press and public alike .
 Bhaskar Nath has imbided Bhaskar Nath paternal uncle , Pt .

In Tappa .

Premadasa Hegoda is a Sri Lankan sitarist .
 Premadasa Hegoda has lived in Japan since 1974 .
Hegoda studied with Ravi Shankar .
 Ravi Shankar is an associate professor of Music at the University of Tokyo and also teaches Indian music at Takasaki Art College .
 Ravi Shankar also operates the Premadasa Institute of Indian Music in Tokyo .
 Ravi Shankar composed the first sitar concerto in Japan , sponsored by Nihon Television , which was performed with the Yomiuri Symphony Orchestra and the Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra
 Munawar Ali Khan was a Hindustani classical singer of the Kasur Patiala Gharana .
 Munawar Ali Khan was the son of the maestro Bade Ghulam Ali Khan .
 Munawar Ali Khan was taught by Munawar Ali Khan father Bade Ghulam Ali Khan and Munawar Ali Khan uncle Barkat Ali Khan .
 Munawar Ali Khan also learnt Dhrupad from Hussainuddin Dagar .
 Munawar Ali Khan accompanied Munawar Ali Khan father to all Munawar Ali Khan concerts and became an integral part of Munawar Ali Khan fathers recital after Munawar Ali Khan father had a paralytic attack in early 1961 .
 Munawar Ali Khan had a full-throated voice with open aakar and Munawar Ali Khan style differed from Munawar Ali Khan fathers quicksilver style .
 After Munawar Ali Khan fathers demise in 1968 Munawar Ali Khan started giving solo concerts and bravely faced the challenge as the Khalifa of the Kasur Patiala Gharana .
 Munawar Ali Khan was an A-grade artist at All India Radio .
 Munawar Ali Khan also joined Bharatiya Kala Kendra in Delhi as a music teacher .
 Munawar Ali Khan performed in major music festivals in India and abroad .
 Munawar Ali Khan toured extensively in Germany , Switzerland , U.K. , France , Australia and represented India in Afghanistan in 1986 and in Pakistan in 1984 .
 Munawar Ali Khan has several discs to Munawar Ali Khan credit both in India and abroad , released by Audiorec , HMV , EMI Music and Sony Nad .
 With Sandhya Mukherjee Munawar Ali Khan also sang for a Bengali film Jaijawanti .
 Munawar Ali Khan created many khyal and thumri bandishes as well as geets and ghazals .
 Munawar Ali Khan sang ragas which were not very popular in Munawar Ali Khan Gharana , such as Shuddh Kalyan , Bairagi Bhairav , Abhogi Kanada , Suha Kanada , Devgiri Bilawal , and Ahir Bhairav and Munawar Ali Khan created a new raga named Malini Basant .
 Munawar Ali Khan was also a successful teacher ; Munawar Ali Khan students include Ajoy Chakraborty , Indira Misra , Primila Puri , Sanjukta Ghosh , Sajjad Ali and Kumar Mukherjee .
 This Kasur Patiala legacy is now carried by Raza Ali Khan son Raza Ali Khan and Raza Ali Khan nephews Jawad Ali Khan , Mazhar Ali Khan , Naqi Ali Khan , and Abdul Aziz Khan .
Munawar Ali Khan died at age of 59 in Kolkata on 13 October 1989
Taufiq Qureshi is an Indian classical musician .
 Taufiq Qureshi is a percussionist and a composer .
Born in Mumbai , to legendary tabla player , Ustad Alla Rakha .
 Ustad Alla Rakha eldest brother is tabla player , Ustad Zakir Hussain .
 His eldest brother received guidance from Ghatam Vidhwan , Pandit Vikku Vinayakram .
 Taufiq Quereshi started Taufiq Quereshi career early .
 Taufiq Quereshi stint with live performances began with the creation of Taufiq Quereshi own world music band , ` Surya ' way back in 1986-87 .
 Taufiq Quereshi has been featured as a performing artiste on the 2009 - Grammy award winning album Global Drum Project , Remember Shakti , Masters of Percussions and Summit .
 Taufiq Quereshi collaborates with various classical artists for fusion concerts .
 A dedicated self-learner , Taufiq Quereshi soon discovered A dedicated self-learner greatest asset ; ' a feel for the world of sound with all it 's intricate nuances ' .
 This quality makes A dedicated self-learner one of the most sought after rhythm-programmers , arranger-composers and percussionists in the world of studio recordings .
 A dedicated self-learner plays a variety of percussion instruments like djembe , duff , bongos , batajon .
 A dedicated self-learner performance on drums with a soft beat of a muffled drum and the very next moment ups the tempo and demonstration of different sounds - like breath , rhythm , breaking a champagne bottle , the sound of the train and the arrival of people , horses and others on arrival at the palace on the drums are quite popular .
 Taufiq Quereshi has done pioneering work on the African drum - Djembe .
 Taufiq Quereshi is the first artiste to have developed a unique rhythmic language to adapt the Tabla syllables on the Djembe .
Taufiq 's trademark style incorporates body and vocal percussions to create unique rhythmic motifs spanning across cultures .
 Taufiq Quereshi sense of tone and command over a wide variety of percussion instruments is phenomenal .
 For over a decade , Taufiq Quereshi has been imparting training to deserving students , some of whom are now making their mark .

Some of the popular ones are : Manikchand Paan Masala-Unche Log unchi Pasand , Babool toothpaste , Taj Mahal Brookebond Tea-Wah Taj , Tanishq Jewelry , Britannia GoodDay Biscuits , Coke-Sar Utha Ke Jiyo , Paragon footwear , Sony Bravia , Hit Spray , Pepsi-Indian Cricket team / World Cup , Indian Railways , Nike shoes-Parallel Journey .

He also been a part of background score and music for movies like Damini , To Pakistan , , -LSB- Ashoka , Kashmir , Black , Dil Chahta Hai , Sawariya , Dhoom 2 , Bhool Bhulaiya , Parzania , Tere Naam , Jab We Met , Action Replay , Housefull 2 , Tez , ABCD , Bhaag Milkha Bhaag .
Taufiq Qureshi is married to Geetika Varde , a renowned vocalist of the Jaipur-Atrauli gharana
The Raga Guide is a 1999 Nimbus Records compilation of 74 Hindustani ragas on four CDs .
 The Raga Guide includes a textbook edited by Joep Bor with information and western-style transcriptions of the ragas and a catalogue of two sets of ragamala plates , dated to ca. 1610 and 1650 .
The 1610 plates are painted in the Mughal style .
The featured artists are Vidyadhar Vyas , Shruti Sadolikar-Katkar , Buddhadev Das Gupta , and Hariprasad Chaurasia
Dilshad Khan is a Bengali Hindustani classical singer of the Patiala Gharana .
Dilshad Khan was born Arabinda Dasgupta in Kolkata , the second son of civil servant P M Dasgupta and Bhabani Dasgupta .
 Dilshad Khan was named as Arabinda Dasgupta .
Dilshad is the younger brother of eminent sarod maestro Buddhadev Das Gupta .
 Dilshad attended St. Xaviers Collegiate School , Kolkata , where future music composer R. D. Burman was future music composer R. D. Burman classmate .
 Dilshad started learning tabla at the age of four , but later took up singing under the guidance of N.C. Chakravorty , Hidan Banarjee and Gyan Prakash Ghosh .
 Dilshad was inspired by Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan .
After moving permanently to Mumbai Khan became a disciple of eminent Kirana gharana vocalist Padmashree Ustad Faiyaz Ahmed Khan .
He gave up a lucrative career as a marine engineer .
Dilshad Khan is married to classical vocalist , Parveen Sultana .
They have a daughter
Sawai Gandharva Bhimsen Festival edition of the festival is also held in Hyderabad , India at the historical Chowmahalla Palace .
 It was organised for the first time in Hyderabad in February 2012 .
It is organised by Mohan Hemmadi and Abhijit Bhattacharjee .
It was decided to make it an annual event in Hyderabad like the Pune edition , and possibly an all-night event .
The festival started on a wrong note with police denying permission and the show on the first day had to be curtailed .
And the police gave a limited permission till 10 p.m. in the night , making it difficult for artists to be accommodated well in stipulated time
Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib was a prominent musician of the Agra Gharana , who excelled both as singer and teacher .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib father , Natthan Khan , was Natthan Khan an acclaimed performing artist of Natthan Khan time , and a noted guru .
 Vilayat Hussain Khans elder brothers were also noted singers and taught Vilayat Hussain Khans elder brothers after their fathers early death .
 Abdullah Khan was Natthan Khans son who was several years senior to Abdullah Khan brother Vilayat Hussain Khans elder brothers .
Vilayat Hussain Khan , the singer , is not to be confused with the famous and controversial sitar player Vilayat Khan .
 Vilayat Khan the singer had several disciples in Maharashtra , and the region owes its eminence in Hindustani music to the work of generous teachers like Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib , Balakrishnabuwa Ichalkaranjikar , Alladiya Khan , and Abdul Karim Khan .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib most famous guru-shishya relationship was with Jagannathbuwa Purohit and each of several disciples in Maharashtra composed several bandishes dedicated to the other .
 Vilayat Abdullah Khan singing from Abdullah Khan later years is available through commercial releases and private collectors .
Vilayat Hussain Khan composed bandishes in many ragas including some very rare ones under the nome de plume Pran Piya .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan received Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib early training in hindustani classical music from Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib father Natthan Khan who was one of the pioneers of the Agra Gharana .
 After Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib fathers death , Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib was trained by Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib uncles Kallan Khan and Mohammad Baksh .
The total number of gurus of Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan sahib are estimated at around 42 which include aftab-e-mousiqi Ustad Faiyaz Khan .
 Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib most famous guru-shishya relationship was with Jagannathbuwa Purohit and each of them composed several bandishes dedicated to each other .
 Some of Ustad Vilayat Hussain Khan Sahib well known students include Mogubai Kurdikar , Pandit Yashpaul , Jagannathbuwa Purohit , Menaka Shirodkar , Ratnakant Ramnathkar , Ram Marathe , Gajananrao Joshi and Girija Kelekar .
 Some of his well known students son Yunus Hussain Khan is a prominent name in Agra Gharana as well
Yogesh Samsi born to renowned vocalist Pandit Dinkar Kaikini .
 Yogesh Samsi father the eminent vocalist Dinkar Kaikini initiated Yogesh Samsi at the age of six .
At the age of four he started learning the tabla from Pandit H. Taranth Rao .
Later , he sought the guidance of Ustad Allarakha Khan , one of the greatest percussionists .
He spent 23 years under the tutelage of Allarakha .
Yogesh Samsi has accompanied the top grade instrumentalists and vocalists and dancers of India , including Ustad Vilayat Khan , Pt Dinkar Kaikini , Pandit Bhimsen Joshi , Pt Shivkumar Sharma , Pt Hariprasad Chaurasia , Ustad Amjad Ali Khan and Pt Birju Maharaj .
 Yogesh Samsi strives to keep up Yogesh Samsi revered Gurus word of preserving the tradition in the presentation of tabla solo .
 Yogesh Samsi also appeared in the first episode of Idea Jalsa with Shivkumar Sharma & Takahiro Arai
Pandit Mukul Shivputra is a Hindustani Classical vocalist of the Gwalior Gharana and the son and foremost disciple of Pt .
Kumar Gandharva .
Born in Bhopal to Bhanumati Komkalimath and Pt .
 Kumar Gandharva , Pt .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra took to musical training early on from Pandit Mukul Shivputra father .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra continued Pandit Mukul Shivputra musical education in Dhrupad and Dhamar with Pt .
K. G. Ginde and in Carnatic Music with M. D. Ramanathan .
 Since K. G. Ginde teens , Pt .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra regularly accompanied Pandit Mukul Shivputra father on Tanpura for vocal support .
In 1975 , Pt .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra , then known as Mukul Komkalimath , debuted Pandit Mukul Shivputra first performance at the 23rd Sawai Gandharva Music Festival being the first in Pandit Mukul Shivputra generation of singers to debut a performance at the prestigious venue .
 Since Pandit Mukul Shivputra wifes death , Pt .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra has performed infrequently and irregularly in the public , which most attribute to Pandit Mukul Shivputra drug addictions and alcoholism .
Pt .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra is also known for Pandit Mukul Shivputra temperamental antics on the concert stage , from lecturing Pandit Mukul Shivputra accompanists on how to play their instruments , to showing up drunk to Pandit Mukul Shivputra performances .
Pt .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra lost Pandit Mukul Shivputra wife after the birth of their son , Bhuvanesh Komkalimath who Pandit Mukul Shivputra is a vocalist .
Pt Mukul Shivputra has been treated for addiction at Indore Deaddiction Clinic .
 Pandit Mukul Shivputra currently lives in Pune and is quite back to a normal life .
 As per this interview titled The Raga of Truth in 2010 Pandit Mukul Shivputra has chosen a life of a fakir and chooses to wander in search of finding the essence of the Ragas Pandit Mukul Shivputra sings , just like the ancient seers of Marga Sangeet .
 As per the interview Pandit Mukul Shivputra is convinced that Pandit Mukul Shivputra can realise the truth of a raga the way Pandit Mukul Shivputra elders realised .
 A raga itself is a means to salvation for a vocalist , Pandit Mukul Shivputra believes .
 And Pandit Mukul Shivputra lives what Pandit Mukul Shivputra realises
David A. Immergluck is an American multi-instrumentalist who is best known as a guitarist in the alternative rock bands Counting Crows , Camper Van Beethoven and the Monks of Doom .
 A versatile musician , David A. Immergluck plays mandolin , pedal steel guitar , electric sitar , and keyboards on a professional level , sings and harmonizes with backing vocals , and performs some songs as a slide guitarist .
David Immerglucks surname is Austrian , and roughly translates from German as always lucky .
 David A. Immergluck nickname is Immy , often coupled with the slang phrase gim me .
 David A. Immergluck began playing music in the San Francisco Bay area .
 Like other aspiring young musicians , David A. Immergluck played with various childhood friends , but began a lifetime habit of joining or sitting in with more than one band at a time , learning from the exposure to other differing musical influences and interests .
 David A. Immergluck early began to experiment with different sounds and a growing interest in instruments beyond just the guitar .
 Performing in an esoteric rock band called Polymorph , David A. Immergluck recorded Polymorph first singles with a band named Mod-L Society ; Back To Baltimore , and Janie , in 1985 .
 By 1986 , Polymorph had moved on to a band called The Ophelias , and the same year , had spread Ophelias interests to joining other indie rock bands .
 The Monks of Doom were a side project formed by members of the popular progressive San Francisco Bay area indie rock Camper Van Beethoven .
Formed in 1986 , the Monks of Doom somehow fused post-punk sensibilities with prog rock decadence and folk tradition and elegance .
 Six months into the Monks of Doom career , original guitarist Chris Molla was expelled from the group due to original guitarist Chris Molla lack of commitment and was replaced by David A. Immergluck , who contributed guitar , pedal steel , vocals , and keyboards in the group .
 One Allmusic critic compared the Monks of Doom work to pop experimentalists Frank Zappa and Syd Barrett .
Bassist Victor Krummenacher noted , We were interested in doing slightly more outside music that had heavier and more progressive tendencies .
 One was an outside expansion , a chance to go wherever We imagination took We .
 David A. Immergluck described the sonic chemistry between that of David A. Immergluck and Lisher , the bands two guitarists , as music that seemed to juxtapose the chaotic and the beautiful , the raw bluster and the ornate .
 David A. Immergluck also joined Camper Van Beethoven as a member for the final tours of their initial run , prior to their breakup in 1990 .
 The Monks of Doom intensified the Monks of Doom activity after this , ultimately producing five albums to positive acclaim before the members took a long reprieve in 1993 .
Both groups have since reformed - Camper Van Beethoven in 1999 , and the Monks of Doom in 2003 .
 Around 1993 , David A. Immergluck became involved with an early incarnation of the modern rock group Counting Crows albums , and has since appeared in some capacity on all of Counting Crows albums .
 Because of other musical projects , David A. Immergluck initially functioned only as a session player .
 With David A. Immergluck skills on a variety of guitars , including both slide guitar and pedal steel guitar , mandolin , keyboards and backing vocals , David A. Immergluck easily fell into place with old friends from the San Francisco Bay scene .
 Since 1999 , David A. Immergluck has been a permanent member of the band , touring and recording .
 David A. Immergluck joined another band , Glider , during the time David A. Immergluck was contributing to the Monks of Doom .
 David A. Immergluck has also performed as both a session musician and a sideman with a wide range of other artists , including John Hiatt , Chantal Kreviazuk , Elan Sara Defan , Cracker , The Walkabouts , Low Stars , Jason Karaban and Sordid Humor .
 David A. Immergluck , along with Davey Faragher , was nominated for a Grammy award for Best Contemporary Folk Album in 2001 for David A. Immergluck work with John Hiatt s album Crossing Muddy Waters , a bluesy soulful album of only three performers , without drums , compared by some to the work of Tom Waits , with Immergluck contributing mandolin , 12-string guitar , and slide guitar on many songs .
In 2013 , Immergluck appeared on the opening track of Joseph Arthur s tenth studio album , The Ballad of Boogie Christ .
Extensive description of instruments on the official website in the infobox : .
 David A. Immergluck has listed a variety of musicians who were influences on David A. Immergluck music .
They include : Jimi Hendrix , Bob Dylan , The Band , Van Morrison , The Doors , Bruce Springsteen , Jerry Garcia , Guided By Voices , Peter Green , Led Zeppelin , and Miles Davis
Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty is an Indian Hindustani classical vocalist .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty belongs to the Patiala gharana .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty was born in Kolkata , Bengal to Ajit Chakrabarty in a Hindu Brahmin family .
 They moved to India from Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty homeland , Bangladesh during the partition and raised Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty two sons in Shyamnagar .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty younger brother , Sanjay Chakrabarty is a noted composer and music therapist .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty was a disciple of Ustad Munawar Ali Khan .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty is also a first class graduate from the Rabindra Bharati University .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty showed extraordinary promise in vocal music and at the age of three , began taking lessons from Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty father Ajit Chakrabarty .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty then learnt from Pannalal Samanta and Kanai Das Bairagi and later became a student of Padma Bhushan Pandit Jnan Prakash Ghosh .
 In 1969 , Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty training took a decisive turn as Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty became a disciple of Ustad Munawar Ali Khan , son of the legendary maestro of the Patiala-Kasur gharana , Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty is notable for imagination and sensitivity to lyrics , coupled with Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty uncanny sense of rhythm .
 Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty founded and runs the Shrutinandan music academy .
 Ajoy Chakrabarty is married and Pandit Ajoy Chakrabarty daughter , Kaushiki Chakrabarty is also an upcoming talent of Hindustani classical music
Bhagwat was born in Bhilai , India .
 Bhagwat was introduced to playing sitar at the age of nine by Bhagwat uncle .
 Bhagwat trained under R. N. Verma of the Maihar gharana and traveled to Bhilai at the age of 13 to train under Bimalendu Mukherjee of the Imdadkhani gharana .
 Bhagwat performed for All India Radio beginning in 1994 and was awarded a national scholarship by the Indian Ministry of Human Resource Development .
 Bhagwat performed in Bhilai , India and the United States .
 Bhagwat is based in the United States , and married .
 Bhagwat continues to train as a sitarist and listens to Indian classical singers to improve Bhagwat technique
The history of the sitar in jazz , that is the fusion of the sounds of Indian classical music with Western jazz , dates back from the late-1950s or early-1960s when musicians trained in Indian classical music such as Ravi Shankar started collaborating with jazz musicians such as Tony Scott and Bud Shank .
Later jazz recordings containing sitar music include albums by Miles Davis , Alice Coltrane , Yusef Lateef , Joe Harriott , and Ornette Coleman .
Although music based around the sitar would later spread from jazz to more popular music via The Beatles , the sitar became more widely known in the western world mainly through the work of Indian musicians such as Pandit Ravi Shankar , beginning in the late 1950s .
From there it was taken up by jazz musicians and would later became a youth phenomenon in the mid-1960s after Beatle George Harrison took lessons from Ananda Shankar , nephew of Pandit Ravi Shankar , and played sitar on several songs .
The first recorded collaboration between Indian and Jazz musicians occurred in 1961 with Ravi Shankar and a group led by the West Coast American saxophonist/flutist Bud Shank .
 Indian and Jazz musicians album entitled Improvisations only features one track , Improvisations on the theme music from Pather Panchali , in which Ravi Shankar and the Western musicians play together .
 The track is remarkable for little else ; it is simply Western film music with the sitar playing the melody .
 However , it is interesting to note that this session , and that of film composer Shankar Jaikishan , were connected the film industry , for Indian film music surely contributes the most considerable corpus of music that combines Indian and Western musics .
 However , both Ravi Shankar and Ananda Shankar are important figures with regard to Jazz because it was primarily through both Ravi Shankar and Ananda Shankar music that John Coltrane and others became aware of Indian music .
 Tony Scott recorded a track entitled Portrait of Pandit Ravi Shankar on Pandit Ravi Shankar Dedications album , as early as 1957 .
 John Coltrane met Shankar in 1965 after a long period of mutual admiration and letter writing .
Coltranes name is inextricably linked to the emergence of modal Jazz in 1958 on Miles Davis album Milestones and it is believed that modal Jazz was inspired by Indian music .
 Indian influence is an important issue in the later music of John Coltrane such as the album Kulu Se Mama and also of musicians such as Yusef Lateef and Ornette Coleman .
In America , the profile of the sitar in Jazz was maintained by Collin Walcott .
After graduating from Indiana University in 1967 , where his major study was percussion , he travelled to Los Angeles to study sitar with Ravi Shankar and tabla with Alla Rakha , then the most famous tabla player in the West .
The most significant corpus of his output was with the groups Oregon , Codona and his own quartet , despite a prolific career as a sideman for players such as Miles Davis and Egberto Gismonti .
Walcott was heavily influenced by John Coltrane s Quartet .
 Walcott , like Mayer , is musically bi-lingual which helps to explain why the Indian and Western aspects of his musics fit together far more comfortably than previous experiments .
 Whilst Mayer acted as a bridge between musicians of two cultures , Walcott , like John Coltrane , absorbed the Indian music and assimilated it within his own music .
His quartet consisted of other American musicians so that the feeling of empathy between the musicians , which is a pre-requisite of good group improvisation , is maintained .
Walcott created a sitar technique which is not found in Indian music .
This involves stopping more than one string to create harmonies , usually thirds .
The more recent excursion of the sitar into Jazz is that of the sitar player Nishat Khan who is highly regarded as an Indian Classical player .
His first experience of playing with a jazz musician was a trio with the guitarist John McLaughlin who has been collaborating with Indian musicians since the mid-seventies with groups such as Shakti .
In the Nineties , Nishat Khan was working on his own Jazz project .
He rehearsed with American alto saxophonist Steve Coleman and recorded with a band which consisted of Django Bates , Mark Mondesir , Martin France , and two drummers from Africa .
The group did not perform in public , and the recording was not released .
In 2006 , Andrew Cheshire released Silent Trees Falling , an album composed solely of .
electric sitar in a mostly trio setting .
Widely regarded as an unheralded master of jazz .
 guitar , Andrew Cheshire combined raw jazz improvisation with an eastern flavored vocabulary resulting .
in a record that captures the spontaneity of jazz coupled with the sonority of the far east .
Comparative view of jazz and Indian classical music .
Indian music is the greatest tradition of improvisation in the East .
Therefore it is unsurprising that Jazz musicians , which have become the greatest exponents of improvisation in the West , have developed a certain fascination for Indian musicians and vice versa .
 John Coltrane was fascinated by Indian music .
 Keith Jarrett returned to improvised music , after a phase of playing entirely Western Classical music , on hearing a concert of Indian Classical music which Indian Classical claims was a reminder that what I was doing was not music .
 This statement reveals that to Keith Jarrett , who is primarily a Jazz musician , Indian music contains something intrinsic to Keith Jarrett conception of music that does not exist in Western Classical music .
Both Jazz and Indian music are commonly described as improvised music but in fact , composition is integral to both arts .
Compositions are used mainly as a springboard for improvisation and would probably account for about a tenth of a performance in both traditions .
One of the functions of the composition is to define the structure upon which the improvisation is based .
In Indian music , the gat is always played at the beginning of the final portion of an exposition of a rag by the soloist and from this , the tabla player is expected to join in .
It is not uncommon for the tabla to have not been told what the tal or what tempo is to be used and would be expected to derive this information from the gat which he may not have heard before .
If the soloist wishes to change to a new tal or tempo it is signalled by playing a different gat .
The presentation of the two main instruments in jugalbandi has become common both in India and outside .
What happens in Jugalbandi is not unlike the organisation of collective improvisation in jazz , in the sense that the musicians come together in the precomposed song or whatever the basis of the piece , and otherwise take it in turns to improvise in a spirit both of cooperation and friendly cooperation .
In Jazz , the structure of the improvisation is most usually defined by the head which normally comprises a melody and a harmonic structure , but could contain more or less structural information such as changes of feel e.g. from swing to salsa , or changes of tempo or meter .
The standard form of a jazz performance would start with the ` head which might be 32 bars long .
 Then , the musicians would take The standard form of a jazz performance in turn to improvise over this cyclic structure .
The performance ends with a recapitulation of the head .
Improvisations in both musics take place within cyclic frameworks , with the notable exception of free jazz which consciously eschews predetermined structures .
The ability to learn to use these frameworks to assist and inspire improvisation is really the essence of both art forms .
Being able to maintain ones place in the tal is precisely analogous to keeping the form in Jazz playing .
In fact , there are distinct similarities between the Sam of the tal and top of the form , the first beat of repeating structure , in Jazz .
 The special feature of the Sam is that phrases either start or end on The special feature of the Sam , reinforcing the notion that the tal is a circular structure .
 Whilst there is no such formalisation in Jazz of the ` top of the form , there is no doubt that other American musicians often use the ` top of the form as the point of maximum release of tension .
This is a chronological catalogue of recordings which have featured the sitar within a jazz context .
