 In 1985 , Private First Class Leonard M. Kravitz parents divorced , which had a profound impact on Private First Class Leonard M. Kravitz .
 Private First Class Leonard M. Kravitz relationship with Private First Class Leonard M. Kravitz father became extremely strained .
Kravitz focused on his music to help him get through this period .
That year , Kravitz met actress Lisa Bonet backstage at a New Edition concert .
 actress Lisa Bonet worked on The Cosby Show , the number one rated show on television .
They were close friends for two years before falling in love .
 Like Kravitz , actress Lisa Bonet is half African American and half Russian Jewish .
Kravitz moved back to New York City where The Cosby Show was produced in 1987 , moving in with then girlfriend Bonet .
 Kravitz and actress Lisa Bonet eloped to be married on November 16 , 1987 , actress Lisa Bonet 20th birthday , in a Las Vegas ceremony .
Kravitz , still known as Romeo Blue at the time , suddenly found himself in the headlines of tabloid newspapers .
 Kravitz and Bonet had a daughter , Zoe Isabella Kravitz , born on December 1 , 1988 .
 Kravitz and actress Lisa Bonet divorced in 1993 .
In 2001 , he began dating model Adriana Lima .
In 2002 , the couple was engaged , but less than a year later , the engagement was called off .
Kravitz identifies himself as a Christian in a religious sense , through choice but Im also a Jew , its all the same to me .
 During another interview Kravitz stated , Im half Russian Jewish , Im half black , I look in-between .
He also notes that spirituality has been an important issue in my growth , given his upbringing by parents of different faiths .
Such spirituality is prominently featured in many of his songs , such as the lyrics on his album Baptism , and having his back inscribed with a tattoo stating , My Heart Belongs to Jesus Christ .

colspan = 3 style = background : #DAA 520 ;| Grammy Award .

 colspan = 3 style = background : #DAA 520 ;| MTV Video Music the Grammy Awards of 2001
Ganayogi Panchakshara Gawai was a blind singer from Gadag , a town in southern state of Karnataka , India .
 Ganayogi Panchakshara Gawai was born at Kadashettihalli in Hangal Taluk , Karnataka .
 Ganayogi Panchakshara Gawai school Veereshwara Punyashrama was a premier learning center for Hindustani Music .
The Kannada film Ganayogi Panchakshari Gavayi is based on his real life incidents
In Hindustani music , meend refers to a glide from one note to another .
It is an essential performance practice , and is used often in vocal and instrumental music .
On the veena , sitar , and other plucked stringed instruments , it is usually done by pushing the strings across the frets to vary their effective length and tension ; compare portamento and finger vibrato .
It is considered a sort of alankar , or ornament .
Meend is important part of any classical performance , however it is a technique not possible on a hand-held harmonium often used in musical concerts , traditionalist singing khyal prefer an accompaniment like sarangi
The sitar is a plucked stringed instrument used mainly in Hindustani music and Indian classical music .
The instrument descended from long-necked lutes taken to Pakistan from Central Asia and is also believed to be influenced by the Veena .
 The sitar flourished in the 16th and 17th centuries and arrived at the Sitar present form in the 18th century Mughal period .
 the Sitar derives the Sitar distinctive timbre and resonance from sympathetic strings , bridge design , a long hollow neck and a gourd resonating chamber .
Used widely throughout the Indian subcontinent , the sitar became known in the western world through the work of Ravi Shankar beginning in the late 1950s and early 1960s .
 The sitar saw further use in popular music after the Beatles featured the sitar in their compositions Norwegian Wood , Within You Without You , Tomorrow Never Knows and Love You You To .
 Their use of the instrument came as a result of George Harrisons taking lessons on how to play Their use of the instrument from Shankar and Shambhu Das .
 Brian Jones of the Rolling Stones also used a sitar in Paint the Rolling Stones Black and a brief fad began for using the instrument in pop songs .
The Hindi word sitar originally derives from Persian seh + tar , literally meaning three strings .
The instrument descended from Central Asia to North India during the Delhi Sultanate period and is also believed to be influenced by the Veena .
 The first prototype instruments were invented during the Delhi Sultanate period of the 13th/14 century when the Persian patrons of music and poetry encouraged innovation in Indian art .
 It is named after a Persian instrument called the setar .
Hazrat Amir Khusro , the great Sufi musical and poetic genius , laid the foundation for its development .
 The sitar flourished in the 16th and 17th centuries and arrived at the Sitar present form in the 18th century Mughal period .
In his Bharatiya Sangeet Vadya Dr. Lalmani Misra traces the instruments development from the Tritantri veena through the nibaddh and anibaddh Tamburas also called tanbur and later the jantra .
Construction of the similar tanpura was described by Tansen .
During the time of Moghul Empire in the Indian subcontinent from about 1526 to 1857 .
 Persian lutes were played at the Mughal court and may have provided a basis of the sitar ; however , there is no physical evidence for the sitar until the time of the collapse of the Mughal Empire between 1690 and 1720 .
For comparison , lute-like instruments were depicted in Ancient Egyptian tomb paintings dated to the 18th Dynasty , so possibly predating evolution of the Sitar by 3,000 years .
A sitar can have 18 , 19 or 20 strings .
Six or seven of these are played strings which run over curved , raised frets , and the remainder are sympathetic strings which run underneath the frets and resonate in sympathy with the played strings .
The frets are movable , allowing fine tuning .
The played strings run to tuning pegs on or near the head of the instrument , while the sympathetic strings , which are a variety of different lengths , pass through small holes in the fretboard to engage with the smaller tuning pegs that run down the instruments neck .
 The Gandhaar-pancham sitar has Six playable strings , whereas the Kharaj-pancham sitar , used in the Maihar gharana , to which Ravi Shankar belongs , and other gharanas such as Bishnupur , has seven .
Three of these , called the chikaari , simply provide a drone ; the rest are used to play the melody , though the first string is most used .
The instrument has two bridges : the large bridge for the playing and drone strings and the small bridge for the sympathetic strings .
 the Sitar timbre results from the way the strings interact with the wide , sloping bridge .
As a string reverberates its length changes slightly as its edge touches the bridge , promoting the creation of overtones and giving the sound its distinctive tone .
The maintenance of this specific tone by shaping the bridge is called jawari .
Many musicians rely on instrument makers to adjust this .
The bridges are fixed to the main resonating chamber , or kaddu , at the base of the instrument .
Some sitars have a secondary resonator , the tumbaa , near the top of the hollow neck .
Materials used in construction include teak wood or tun wood , which is a variation of mahogany , for the neck and faceplate , and gourds for the resonating chambers .
The instruments bridges are made of deer horn , ebony , or very occasionally from camel bone .
Synthetic material is now common as well .
There are three popular modern styles of sitar offered in a variety of sub-styles and decorative patterns .
The two popular styles are the gayaki style sitars and the full decorated instrumental style sitars .
The gayaki style sitar is mostly of seasoned toon wood , with very few or no carved decorations .
 The gayaki style sitar often has a dark polish .
The inlay decorations are mostly of mother of pearl .
The number of sympathetic strings is often limited to eleven but may extend to thirteen .
 Jawari grinding The two popular styles are also different , as is the thickness of the tabli .
The other type of sitar , the instrumental style , is most often made of seasoned toon wood , but sometimes made of teak .
 The other type of sitar is often fitted with a second resonator , a small tumba on the neck .
This style is usually fully decorated , with floral or grape carvings and celluloid inlays with colored and black floral or arabesque patterns .
 The other type of sitar typically has thirteen sympathetic strings .
 The other type of sitar is said that the best Burma teak sitars are made from teak that has been seasoned for generations .
Therefore instrument builders look for old Burma teak that was used in old colonial-style villas as whole trunk columns for their special sitar constructions .
The sources of very old seasoned wood are a highly guarded trade secret and sometimes a mystery .
There are various additional sub styles and cross mixes of styles in sitars , according to customer preferences .
Most importantly , there are some differences in preferences for the positioning of sympathetic string pegs .
Amongst all sitar styles there are student styles , beginner models , semi-pro styles , pro-models , master models , and so on .
Prices are often determined by the manufacturers name and not by looks alone or materials used .
Some sitars by certain manufacturers fetch very high collectible prices .
Most notable are older Rikhi Ram and older Hiren Roy sitars depending upon which master built the instrument .
Though not technically a sitar , the electric sitar is a guitar with a special bridge , known as the buzz bridge , and sympathetic strings , to mimic the sitar .
It has 6 strings , and lacks movable frets .
Tuning depends on the sitarists school or style , tradition and each artists personal preference .
The main playing string is almost invariably tuned a perfect fourth above the tonic , the second string being tuned to the tonic .
The tonic in the Indian solfege system is referred to as sadja , sadaj , or the shortened form sa , or kharaj , a dialectal variant of sadaj , not as vad , and the perfect fifth to which one or more of the drones strings are tuned is referred to as pancam , not samvad .
The sympathetic strings are tuned to the notes of the raga being played : although there is slight stylistic variance as to the order of these , typically they are tuned : .
The player should re-tune for each raga .
Strings are tuned by tuning pegs , and the main playing strings can be fine-tuned by sliding a bead threaded on each string just below the bridge .
In one or more of the more common tunings the playable strings are strung in this fashion : .
In a Gandhar Pancham sitar , the bass or kharaj strings are removed and are replaced by a fourth chikari which is tuned to Ga. .
By playing the chikari strings with this tuning , one produces a chord .
 To tune the sympathetic strings to raga Kafi for example : I Sa , vii ni I Sa , II Re , iii ga , III Ga , iv ma , V Pa , VI Dha , vii ni I Sa , I Sa , II Re , iii Ga. .
There is a lot of stylistic variance within these tunings and like most Indian stringed instruments , there is no default tuning .
Mostly , tunings vary by schools of teaching and the piece that is meant to be played .
The instrument is balanced between the players left foot and right knee .
The hands move freely without having to carry any of the instruments weight .
The player plucks the string using a metallic pick or plectrum called a mizraab .
The thumb stays anchored on the top of the fretboard just above the main gourd .
Generally only the index and middle fingers are used for fingering although a few players occasionally use the third .
A specialized technique called meend involves pulling the main melody string down over the bottom portion of the sitars curved frets , with which the sitarist can achieve a seven semitone range of microtonal notes .
Adept players bring in charisma through use of special techniques like Kan , Krintan , Murki , Zamzama etc. .
 Adept players also use special Mizrab Bol-s , as in Misrabani and create Chhand-s even in odd-numbered Tal-s like Jhoomra .
 The Sitar Maestro Vilayat Khan had been touring outside North India off and on for more than 50 years , and was the first Indian musician to play in England after independence and to introduce the sitar to world audiences .
Then in the late 1950s and early 1960s Ravi Shankar along with his musical partner on Tabla Alla Rakha began a further introduction of Indian classical music to the West .
 The Kinks top 10 single See I Friends featured a low tuned drone guitar which was widely mistaken to be the instrument .
 The sitar saw further use in popular music after the Beatles featured the sitar in My Friends compositions Norwegian Wood , Within You Without You and Love You To .
 My Friends use of the instrument came as a result of George Harrisons taking lessons on how to play Their use of the instrument from Shankar and Shambhu Das .
 Brian Jones of the Rolling Stones also used a sitar in Paint the Rolling Stones Black and a brief fad began for using the instrument in pop songs .
 Led Zeppelin s Jimmy Page talked about Brian Jones of the Rolling Stones love of Indian music , saying lets put his love of Indian music this way ; I had a sitar before George Harrison ... I went to North India after I came back from a tour with the Yardbirds , I had been listening to Indian music for quite a while and wanted to hear it first hand .
The East Indian scales used on the track Friends Kashmir are considered fine examples of the influence of the sitar in rock music .
 The Doors extensively used Indian and near eastern scales in Indian and near eastern scales psychedelic soundscapes .
Robbie Kriegers guitar playing in The End is saturated in sitar melodic influence .
Psychedelic music bands often used new recording techniques and effects and drew on non-Western sources such as the ragas and drones of Indian music .
The Electric Prunes appeared in early ads for the Vox Wah wah pedal , which touted the effects ability to make an electric guitar sound like a sitar .
Psychedelic influences spread into folk , rock , and soul , creating the subgenres of psychedelic folk , psychedelic rock , psychedelic pop and psychedelic soul in the late 1960s before declining in the early 1970s .
 Psychedelic music bands expanded Psychedelic music bands musical horizons , and went on to create and/or influence many new musical genres including progressive rock , kosmische musik , synth rock , jazz rock , heavy metal , glam rock , funk , electro and bubblegum pop .
Psychedelic music was revived in a variety of forms of neopsychedelia from the 1980s onwards , and re-emerged in electronic music in genres including acid house , trance music and new rave
Gualberto Garcia Perez is a musician credited with creating Flamenco Fusion , also called Rock Andaluz .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez was born in 1945 in Sevilla , Spain .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez maternal grandfather was a jack-of-all-trades who sung Flamenco , nicknamed Currillo el Calentero .
 His maternal grandfather Mother , Pastora Perez Peral , was an amateur flamenco singer well-regarded by her neighbors .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez entered the Salesians school where Gualberto Garcia Perez two passions in life were formed : football and music .
 Under the attentive guidance of Don Pedro , Gualberto Garcia Perez early mentor at the Salesians school , Gualberto Garcia Perez and Gualberto Garcia Perez classmates went on to become part of the local lore of the choir Rociero de Triana when his entire school football team was absorbed into the professional Real Betis Balompie soccer club .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez would reach the All-Andalusian team and others , like Quino , would go so far as to play for the Spanish national football team .
 At the age of 17 , Gualberto Garcia Perez quit football to dedicate Gualberto Garcia Perez to music , forming the rock group The Bats , which was followed in 1967 by Smash , a group which pioneered Spanish and Andalusian Rock history .
 After disbanding the group , Gualberto Garcia Perez left Spain for the US to study music , alongside Gualberto Garcia Perez first wife , Jessica Jones Carson , an American from New York City .
 There , Gualberto Garcia Perez began to establish Gualberto Garcia Perez as a composer .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez first work was the rock opera Behind Stars ; in cooperation with the Good Vibrations Studio and the Yoga Symphony Orchestra , Gualberto Garcia Perez formed a group for it with the famous Hindu sitar player Diwan Mothihar .
This first solo recording has not been released yet .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez early works feature the voice and lyrics of Gualberto Garcia Perez first wife .
 Returning to Spain for the US Gualberto Garcia Perez published two solo albums : A la vida al dolor and Vericuetos .
 In 1976 Gualberto Garcia Perez spent several months in France and the Netherlands , composing chamber music , which would lead to Gualberto Garcia Perez next record : Otros dias .
 Between 1976 and 1979 Gualberto Garcia Perez arranged and collaborated several projects , rock and flamenco compositions , which were all brought together on Inquietudes a compas , re-released in 1997 .
 In 1979 Gualberto Garcia Perez recorded a fusion album between cantejondo songs and sitar called Gualberto Garcia Perez and Agujetas .
 During this decade Gualberto Garcia Perez made mostly orchestration arrangements , such as flamenco and classical instrumentation .
 At this time Gualberto Garcia Perez arranged Casta for Lole y Manuel and Cuaderno de coplas and A traves del olvido by Carlos Cano , as well as the song Rimas de Becquer , for Benito Moreno .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez also recorded the album Puentes and compositions for a clarinet trio called Quartet Biennial , a work for the Banda Municipal de Sevilla , as well as a piece called Turrunuelo for an inaugural concert of the second Biennial .
 Gualberto Garcia Perez has also directed the choir Rociero de Triana longer than any other director in the choir Rociero de Triana history .
 Under Gualberto Garcia Perez direction , many successful albums were released .
In 1983 , after some memorable concerts with Ricardo Mino , he is asked to record once more live with Ricardo Mino , which resulted in the album , Puente Magico .
 In 1987 , Gualberto Garcia Perez started getting involved with musical computer science , which prompted the creation of Gualberto Garcia Perez own studio , which Gualberto Garcia Perez uses mainly to create music for cinema and television .
 In 1990 Gualberto Garcia Perez returned to the performing scene , touring for a long summer .
From this period , the first Cycle of the New Music at the University of Seville stands out .
Also from this period is the album Sin Commentario , released later by Lost Vinyl in 1996 .
 Also of note are Sin Commentario participation at the prestigious International Festival of the Guitar in Cordova , a Festival in Italy where Sin Commentario played next to Nacho Duato , and Encuentros de Nueva together with Wim Mertens .
 In 1995 Gualberto Garcia Perez participated in a new series of concerts , in which Gualberto Garcia Perez worked with diverse instruments upon prerecorded bases , combining different styles and tendencies .
 In 1998 Gualberto Garcia Perez recorded Resistances with Ricardo Mino , and in 2000 Gualberto Garcia Perez recorded the critically acclaimed Contrastes along with Ricardo Mino and several other artists
The Mewati Gharana is an apprenticeship clan and musical family of Hindustani classical music founded in the late 19th century by Utd .
Ghagge Nazir Khan of Jodhpur .
 With Jodhpur own distinct aesthetic and stylistic views and practices , the gharana is an offshoot of the Gwalior Gharana and acquired Jodhpur name after the region from which Jodhpur founding exponent hailed : the Mewat region of Rajasthan .
The gharana gained visibility and following the latter-half of the 20th Century after acclaimed contemporary vocalist Pt .
Jasraj became popular in the realm of Hindustani Classical music at the same time and is viewed as a figure who revived and popularized the gayaki .
The musical ancestors of Ghagge Nazir Khan , the fountainhead of the Mewati Gharana , were exponents and descendants of the Gwalior Gharana .
 In seeking musical patronage , these descendants of the Gwalior Gharana style separated from their original clan and settled in what is now western and southern Rajasthan .
 Being isolated from the mainstream Gwalior Gharana musicians , the Rajasthan-based branch of the Gharana developed new stylistic forms and aesthetic principles as a result of separation .
Eventually , these changes resulted in the Mewati gayaki and became distinct although reminiscent of the Gwalior style .
 the Mewati gayaki is for this reason that the Mewati Gharana is considered both musically and genealogically different from the Gwalior Gharana style .
 Ghagge Nazir Khan passed on Ghagge Nazir Khan of Jodhpur . musical tradition to Ghagge Nazir Khan of Jodhpur . foremost disciples , Pandit Natthulal and Chimanlal Pandit .
 Pandit Natthulal passed the tradition onto Pandit Natthulal nephew , Pandit Motiram who shared this tradition with Pandit Natthulal brother , Jyotiram Pandit around the start of the 20th century .
 During this period , The Mewati Gharana musicians were under monarchical patronage for Mewati musicians music .
 Jyotiram later became a disciple of Rajab Ali Khan , bringing elements of the Jaipur and Kirana gayakis into the The Mewati Gharana style .
Motiram passed this tradition to his sons , Pandit Maniram and Pratap Narayan Pandit .
 After Motirams unprecedented and untimely demise , Maniram and Pratap Narayan were instrumental in grooming Motirams younger brother , Jasraj , in the The Mewati Gharana tradition after Jasraj renounced playing Tabla , Jasraj primary training at the time .
 Influenced by the music of Amir Khan and Begum Akhtar , Jasraj introduced new stylistic elements into the traditional The Mewati Gharana style , producing a more emotive , devotional , rhythmic-conscious , and lyric-conscious style .
 Although it has ancestry in the style and trends of the Gwalior Gharana gharana , the Mewati Gharana gayaki has some distinct qualities .
Through Sufi and Kirtankar influence , the Mewati Gharana gayaki includes theistic and spiritual elements , where religious verses from Hinduism and Shia Islam especially Ismailism are incorporated not only in the grammatical content of the music , but as an intrinsic elements in musical development , some contemporary compositions invoke the name and attributes of Mawlana Shah Karim al-Hussaini Aga Khan as the manifest Imam and the tenth incarnation of Lord Vishnu according to the Dashavatara .
The verse Om Shri Anant Hari Naaraayan is typically invoked as the initiation of a performance , and as the grammatical medium for an Alap .
 Elements of Hinduism and Shia Islam are simultaneously and polytheistically incorporated throughout musical works .
Mewati gayaki includes substantial use of sargam and tihais .
 In a crude sense , the approach to Taankari is similar to the Patiala Gayaki and Tappa Gayaki in execution but is closer to the Gwalior Gharana gayaki in application .
Several ragas unique to the Mewati Gharana include Jaiwanti Todi , Din Ki Puriya , Odhav Bageshree , Khamaj Bahar and Bhavani Bahaar .
Pt .
 Jasraj has added many devotional compositions to the The Mewati Gharana repertoire , the most popular being , Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya in Bhimpalasi
Gopeshwar Banerjee or Gopeshwar Bandopadhyay was an Indian classical singer and musicologist , belonging to Bishnupur gharana of Hindustani music , which originated in Bishnupur in West Bengal .
 Gopeshwar Banerjee was known for Gopeshwar Banerjee khyal and dhrupad renditions , besides Rabindra Sangeet .
 Gopeshwar Banerjee also sang thumri , and most notably the thumri , Kon Gali Gayo Shyam , in Raga Mishra Khamaj , which Gopeshwar Banerjee popularized .
As a musicologist , he published several books of rare compositions with musical notations , including dhrupad and Rabindra Sangeet .
He started his career as a court musician of the Maharaja of Burdwan in 1895 , and worked there for 29 years till 1924 .
Thereafter he shifted to Kolkata .
Towards the end of his career , he was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship in 1962 , the highest honour conferred by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama .
 Born in 1880 , in Bishnupur , Bankura in West Bengal Bishnupur , Bankura in Bengal was the second son of Bishnupur , Bankura in Bengal father Anantalal Banerjee , who was court musician in of Ramkrishna Singhadev of Bishnupur .
 Bishnupur , Bankura in Bengal was disciple of Ram Shankar Bhattacharya , later became the first teacher of the residential music school of Bishnupur , Bishnupur Sangeet Vidhyalaya , later renamed Ram Saran Music College .
 All Bishnupur , Bankura in Bengal three sons , Ramprasanna Banerjee , Gopeswar Banerjee and Surendranath Banerjee were all singers and also musicologists .
 His son Ramesh Banerjee did valuable documentation and music notation work in the field of Indian classical music .
The eldest , Ramprasanna Banerjee wrote , Sangeet Manjari , which contained theoretical treatise on musical concepts , besides favoured practices in vocal recitals , and notations of various genres , like dhrupad , khyal , thumri , and tappa .
 Ramprasanna Banerjee wrote younger brother Surendranath Banerjee was also a noted musicians and one of the pioneers of the Bishnupur gharana .
 Later remained Principal of the Ramsaran Music College in Bishnupur .
 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College died in 1972 in Bishnupur .
 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College received Principal of the Ramsaran Music College music training from musicians of Betiya gharana of Bihar , as did another contemporary singer of the Bishnupur gharana , Radhika Prasad Goswami .
 Early in Principal of the Ramsaran Music College career , in 1895 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College was appointed a court singer , by the Maharaja of Burdwan , here Principal of the Ramsaran Music College worked here for the next 29 years , till 1924 .
 This turned out to be most fruitful period of Principal of the Ramsaran Music College career .
 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College devoted Principal of the Ramsaran Music College time in the research of the theory and history of Indian music .
 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College travelled across India with the the Maharaja of Burdwan and became acquainted with several noted musicians of the time , which expanded Principal of the Ramsaran Music College knowledge of various musical traditions and genres .
 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College also learnt to play surbahar from Sayed Mohammed working at the court of Maharaja Jatindramohan Tagore , thereafter Principal of the Ramsaran Music College also learnt sitar from Imdad Khan .
 Principal of the Ramsaran Music College surbahar recital along with Imdad Khan , where even commercially recorded .
 While still in Burdwan , Principal of the Ramsaran Music College published Sangita Chandrika in two volumes , an early and important study of musicology in India .
 Burdwan also included a collection of Bengali and Hindi songs set to music .
 Bengali other books on musicology include Geet-Darpan , Geet-Praveshika and Rabindra Sangeet , all in Bengali language .
 Once Bengali term as Burdwan came to end , Bengali shifted to Calcutta , where Bengali spent Bengali next 20 years , till 1943 .
 By now from singing , in time , Bengali had become an eminent musicologist .
 Bengali along with Bengali cousin Surendranath Banerjee , compiled a large number of Dhrupad compositions , complete with His son Ramesh Banerjee musical notations .
 Later , Bengali not just sang , but also reproduced some of the well known Rabindra Sangeet songs , the well known Rabindra Sangeet songs is songs composed by Rabindranath Tagore , especially those in the Dhrupadanga .
 Prior to 1917 , His son Ramesh Banerjee had published the first volume of Sangeet Chandrika , which included the notations for Tagores composition , Patha ekhan kela alasita anga .
 Today , Tagores is amongst the few singers from Bengal of the period , who performed the dhrupad-genre of singing , besides Radhika Prasad Goswami , Gopal Babu and Aghor Chakravarti .
 Tagores son Ramesh Banerjee also became a singer , while Tagores notable disciples include Rita Ganguly .
 In 1962 , Tagores was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship the highest honour conferred by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama
Vinod Kumar Dwivedi is an Indian classical Dhrupad - Dhamar singer , belonging to the Dharbhanga gharana .
 During Vinod Kumar Dwivedi childhood Vinod Kumar Dwivedi was trained by Vinod Kumar Dwivedi maternal uncle Sadhu Prashad Shukla and by Swami Atmanand in Banda , Uttar Pradesh .
 Later Vinod Kumar Dwivedi was trained by Kashinath Bodas , Abhay Narayan Malik and Prem Kumar Mallick .
 Vinod Kumar Dwivedi got an MA in Political Science , the Sangeet Prabhakar from Prayag Sangeet Samiti , and the Sangeet Alankar from Gandharav Mandal , and passed the UGC NET lectureship examination .
 Vinod Kumar Dwivedi is an artist at AIR and Doordarshan in Lucknow .
 Vinod Kumar Dwivedi is also an ICCR panel artist , and an examiner at the Lucknow Bhatkhande Vidyapeeth and Allahabad Prayag Sangeet Samiti .
 Vinod Kumar Dwivedi is a lecturer of music at Jugal Devi Saraswati Vidhya Mandir and principal of Ranjana Devi Sangeet Mahavidhyala , both in Kanpur .
 Vinod Kumar Dwivedi has performed in many cities in India , including Kanpur , Lucknow , Agra , Chitrakoot , Varanasi , Guwahati , Jaipur , and Mumbai .
 Vinod Kumar Dwivedi also performed in Colombo , Sri Lanka under a program jointly organised by Bhatkhande Vidyapeeth , Lucknow and ICCR COLOMBO
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan is a Tabla player of international repute and belongs to the A.I.R Delhi Gharana .
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan was born in 1934 at Sikar , Rajasthan , in a family of musicians .
 Nazir Khan Ustad Faiyaz Khan father , was a sarangi and tabla - player at the court of the Maharaja of Karoli .
 Munir Khan Nazir Khan his father elder brother is a well-known sarangi player .
 Munir Khan his elder brother initial training was under Ustad Hidayat Khan .
 Then Munir Khan his elder brother also learnt under the late Ustad Inam Ali Khan of the A.I.R Delhi gharana of Tabla .
Ustad Faiyaz Khan has also received training in mridangam from Ramnad Ishwaran .
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan began Ustad Faiyaz Khan career in All India Radio Jaipur in 1955 .
 In 1958 Ustad Faiyaz Khan moved to A.I.R Delhi .
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan retired as a staff artist from there in 1993 .
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan has accompanied many great stalwarts as well as has performed as soloist .
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan also has travelled the world extensively , for performances .
Some of them being participating in the festival of Shiraz , Iran , at Queen Elizabeth Hall in London , and performances in Australia , the U.S. and Europe .
Faiyaz Khan has had the rare opportunity to accompany three generations of musicians : from the great masters of yesteryear , such as Bade Ghulam Ali Khan , Amir Khan , Hafiz Ali Khan , Begum Akhtar , Gangubhai Hangal , Pannalal Ghosh , Siddheshwari Devi , Mallikarjun Mansur , and the masters of today like Pandit Ravi Shankar , Ali Akbar Khan , the late Nikhil Banerjee , Vilayat Khan , Sharan Rani , Parween Sultana , Amjad Ali Khan , Hariprasad Chaurasia , Bhimsen Joshi , Pandit Jasraj , Pandit Shivkumar Sharma , Ajoy Chakraborty etc. .
 Ustad Faiyaz Khan has also taught for a year in 1985 at the Washington University and since 1992 Ustad Faiyaz Khan has been a regular at the Rotterdam Conservatory
In Hindustani classical music , chilla or chilla katna is a stage of training or ritual where the student is fully isolated from the outside world and lives for music only .
 Some musicians spend long periods of Some musicians training in varying degrees of isolation and describe these as Some musicians chilla ; for others , its a shorter , more extreme retreat , traditionally lasting 40 days .
 In either form , it is thought to have the power of transforming not only the students music , but The word Chilla whole life .
 The word Chilla is widely used in the Punjab gharana of tabla playing .
Abdul Karim Khan , a singer of the Kirana Gharana , described chilla as lighting a fire under your life .
You either cook or you burn .
If you cook , everyone can enjoy your flavour - otherwise , youll be a mass of cinders , a heap of ash .
The word Chilla can also refer to the forty days after childbirth during which the mother is said to be unclean , or quarantined , or more generally a period of religious fasting and worship
Manik Varma is considered the doyen of Hindustani classical Music from the Kirana Gharana , most known for her song , Amrutahuni Goad .
She also excelled in semi-classical and light music like Thumri , Marathi Natya Sangeet , Bhavgeet and Bhakti geet .
She was a disciple of Hirabai Barodekar , daughter of Abdul Karim Khan and Sureshbabu Mane son of Abdul Karim Khan .
, the founder of the Kirana Gharana .
In April 1955 , her songs became part of the Geet Ramayan , a presentation of songs on Ram , a weekly , year-long programme by All India Radio , Pune , along with artists like Lata Mangeshkar , Yogini Joglekar , Usha Atre , Babanrao Navdikar and Sudhir Phadke .
 A number of renowned artists including Asha Khadilkar , Shaila Datar were trained under Asha Khadilkar .
 Many new singers perform Riyaz of Asha Khadilkar songs at initial stage of Many new singers training .
 Asha Khadilkar maiden name was Manik Dadarkar .
 Asha Khadilkar daughters include , Rani Varma who is also a well-known singer in Asha Khadilkar own right , Aruna Jaiprakash , Bharati Achrekar , an actor and Vandana Gupte , a Marathi Natya Sangeet stage , film and television actor .
 Asha Khadilkar received the prestigious Padma Shri award from the Government of India in 1974. , followed by the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award given by the Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama in 1986 .
 In Asha Khadilkar memory Manik Varma Pratishthan was established in Mumbai , which also presents Manik Ratna Award and scholarships .
It also organises function on the birth and death anniversary of Manik Verma .
 On Asha Khadilkar ninth death anniversary on November 12 , 2004 , a musical programme Baharla Parijaat Daari was presented by Devgandharva Bakhlebua Trust at Tilak Smarak Mandir in Pune
DesiRock is the third album by British-Indian producer DJ Swamis alternative bhangra group Swami and is also the title of the albums electro / bhangra / rock fusion lead track .
 DesiRock is their most popular album to date and voted as one of BBC Radio 1 s best DJ tracks of the year .
 DesiRock was also crowned the best album of the year by Eastern Eye newspaper .
 In the year after DesiRock release , producer DJ Swami won the Media Storm Best Producer award at the UK Asian Music Awards .
The album was Swamis first in the bands current lineup .
The album cover shows DJ Swami , flanked by the bands two vocalists , S-Endz and MC Sarpanch .
DesiRock Entertainment is the name of DJ Swamis music production company specializing in progressive South Asian electronic music
Professor B. R. Deodhar was an Indian classical singer , musicologist and music educator .
 Professor B. R. Deodhar was a vocalist of Khayal - genre of Hindustani classical music .
 Professor B. R. Deodhar was awarded the 1964 Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship , the highest honour conferred by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama .
 Thereafter in 1976 , Professor B. R. Deodhar was awarded the Padma Shri , by Government of India .
 Professor B. R. Deodhar was born in Miraj in present Sangli district of Maharashtra on September 11 , 1901 .
 Professor B. R. Deodhar started Professor B. R. Deodhar musical training with Nilkanth Buwa Alurmath , the guru bhai of noted singer and educator Vishnu Digambar Paluskar , and a disciple of Balakrishnabuwa Ichalkaranjikar of Gwalior gharana .
 Thereafter , Professor B. R. Deodhar also received training under Abdul Karim Khan of Kirana gharana and Vinayak Rao Patwardhan , another disciple of Paluskar .
 Later Professor B. R. Deodhar joined the Gandharva Mahavidyalaya , where Professor B. R. Deodhar became a leading disciple of Vishnu Digambar Paluskar , the founder of institution .
 Professor B. R. Deodhar was the only student of Paluskar , who was allowed to also pursue formal education .
 Thus after matriculation Professor B. R. Deodhar also pursued higher education and later received a B.A. degree .
 Professor B. R. Deodhar also studied Western classical music .
 In the coming years , Professor B. R. Deodhar continued Professor B. R. Deodhar musical education from leading musicians of various traditions including those from Agra gharana , Mohanrao Pakelar from Jaipur gharana , sarangi - player Majeed Khan , Inayat Khan , Ganpatrao Dewaskar , Pt .
 Sadashivbuwa Jadhav of Gokhale gharana , Shinde Khan of Gwalior gharana , sitar-player Murad Khan of Indore , and most importantly , Bade Ghulam Ali Khan of Patiala gharana , with whom Gokhale remained associated for many years , and became an important musical influence on Gokhale gayaki , singing style .
Thus , he incorporate styles of several traditions , gharanas into his singing , and this also paved way for his career as a musicologist .
In time , he also collected musical compositions , rare ragas from all the traditions he was associated with , through his career .
He established the Deodhar School of Music in Mumbai , breaking from the gharana tradition .
He also edited Hindi music monthly magazine , Sangeet Kala Vihar , and also published several books on music and musicians .
 In 1964 , he was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship the highest honour conferred by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy for Music , Dance and Drama .
This was followed by Padma Shri , by Government of India in 1976 .
 Amongst Padma Shri noted disciples , were singer Kumar Gandharva , Saraswati Rane , and Laxmi Ganesh Tewari .
 In 1993 , Padma Shri monthly columns , in Sangeet Kala Vihar , which included biographies of 19th-century Indian musicians , were published as book , Pillars of Hindustani music
Gopal Shankar Misra was an Indian musician and music teacher , who played the vichitra veena .
Misras father , Lalmani Misra , was born in the 1920s and became a singer and instrumentalist who performed dhrupad and khyal , and played the tabla , the sitar , and revived the vichitra veena by creating playing-technique for it .
 In Gopal Shankar Misra early years Gopal Shankar Misra had toured the globe as music-director to dance troupe of Pt .
Uday Shankar .
 Dr. Lalmani Misra was a performing musician and an academic , who served as Dean of the Faculty of Performing Arts at Banaras Hindu University , where Gopal Shankar Misra worked as a teacher and administrator , until Gopal Shankar Misra death in 1979 .
This left the 22-year-old Gopal a challenge of work unfinished .
 The family eventually attained Gharana status when the third generation - the 22-year-old Gopal and Padmajas son and daughter , Gandharva and Shruti - began to excel at the veena .
 Gharana status was much later on that the Uday Shankar connection was to resurface a generation later , when the 22-year-old Gopal was invited to join the 1998 UK touring and Real World recording project made by State of Bengal and Ananda Shankar , Uday Shankars son .
 the 22-year-old Gopal was born in Kanpur , India in 1957 .
 the 22-year-old Gopal sister , his sister Ragini , was born some years later .
 the 22-year-old Gopal mother was Padma .
 Surrounded by and growing up with music , the 22-year-old Gopal interest deepened following an international tour with the 22-year-old Gopal father .
 the 22-year-old Gopal had studied vocal music and sitar since the age of four and was interested in cricket and other sports .
 At the age of 15 the 22-year-old Gopal interest in music turned serious .
 the 22-year-old Gopal father introduced his son in 1975 at Varanasi .
Chhotelal Mishra disciple of Pandit Anokhelal Mishra , accompanied Gopal who performed a rendering of Marwa , Chandrakauns and Pahadi on sitar .
Gopals mother died of cancer on 5 April 1977 .
His father , Lalmani Misra , took the children around the country , performing and meeting academics and musicians .
 As a visiting Professor at Penn University , Gopal Shankar Misra had to leave for a semester .
 a visiting Professor at Penn University recorded ample music lessons for the 22-year-old Gopal and his sister Ragini so that both excelled in their respective examinations .
 On a visiting Professor at Penn University return , a visiting Professor at Penn University developed an ache in a visiting Professor at Penn University back and had to rely more on a visiting Professor at Penn University children .
 the 22-year-old Gopal and his sister Ragini thereby received training in academics of music , which served Gopal and Ragini much later on .
 After the passing away of the 22-year-old Gopal mother , the 22-year-old Gopal had become devoted to the 22-year-old Gopal father and sister .
 When the 22-year-old Gopal father died , he started training his first student while he himself was learning .
 As time went by His students traveled from all over to learn Sitar and Vichitra Veena .
 His most dedicated disciple was His most dedicated disciple sister , his sister Ragini .
 Today his sister Ragini is the sole exponent of Misrabani .
 his sister Ragini plays the complex Misrabani compositions on Jhoomra Tal .
 Ragini credits his sister Ragini brother for instilling the innovation of their father so well , that his sister Ragini can play the toughest of compositions almost instantaneously .
 his sister Ragini presented 16 Pearls a non-stop string of sixteen compositions in sixteen different Raga-s , starting from sixteen consecutive beats on Trital .
 Gopal Shankar also inspired the 22-year-old Gopal sister to take up another instrument - jal tarang when his sister Ragini was in school .
 his sister Ragini has also been recognized as the first woman player of jal-tarang following Sitar gatkari in his sister Ragini presentation .
At this juncture , his devotion to the Veena intensified .
In playing Vichitra Veena , he felt closer to his father and through this , was able to draw much comfort in the coming years .
 Having observed his fathers chaste style of living , the 22-year-old Gopal bid adieu to his natural youthful manner and strictly followed an ascetic like life-style .
 At the age of 22 he was appointed lecturer in music at Banares Hindu University and shortly afterward became Doctor of Music in Sitar .
He had also studied Sanskrit for his M.A. degree .
Over the years he became a Grade A Indian musician , making several radio recordings and giving concerts , while encouraging a number of students to take up veena .
Teaching at Banaras Hindu University exposed him to many potential learners .
 Having inherited the art of imparting tid-bits of skill as well as wisdom about the swaroop of Raga , the swaroop of Raga had already taught the swaroop of Raga sister Ragini while still a student himself .
 Now , the swaroop of Raga ability to teach with patience was fully exploited .
 the swaroop of Raga students were not limited to a single instrument .
Kamala Shankar played guitar while Taranga Vilasini sports a santoor .
 His students from Korea , Sri Lanka , Canada , France , Germany etc. would come to Varanasi to learn with Taranga Vilasini .
 Taranga Vilasini was equally at home with theory and demonstration , and would often repeat Taranga Vilasini fathers advice , Dont discuss , do it .
 Completely at home with technology , Taranga Vilasini visual sensibility were equally strong .
 Taranga Vilasini would capture finger movements and other postures accurately on video , which proved immensely useful to Taranga Vilasini students .
 All Taranga Vilasini students would record His students sessions with Taranga Vilasini and return only after His students had perfected the phrase or melody .
 Taranga Vilasini teaching was effective as His teaching was inspiring .
Many of Gopal Shankars students are now teaching music at various levels .
 Many of Gopal Shankars students toured extensively in Kanpur , India in 1957 , USA and Europe and was fulfilling Many of Gopal Shankars students fathers wishes by introducing the instrument to new situations and audiences .
 Kanpur , India in 1957 was through Gopal Shankar Misra that the vichitra veena finally found wider international fame .
The veena is associated with Saraswati , the Goddess of learning in Hindu mythology .
In Hindi vichitra means peculiar and the veena is part of a family of chordophone or stringed instruments said to predate the sitar .
It evolved from the ancient Ban and later was known as Batta-Been .
 the 22-year-old Gopal inherited the style known as Misrabani , from the 22-year-old Gopal father who had brought the instrument to prominence in Northern Indian music .
 Gopal Shankar Misra was an acclaimed artiste of Sitar who was invited all across Indian and abroad .
 But because Vichitra Veena held a special meaning for Gopal Shankar Misra father , he could not let it lie silent .
The vichitra veena is made of a broad , fretless , horizontal arm or crossbar around three feet long and six inches wide , with two large resonating gourds , which are inlaid with ivory and attached underneath at either end .
 The narrow ends of the instrument are fashioned into peacock heads , the national bird of Kanpur , India in 1957 - a most appropriate carving as the 22-year-old Gopal often drew a metaphor between the colours in the birds tail and the musical range that the veena offers .
There are four main playing strings and five secondary strings , which are played openly with the little finger for a drone effect .
Underneath them are 13 sympathetic strings tuned to the notes of the appropriate raag .
The veena has a five-octave range .
Two plectrums identical to those used for sitar are worn on the middle and index fingers of the right hand to pluck the strings , and a glass ball is moved with the left across the main strings to create melody .
Olive oil or butter is put on the strings to ease the playing action .
The veena was often used to accompany the Dhrupad style of singing and this did not allow for much intricacy or embellishment around the notes .
 Along with portamento passages where the notes glide effortlessly into each other , the dramatic and vigorous plucking style , the jumping from note to note , was a stylistic departure developed in Gopals family tradition , Misrabani .
Through the efforts of Gopal Shankar Misra , a course of D.Mus .
 in Vichitra Veena was to be started by College of Music and Fine Arts , B.H.U. when Gopal Shankar Misra sudden demise at Bhopal on August 13 , 1999 while attending a function held in the memory of Gopal Shankar Misra father , Lalmani Misra bereaved besides his family , a number of existing and potential disciples .
He had authored the third part of Sangeet-Sarita , a series started by his father for middle-school students .
 Adept in the school of Misrabani , Misrabani contributed to this true Tantrakari style through performance as well as composition .
 A short article , Vichitra Veena : Innovations and Practices outlines Misrabani involvement and future plans for making this instrument more approachable .
 Misrabani major work dealing with compositions of vocal and instrumental music together in a single volume is yet to see the light of day .
 Those learning Vichitra Veena with Misrabani have turned to sister Ragini Trivedi who has been a guardian mentor to children , Shruti and Gandharva .

Jacket note by Alan James , Out of Stillness Real World Compact Disc , April 2000
Pandit Shankar Ghosh is a noted Indian tabla player from the Farukhabad gharana of Hindustani classical music .
 Pandit Shankar Ghosh is also an occasional Hindustani classical singer where Pandit Shankar Ghosh follows the Patiala gharana .
 Pandit Shankar Ghosh was awarded the 1999-2000 Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in Tabla , the highest Indian recognition given to practicing artists , by Sangeet Natak Akademi , Indias National Academy of Music , Dance & Drama .
 Pandit Shankar Ghosh started learning training taleem in 1953 under Pandit Gyan Prakash Ghosh of Calcutta , who pioneered the concept of tabla ensembles , which employed numerous tabla players playing the same pieces ; a tradition later taken forward by Pandit Ravi Shankar Pandit Ravi Shankar .
 Pandit Shankar Ghosh other gurus were Pt .
Gyan Prakash Ghosh , Ustad Feroz Khan , Pandit Anath Nath Bose and Pandit Sudarshan Adhikari .
He started touring the US in 1960s with sarod maestro , Ustad Ali Akbar Khan and won rave reviews , and over the years he toured with Pandit Ravi Shankar , Ustad Vilayat Khan , Pandit Nikhil Banerjee , Sharan Rani , Pandit V. G. Jog .
In India he has performed with vocalists such as Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan , Pandit Omkarnath Thakur , Pandit Vinayak Rao Patwardhan , Girija Devi and Smt .
Akhtari Bai .
 During Akhtari Bai . stay abroad Akhtari Bai . also collaborated with artists like Greg Ellis , Pete Lockett and John Bergamo .
 Akhtari Bai . has received awards like ITC Sangeet Research Academy award and the Ustad Hafiz Ali Khan award .
 Teaching tabla over three decades , presently Akhtari Bai . teaches in institutions at Kolkata , Paris and Bonn .
 Akhtari Bai . is married to Hindustani classical vocalist of Patiala gharana , Sanjukta Ghosh , and is the father of the tabla maestro Bickram Ghosh , whom Akhtari Bai . has also trained in tabla , and who went on to perform with musical legends like Ustad Ali Akbar Khan and Pandit Ravi Shankar
Sheema Mukherjee is a British composer and sitar player .
 the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee is best known for the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee work with musical collective Transglobal Underground and The Imagined Village .
 the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee is the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee .
 In 2005 , Billboard referred to the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee as a sitar prodigy .
 Sheema Mukherjee studied Hindustani classical music under the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee uncle Nikhil Banerjee , Ali Akbar Khan and later Aashish Khan .
 In 1998 the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee joined Transglobal Underground .
 In 2005 , the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee composed the music for the West Yorkshire Playhouse productions Gluey and the Lion and Non-Contact Time .
 the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee also composed the score for the Tamasha Theatre Company s 2009 musical Wuthering Heights .
 the niece of sitarist Nikhil Banerjee composition Bending in the Dark was featured during the 2012 Summer Olympics
Petr Kroutil is a Czech musician and actor .
 Petr Kroutil is a clarinettist , saxophonist , bansuri player , vocalist , composer and arranger .
 Petr Kroutil studied jazz music from a very young age and began playing the recorder at the age of six .
 By the age of nine , Petr Kroutil had begun studying the clarinet .
 After graduating from high school Petr Kroutil went on to study at The Jaroslav Jezek Conservatory of Music graduating with a degree in Jazz Performance .
 Then Petr Kroutil attended the Berklee College of Music in Boston , Massachusetts , until 2003 , studying performance and jazz composition .
 In 1991 , at the age of eighteen , Petr Kroutil became a member of the extremely successful big band , the Original Prague Syncopated Orchestra .
The band , which concentrated on performing music from the 1930s era , toured Europe and North Africa extensively .
 After starring as Danny in the romantic comedy Prima Sezona - The Swell Season , an adaptation of the novel by Josef Skvorecky , Petr Kroutil gained fame in the Czech Republic .
He also recorded and performed the soundtrack for the mini-series .
 In 1996 , Petr Kroutil co-established the big band The Prague Swing Orchestra , specializing in swing music of the 1940s .
 As the lead soloist , singer and emcee for P.S.O , P.S.O played at some of the most prestigious jazz festivals in Europe .
In addition , the orchestra has performed many live jazz concerts which were televised and internationally broadcast .
 In 1997 , Petr Kroutil also formed a modern jazz quintet `` Pratele Ticheho Jazzu '' influenced by American West Coast musicians like Stan Getz , Gerry Mulligan and Chet Baker .
The members of the quintet were the top Czech jazz players .
 In 2002 , Petr Kroutil released an album Bhakti Junction in London with established singer Renu Gidoomal .
The British-Indian Jazz-Fusion album includes two original compositions by Kroutil .
 Petr Kroutil became a member of the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line s orchestra in 2003 .
The Orchestra performed with some of the top American jazz and pop musicians including The Platters with Herb Reid , Marty Allen , Kenny James , Victor Mendoza 's Afro-Latin American Big Band and Joe Mareiny who had been a member of Louis Armstrong 's The All Stars Band .
 Living in Nepal 's from 2004-2005 , he studied bamboo flute or bansuri and classical Indian music at the Kathmandu University Department of Music .
He also established his own band The Mc Twisters , performing his own compositions .
 Although the band only survived two years , it became very successful in Nepal 's and India .
The Mc Twisters were nominated for Nepali Grammys in 2006 .
 Co members of the band are the finest Nepal 's players : Manoj , Nirakar , Adrian and Sanjey from the famous , multi Nepali Grammy winner band 1974 A.D. Returning home to the Czech Republic in August 2005 , Petr Kroutil formed a brand new trio called Shanti , which performs mostly Nirakar original compositions and some standards .
 Nirakar is also a co-front man for the top Czech jazz singer Jana Koubkova 's band .
 In 2006 Petr Kroutil started Petr Kroutil own band called Petr Kroutil Orchestra which plays not only jazz standards , but Petr Kroutil originals as well .
 Petr 's co-musicians are well known and established colleagues who teach in Prague 's Jazz The Jaroslav Jezek Conservatory of Music Of Jaroslav Jezek .
 In Autumn 2007 Petr Kroutil permormed with a living legend of Russian rock music - mystical Boris Grebenschicov .
 Instead of hard rock music , Petr 's co-musicians performed together tibetians mantras for over 800 thrilled listeners .
 For Michal Horacek Michal Horacek recorded all wind instruments for the most selling and successful album of a year - Ohrozeny druh .
 With Petr 's long time friend - Renu Gidoomal , Petr 's long time friend - Renu Gidoomal recorded a new CD for Kids called Human Values , released in UK in October 2010 .
In the same time they performed together on Trafalgar Square for over 25000 people with their - Bhajazz concept .
 Petr Kroutil came back to London and to the Trafalgar Square again during the summer 2012 where Petr Kroutil was performing for the River Of Music Festival .
 London was the most ambitious music project ever done in London .
 Over 2000 musicians from all around the world was performing on five stages around London just before the Olympic games started .
 Petr Kroutil was chosen as the only one from the Czech republic and Petr Kroutil performed with Budapest Bar from Hungary .
The concert itself was broadcast by BBC
Talvin Singh Matharoo , is a producer and composer and tabla player , known for creating an innovative fusion of Indian classical music and drum and bass .
Singh is generally considered involved with an electronica sub genre called Asian Underground , and more recently as Indian and/or Asian electronica .
 After collaborating with Siouxsie and the the Banshees and Bjork in the early 1990s , Singh released Siouxsie debut album Ok which received the Mercury Music Prize in 1999 .
Singh has since collaborated with a variety of acts including Madonna and Massive Attack .
Singh grew up in Leytonstone and began playing the tablas as a child .
At the age of 16 , Singh went to India for two years where he studied tabla under Pandit Lashman Singh .
He then returned to the UK after just one year .
In spite of this classical training , Singhs tabla playing was not accepted by British promoters of classical Indian music , as he incorporated too strongly his western influences .
By the late 1980s , Singh had decided to turn towards the fusion of sounds .
 In 1991 , he came to prominence by both playing tabla and singing on the Kiss Them for Me single by Siouxsie and the Banshees : the single peaked in the Billboard Hot 100 at number 23 .
Singh then became the sixth member of the Banshees and took part with them as second headliners of the inaugural Lollapalooza tour .
 Two years later in 1993 , he was recruited by Bjork to be Bjork percussionist and director on Bjork 1993s Debut album .
 In late 1995 , Singh founded the Anokha club night with promoter Sweety Kapoor at East Londons Blue Note , where drumnbass DJs and South Asian punk bands went head to head with the amped-up sounds of South Asian tabla and percussion .
Guest spots by LTJ Bukem and others made Anokha a Monday-night hotspot in London , and Singh signed to Island for an Anokha compilation including several of his own productions .
 Anokha worked as a remixer , for Blondie on LTJ Bukem and others Maria single .
In 1998 , Singh released his solo debut album , Ok .
The record was critically acclaimed and received the prestigious Mercury Music Prize in 1999 .
That same year , he also collaborated with David Sylvian .
 In 2000 , he worked with Madonna for Madonna album , Music .
Singh is an accomplished Tabla player , electronic musician , music theorist , record producer and DJ .
As a solo artist , he is perhaps best known as the father of modern Asian electronica music , though he is also a highly celebrated tabla player , record producer and visual practitioner .
 Drawing inspiration from the classical Indian arts , Singh first came to prominence as a tabla percussionist in the 1980s London music scene .
 Whilst still in his mid-teens , Singh traveled to India for two years to earn pupillage from Acharya Pandit Laxman Singh , master tabla maestro of the Punjab school .
This period made an indelible mark on the young artist and he has since continued to practice and perform the art form internationally .
Singh 's collaborations with Indian classical musicians include Ustad Sultan Khan , Rakesh Churasia , Ustad Imrat Khan and Ustad Amjad Ali Khan amongst scores of others .
Singh also became involved in experimental music collaborations beginning in the late 1980s , working with Sun Ra and Courtney , which helped to popularize the burgeoning Asian underground sub-culture movement .
Singh is notable for re-introducing the concepts of Indian classical music to western pop , dance and Jazz genres in the late 1980s and early 1990s .
Singh 's solo album credits include critical and commercial successes Ok -- which won the UK 's two most prestigious music prizes , ` The South Bank Prize ' and the Mercury Prize in 1999 .
 Ok , his groundbreaking '98 debut release , was recorded in Mumbai , Madras , Okinawa , New York and London , featuring contributions from Bill Laswell , Ryuichi Sakamoto , Ustad Sultan Khan and the Madras Philharmonic Orchestra amongst others .
 Singh has pursued several artistic ventures parallel to and in conjunction with his music career , including creating the seminal London club ANOKHA , performing at the Tate Gallery in London , creating a sound installation at the Frith Street Gallery in London and composing music for various experimental dance , theatre and film projects .
In 1990 Singh conceived the Tablatronic , a hybrid electronic/analog tabla which utilizes a rare internal microphone system .
 In 2010 , Talvin Singh won an award at the the UK 's Asian Music Awards for his Commitment to Scene
George Harrison , was an English musician , singer and songwriter who achieved international fame as the lead guitarist of the Beatles .
 Although John Lennon and Paul McCartney were the bands primary songwriters , most of John Lennon and Paul McCartney albums included at least one Harold Hargreaves Harrison composition , including While US Guitar Gently Weeps , Here Comes the Sun and Something , which became the Beatles second most-covered song .
Harrisons earliest musical influences included Big Bill Broonzy , George Formby and Django Reinhardt ; Chet Atkins , Chuck Berry and Ry Cooder were significant later influences .
 By 1965 he had begun to lead the Beatles into folk rock through his interest in the the Byrds and Bob Dylan , and towards Indian classical music through his use of the sitar on Norwegian Wood .
He developed an interest in the Hare Krishna movement and became an admirer of Indian culture and mysticism , introducing them to the other members of the Beatles and their Western audience by incorporating Indian instrumentation in their music .
 After the bands break-up in 1970 , Harold Hargreaves Harrison released the triple album All Things Must Pass , from which two hit singles originated .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison also organized the 1971 Concert for Bangladesh with Ravi Shankar , a precursor for later benefit concerts such as Live Aid .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison was a music and film producer as well as a musician ; Harold Hargreaves Harrison founded Dark Horse Records in 1974 and co-founded HandMade Films in 1978 .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison released several best-selling singles and albums as a solo performer , and in 1988 co-founded the platinum-selling supergroup the Traveling Wilburys .
 A prolific recording artist , A prolific recording artist was featured as a guest guitarist on tracks by Badfinger , Ronnie Wood and Billy Preston , and collaborated on songs and music with Bob Dylan , Eric Clapton and Tom Petty , among others .
 Rolling Stone magazine ranked A prolific recording artist number 11 in their list of the 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time .
 Harrisons The first marriage , to Pattie Boyd , ended in divorce in 1977 .
 The following year Harrisons Hindu married Olivia Trinidad Arias , with whom Harrisons Hindu had one son , his son Dhani .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison died in 2001 , aged 58 , from lung cancer .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison was cremated and Harold Hargreaves Harrison ashes were scattered in the Ganges and Yamuna rivers in India , in a private ceremony according to Hindu tradition .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison left almost PS100 million in Harold Hargreaves Harrison will .
 Born in Liverpool , Lancashire , England , on 25 February 1943 , Harold Hargreaves Harrison was the youngest of four children of Harold Hargreaves Harrison and Harold Hargreaves Harrison wife Louise .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison had one sister , his wife Louise , and two brothers , Harry and his brother Peter .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison mother was a shop assistant from a Catholic family with Irish roots , and Harold Hargreaves Harrison father was a bus conductor who had worked as a ships steward on the White Star Line .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison future wife , the model Pattie Boyd , described Harrisons Hindu parents as quite short and very Liverpudlian .
 According to the model Pattie Boyd , Harrisons Hindu mother was particularly supportive : All the model Pattie Boyd wanted for the model Pattie Boyd children is that they should be happy , and the model Pattie Boyd recognized that nothing made George quite as happy as making music .
 An enthusiastic music fan , the model Pattie Boyd was known among friends for the model Pattie Boyd loud singing voice , which at times startled visitors by rattling the Harrisons windows .
 While pregnant with George quite as happy , the model Pattie Boyd often listened to the weekly broadcast Radio India .
 Harrisons biographer Joshua Greene wrote , Every Sunday the model Pattie Boyd tuned in to mystical sounds evoked by sitars and tablas , hoping that the exotic music would bring peace and calm to the baby in the womb .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison was born and lived the first six years of Harold Hargreaves Harrison life at 12 Arnold Grove , Wavertree , Liverpool , in a terraced house in a cul-de-sac .
 The home had an outdoor toilet and The home only heat came from a single coal fire .
In 1949 the family was offered a council house and moved to 25 Upton Green , Speke .
 In 1948 , at the age of five , Harold Hargreaves Harrison enrolled at Dovedale Primary School .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison passed Harold Hargreaves Harrison 11-plus examination and attended the prestigious Liverpool Institute from 1954 to 1959 .
 Harrisons Hindu earliest musical influences included George Formby , Cab Calloway , Django Reinhardt , Hoagy Carmichael , and Big Bill Broonzy .
 In early 1956 Harrisons Hindu had an epiphany : while riding Harrisons Hindu bicycle , Harrisons Hindu heard Elvis Presley s Heartbreak Hotel playing from a nearby house , and the song piqued Harrisons Hindu interest in rock and roll .
 Harrisons Hindu often sat at the back of the class drawing guitars in Harrisons Hindu schoolbooks , and later commented , US was totally into guitars .
 Although apprehensive about Harrisons Hindu sons interest in pursuing a music career , in late 1956 Harrisons Hindu father bought Harrisons Hindu a Dutch Egmond flat top acoustic guitar .
 A friend of Harrisons Hindu fathers taught Harold Hargreaves Harrison how to play Whispering , Sweet Sue , and Dinah , and inspired by the music of Lonnie Donegan , Harold Hargreaves Harrison formed a skiffle group called the Rebels with the Rebels brother his brother Peter and a friend , Arthur Kelly .
 On the bus to school Harold Hargreaves Harrison met Paul McCartney , who became a member of John Lennon s band the Quarrymen , and the pair bonded over their shared love of music .
 In March 1958 Harold Hargreaves Harrison auditioned for the Quarrymen at Rory Storm s Morgue Skiffle Club , playing Guitar Boogie Shuffle , but John Lennon felt that Harold Hargreaves Harrison , then 14 , was too young to join the band .
 During a second meeting , arranged by McCartney , he performed the lead guitar part for the instrumental Raunchy on the upper deck of a Liverpool bus .
Soon afterwards he began socializing with the group , filling in on guitar as needed , and by the time he turned 15 they had accepted him as a member .
 Although his father wanted him to continue his education , Harold Hargreaves Harrison left school at 16 and worked for several months as an apprentice electrician at Blacklers , a local department store .
In 1960 Allan Williams arranged for the band , now calling themselves the Beatles , to play at the Kaiserkeller club in Hamburg , owned by Bruno Koschmider .
 The impromptu musical education Harold Hargreaves Harrison received while playing long hours with the Beatles , as well as the guitar lessons Harold Hargreaves Harrison took from Tony Sheridan while they briefly served as Harold Hargreaves Harrison backing group , laid the foundations of Harold Hargreaves Harrison sound and of Harold Hargreaves Harrison quiet , professional role within the group ; Harold Hargreaves Harrison was later known as the quiet Beatle .
 The bands The first residency in Hamburg ended prematurely when Harold Hargreaves Harrison was deported for being too young to work in nightclubs .
 When Brian Epstein became John Lennon and Paul McCartney manager in December 1961 , Brian Epstein polished John Lennon and Paul McCartney image and secured John Lennon and Paul McCartney a recording contract with the EMI Studios .
 The groups The first single , Love Me Do , peaked at number seventeen on the Record Retailer chart , and by the time John Lennon and Paul McCartney debut album , Please Please US , was released in early 1963 , Beatlemania had arrived .
 Their second album , With the Beatles , included Dont Bother Me , Harrisons Hindu The first solo writing credit .
 By 1965s Rubber Soul , Harold Hargreaves Harrison had begun to lead the other Beatles into folk rock through Harold Hargreaves Harrison interest in the the Byrds and Bob Dylan , and towards Indian classical music through Harold Hargreaves Harrison use of the sitar on Norwegian Wood .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison later called Rubber Soul Harold Hargreaves Harrison favourite album .
 Revolver included three of his compositions : Taxman , Love You To and US Want to Tell You .
 Taxman introduction of the drone-like tambura part on Lennons Tomorrow Never Knows exemplified the bands ongoing exploration of non-Western instruments .
 The tabla - driven Love You To was the Beatles The first genuine foray into Indian music .
According to the ethnomusicologist David Reck , the song set a precedent in popular music as an example of Asian culture being represented by Westerners respectfully and without parody .
 Harold Hargreaves Harrison continued to develop Harold Hargreaves Harrison interest in non-Western instrumentation , playing swarmandal on Strawberry Fields Forever .
 By late 1966 Harrisons Hindu interests had moved away from the Beatles , as reflected in Harrisons Hindu choice of Eastern gurus and religious leaders for inclusion on the album cover for Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band in 1967 .
 Harrisons Hindu sole composition on the album was the Indian-inspired Within You Without You , to which no other Beatle contributed .
 Harrisons Hindu played sitar and tambura on the track , backed by musicians from the London Asian Music Circle on dilruba , swarmandal and tabla .
 In 1968 Harrisons Hindu song The Inner Light was recorded at the EMI Studios in Bombay , featuring a group of local musicians playing traditional Indian instruments .
 Released as the B-side to McCartneys Lady Madonna , it was the The first Harold Hargreaves Harrison composition to appear on a Beatles single .
 Derived from a quotation from the Tao Te Ching , the songs lyric reflected Harrisons deepening interest in Hinduism and meditation , while musically a quotation from the Tao Te Ching embraced the Karnatak discipline of Indian music , rather than the Hindu style of Hindu previous work in the genre .
 Bob Dylan and the Band were a major musical influence on Harold Hargreaves Harrison at the end of Bob Dylan career with the Beatles .
 Bob Dylan established a friendship with Bob Dylan and found Bob Dylan drawn to the Bands sense of communal music-making and to the creative equality among the band members , in contrast with John Lennon and McCartneys domination of the Beatles songwriting and creative direction .
 This coincided with a prolific period in Bob Dylan songwriting and Bob Dylan growing desire to assert Bob Dylan independence from the band .
During the recording of The Beatles in 1968 , tensions ran high , and drummer Ringo Starr quit briefly .
 Harrisons songwriting contributions to the album included While US Guitar Gently Weeps , which featured Eric Clapton on lead guitar , Piggies , Long , Long , Long , and Savoy Truffle .
Tensions among the Beatles surfaced again during the filming of rehearsals at Twickenham Studios in January 1969 for what became the album Let It Be .
 Frustrated by the poor working conditions in the cold and sterile film studio , as well as by what he perceived as Lennons creative disengagement from the Beatles and a domineering attitude from McCartney , Harold Hargreaves Harrison quit the group on 10 January 1969 , but agreed to return twelve days later .
Relations among the Beatles were more cordial , though still strained , during sessions for their final recorded album , Abbey Road .
 The LP included two of Harrisons most respected Beatles compositions : Here Comes the Sun and Something , which became one half of the Beatles The first double-sided number one single , Harrisons The first A-side , and Harrisons first A-side The first chart topper .
In 1969 Frank Sinatra recorded Something , and later dubbed it the greatest love song of the past fifty years .
 John Lennon considered it the best song on Abbey Road , and it became the Beatles second most covered song after Yesterday .
 Author Peter Lavezzoli wrote : Harold Hargreaves Harrison would finally achieve equal songwriting status ... with Harold Hargreaves Harrison two classic contributions to the final Beatles LP .
 In April 1970 when Harrisons For You Blue was released in America as a double A-side with McCartneys The Long and Winding Road , it became the bands second chart-topping double A-side and For You Harrisons For You Blue became Harrisons Hindu second number one hit .
 Harrisons Hindu increased productivity and the Beatles reluctance to include Harrisons Hindu songs on John Lennon and Paul McCartney albums meant that by the time of John Lennon and Paul McCartney break-up Harrisons Hindu had amassed a stockpile of unreleased compositions .
 While Harold Hargreaves Harrison grew as a songwriter , Harold Hargreaves Harrison compositional presence on Beatles albums remained limited to two or three songs , increasing Harold Hargreaves Harrison frustration , and significantly contributing to the bands break-up .
 Harrisons Hindu last recording session with the Beatles was on 4 January 1970 , when Harrisons Hindu , McCartney and drummer Ringo Starr recorded the Harrisons Hindu song I Me US .
 Before the Beatles break-up Harrisons Hindu had already recorded and released two solo albums : Wonderwall Music and Electronic Sound , both of which include mainly instrumental compositions .
 Wonderwall Music , a soundtrack to the 1968 film Wonderwall , blends Indian and Western instrumentation , while Electronic Sound is an experimental album that prominently features a Moog synthesizer .
 Released in November 1968 , Wonderwall Music was the The first solo album by a the quiet Beatle and the The first LP released by Apple Records .
 Indian musicians Aashish Khan and Shivkumar Sharma performed on the album , which contains the experimental sound collage Dream Scene , recorded several months before Lennons Revolution 9 .
 In December 1969 Harrisons Hindu participated in a brief tour of Europe with the American group Delaney & Bonnie and Friends .
 During the tour that included Clapton , Bobby Whitlock , drummer Jim Gordon and band leaders Delaney Bramlett and Bonnie Bramlett , Harrisons Hindu began to write My Sweet Lord , which became My Sweet Lord The first single as a solo artist .
 Delaney Bramlett inspired Harrisons Hindu to learn slide guitar , significantly influencing Delaney Bramlett later music .
 After years of being restricted in Delaney Bramlett songwriting contributions to the Beatles albums , Harrisons Hindu released All Things Must Pass .
 the triple album All Things Must Pass was a triple album , with two discs of Delaney Bramlett songs and the third of recordings of Harrison jamming with Friends .
 Regarded by many as Delaney Bramlett best work , the album topped the charts on both sides of the Atlantic .
 The LP produced the number-one hit single US Sweet Lord and the top-ten single What Is Life .
 The album was co-produced by Phil Spector using My Sweet Lord Wall of Sound approach , and the musicians included drummer Ringo Starr , Clapton , Gary Wright , Billy Preston , Klaus Voormann , the whole of Delaney Bramlett and Bonnies Friends band and the Apple group Badfinger .
Ben Gerson of Rolling Stone described All Things Must Pass as being of classic Spectorian proportions , Wagnerian , Brucknerian , the music of mountain tops and vast horizons .
 Author and musicologist Ian Inglis considered the lyrics of the albums title track a recognition of the impermanence of human existence ... a simple and poignant conclusion to Harrisons Hindu former band .
 In 1971 Bright Tunes sued Harrison for copyright infringement over US Sweet Lord owing to its similarity to the 1963 Chiffons hit Hes So Fine .
He denied deliberately plagiarizing the song , but lost the court case in 1976 as the judge ruled that he had done so subconsciously .
 In 2000 Apple Records released a thirtieth anniversary edition of the album and Harrisons Hindu actively participated in its promotion , giving an interview during which Harrisons Hindu reflected on the work : Its just something that was like US continuation from the Beatles , really .
 It was US sort of getting out of the Beatles and just going US own way ... it was a very happy occasion .
 He commented on the production : Well , in those days it was like the reverb was kind of used a bit more than what US would do now .
 In fact , US dont use reverb at all .
 US cant stand it ... You know , its hard to go back to anything thirty years later and expect it to be how you would want it now .
 Responding to a request from Ravi Shankar , Harrisons Hindu organized a charity event , the Concert for Bangladesh , which took place on 1 August 1971 , drawing over 40,000 people to two shows in New Yorks Madison Square Garden .
The goal of the event was to raise money to aid starving refugees during the Bangladesh Liberation War .
 sitar maestro Ravi Shankar opened the show , which featured popular musicians such as Bob Dylan , Clapton , Leon Russell , Badfinger , Billy Preston and drummer Ringo Starr .
A triple album , The Concert for Bangladesh , was released by Apple Corps that year , followed by a concert film in 1972 .
 Tax troubles and questionable expenses later tied up many of the proceeds , but Harrisons Hindu commented : Mainly the concert was to attract attention to the situation ... The money we raised was The money we raised , and although we had some money problems ... they still got plenty ... even though it was a drop in the ocean .
The main thing was , we spread the word and helped get the war ended .
The event has been described as an innovative precursor for the large-scale charity rock shows that followed , including Live Aid .
 Living in the Material World held the number one spot on the Billboard album chart for five weeks , and the albums single , Give US Love , also reached number one in the US .
In the UK , the LP achieved number two , spending 12 weeks on the charts with the single peaking at number 8 .
The album was lavishly produced and packaged , and its dominant message was Harrisons Hindu beliefs .
 In Upton Green opinion Greenes opinion contained many of the strongest compositions of Harrisons Hindu career .
Rolling Stone Stephen Holden declared the album vastly appealing and profoundly seductive ... stands alone as an article of faith , miraculous in its radiance .
 Other reviewers were less enthusiastic , describing the release as awkward , sanctimonious and overly sentimental , a reaction that left Harrisons Hindu despondent .
 In November 1974 Harrisons Hindu began Harrisons Hindu 45-date Dark Horse Tour , becoming the The first ex-Beatle to tour North America .
 In addition to performances by Harrison with an ensemble of musicians such as Billy Preston , Tom Scott , Willie Weeks , Andy Newmark and Jim Horn , the tour also included traditional and contemporary Indian music performed by Ravi Shankar , Family and Friends .
